reviewText:
Australia: The Game

In a world where there is no law or order and madness reigns, Warner Brothers presents a triple A title that doesn't run like it's in Early Access.

Pros:
Runs great even on systems that barely meet minimum specs. Extremely well optimized.
Looks great even on normal settings.
Surprisingly satisfying combat for a system that only uses LMB and RMB.
Driving and car combat are great.
You can literally spend days of your life doing every single side quest.
The only thing that could make this game more macho is objectifying women.

Cons:
Keep getting in the car on the wrong side.
Losing days of your life to this game.
No naked women to objectify.

11/10 would witness again.

reviewText: Oh what a game, WHAT A LOVELY GAME!
voteText: 4,117 of 4,867 people (85%) found this review helpful 3,177 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Introduction
Mad Max is a post-apocalyptic, open-world action game featuring Max, a man haunted by his past. Your goal is travel across the Sands of Silence but to do so you’re going to have to build a new car capable of the long journey, after your trusty Black on Black is stolen by the Immortal Scrotus. Much to Max’s dismay, he can’t build this car alone and must enlist the help of several characters from across the Great White, including the trusty blackfinger, Chumbucket.

Presentation
Mad Max is an incredibly good looking game. The graphics are excellent even when not running the game on maxed out settings (I was playing on normal-high) but adding all the bells and whistles makes this game absolutely gorgeous. The character and vehicle models are all very detailed, particularly Max and The Magnum Opus (the car you’re building). MM’s User Interface is minimalistic and clean, only showing you information that you need when you need it and most of it stays out of the way during regular gameplay. The main menu, in my opinion, is where the presentation is let down slightly. For the most part the menu is easy to navigate but when choosing settings you have to select each setting before editing it and then save each setting individually, not only did this make changing settings significantly slower than usual, it also meant that I kept accidentally returning to the previous menu by trying to change values before selection the option.

Gameplay
MM’s gameplay predominantly consists of combat, both on-foot and while in vehicles, both are fun but not without issues. Melee combat is effectively the same as in the Batman games apart from the fact that you don’t have to jump all over the room to keep your combo going, Max isn’t quite as agile as Batman. As well as your fists, sometimes you can find melee weapons, such as maces, though these break after a few hits. However, it’s not all good; you’ll never be attacked by two enemies at once (apart from charging enemies) which makes controlling a fight a little too easy, once you start building up a heavy attack you can’t interrupt it to counter an enemy and enemies always use the same tactics so they very quickly become predictable. Vehicular combat is easily one of the best parts of MM, there’s nothing quite as satisfying as taking on a convoy though taking on two or three cars can sometime feel tedious. To aid you in vehicular combat you can unlock and upgrade several weapons throughout the game such as a harpoon, rim grinders and anti-boarder spikes. MM also features several abilities to use during vehicular combat (most of which are unlocked alongside Opus upgrades) such as the ‘ricochet bash’ which smashes you from a car on one side to one on your other side, dealing increased damage.

These two types of combat are used across the game’s activities. What are these activities? There’s the obvious story missions and side missions, both of which I’ll return to later, but you also can liberate enemy bases, disarm minefields, take down enemy scarecrows and sniper towers, go up in hot air balloons to survey the area you’re in and of course, take down enemy convoys. Apart from the hot air balloons, all of these activities contribute to lowering the danger in a region which in turn unlocks upgrades for the Magnum Opus.

Story
If you’re familiar with the films, you’ll know that they aren’t as popular as they are because they have stellar plots, it’s all about the action. This game very much follows the same rule. While the game does have a story-arc it doesn’t really get more complex than what I mentioned in my introduction, it mainly consists of going to certain places to get certain things in order to upgrade the Opus. Of course there are some missions which aren’t like this but those are pretty much just to get them to help you get more Opus parts. I won’t say too much about it, so that I don’t spoil the story for those who care, but I personally found the ending a little disappointing. The final boss fight was nowhere near as difficult as it should have been, I breezed through it in around five minutes, and the story sort of just ends after that fight with no implication as to what Max is going to do, they’re probably setting it up for a sequel or DLC. The main missions and side missions take around 20 hours to complete, the rest of my playtime comes from doing the other activities that I mentioned, not bad for the price.

Customisation
Mad Max features a great deal of customisation options for three different ‘things’. First and foremost, we have the upgrades for the Magnum Opus, with eighteen different categories and between three and twelve upgrades for each category there are a huge number of options for your car. It’s also not just a case of the more expensive thing is better, some upgrades have a negative impact on your car as well as positive ones so it’s important to find a good balance which suits your play-style. Up next, we have the upgrades for Max himself. With eight different categories there’s a lot you can do with Max; you can choose his jacket, his hair and beard style, what shotgun he uses as well as unlock skills which help you in melee combat. Unlike with the Opus, all of these upgrades (excluding the skills and tools categories where each upgrade is separate) provide and improvement over the one from the previous level. On top of all of these, you also get upgrades from a character called Griffa using Griffa tokens which you earn by levelling up. Griffa upgrades include improved maximum health, longer lasting melee weapons, and the ability to find more water. Lastly, you can upgrade the Strongholds which you find across the Great White, these upgrades directly benefit Max, for example building an Armoury at a Stronghold will refill all of your ammunition when you travel to said Stronghold and building a Water Tower will refill your canteen.

Audio
The audio in this game is, apart from the occasional bug, absolutely spot on. The voice acting is excellent, particularly from the actors playing Max, Chumbucket and Stank Gum. The game’s soundtrack is fitting, there’s even a nice little Fury Road easter egg thrown in. The sound effects are also very good, particularly the bone crunching combat sounds and the engine and nitro sounds for the Opus. However, I did encounter an audio bug several times where certain sound effects would not play for minutes at a time such as no engine sound or no sounds during combat.

Miscellaneous
As you will have heard, the game’s optimisation is incredibly good, I had a solid 30FPS running the game on normal-high on my pretty mediocre PC
The map is pretty damn big, taking a fair few minutes to drive from one end to the other. Of course most of it is empty but what do you expect from a post-apocalyptic wasteland?
The non-story/side mission activities get incredibly repetitive, not so much capturing War Boy bases or taking on convoys but driving around to pull down scarecrows or search for scrap gets pretty boring
There’s a first person camera for when you’re in a vehicle, not a major thing but it’s pretty cool to see the wasteland through Max’s eyes
Mad Max features the same incredibly good Capture mode as Shadow of Mordor which if you’re a fan of screenshots, is just great. MM’s Capture mode even allows you to record videos, though I didn’t try that out myself
As well as the Magnum Opus you can drive any vehicles which you take from enemies and the store in Strongholds
Verdict
Essential Purchase.

Mad Max is a fantastically good post-apocalyptic, open-world game with great graphics, tons of customisation and a lot of activities to keep you busy.

Just Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Wasteland scrap collector extraodinare
Well plow me down with a Magnum Opus. Not only did we receive a wonderfully frenetic rebooting of the Mad Max film franchise this year with Mad Mad: Fury Road - an insane post apocalyptic ride into madness that did incredible justice to its source material - here we have Warner Bros. game publishing unit pushing out a film tie-in (no reason to head for the hills just yet or set fire to your cat at the sound of film tie-in) with the expert help of those video game wizards at Avalanche Studios - creators of the explosively destructive Just Cause series whose main protagonist CIA agent Rico Rodriguez mirrors the Max from the film franchise with destructive ease simply replacing the desert with Tropicana. If it initially seemed like a fit made in heaven in the boardrooms of Warner Bros when deciding who to outsource the license to then that person who made the decision to hand the reigns over to Avalanche Studios should be given a nice pat on the back accompanied with a bonus cheque.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=545200255
As far as the game goes it's a familiar tale of revenge served with a side order of burly spunk which sees our main protagonist Max undertake a mission to retrieve everything taken from him (including his car) by a war mongering maniac known as Scrotus who is hell bent on post apocalyptic wasteland domination. Thankfully our hero has a sidekick that he tags along  from very early within the game - a grotesque little genius of a mechanic known as Chum Bucket - who convinces our hero to rebuild the Magnum Opus (a car of unparalleled destructive force) and race across the Plains of Silence to silence the demons of the wasteland once and forever. This grand mission will require lots of scrap metal collecting and bonding with various war factions scattered around the large map in order to complete. Completing missions for each of these outposts results in not only special parts being issued which then can be used to further assemble the Magnum Opus but threat levels being lowered in the area which also confers bonuses such as extra ammunition and health being dispensed when visiting each location which certainly does come in handy because the wasteland is filled with punks and maniacs who serve to protect Scrotus domination over the land and who are hellbent on clubbing you into oblivion whether that be on foot or in a vehicle.

Your Magnum Opus won't be much to look at when you first assemble it but putting in some time to deal with Scrotus's threat levels around the map will slowly see you start earning parts that you can upgrade your vehicle with and that incrementally start to make you a force to be reckoned with. It's a slow drip feed reward system that will see you burning rubber from one end of the map to the other and while it does get rather tiresome at a certain point in the game it's still strangely hypnotically satisfying. Hand to hand combat will also feel immediately familiar to anyone who has previously played Assassin's Creed or Batman Arkam franchise as the combat is ripped directly from both those games where you will be surrounded by punks trying to pommel you into dust with the game giving you visual clues when to dodge or block. Vehicle combat on the other hand, which plays out like Need For Speed or The Crew on Crystal Meth, is incredibly satisfying especially when you start to earn various explosive appendages for your vehicle such as Thundersticks or the ability to leave a trail of fire behind you burning anyone or anything that comes into close contact with you. It's hugely entertaining and often results in spectacular non-scripted explosions around you as you take each threat down.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511280079
Where Mad Max falters somewhat is that for an open world game it sadly suffers from a strong case of Ubisoft-ituss. Taking a leaf from Ubisoft, who have mined a gold mint out of this particular formula, sadly means that a lot of the irritations that stem from those games have found their way into this release as well. Many of the quest you undertake will have you running from one end of the map to the next dealing with some faction that plays out exactly the same as the previous twenty before them. There is very little variety and soon each encounter starts to bleed into the next. The game also makes the mistake of thinking ramping up difficulty is solved by simply throwing more enemies at you - which as some of you will already know is a passionate gripe of mine when it comes to open world games. Also for a surprisingly large map their is very little variety in terms of what you can do which is a sad shame because it does get repetitive. I had to take weeks long breaks from the game because of this repetition which would sadly lead to boredom if unchecked.

On a whole though Mad Max is a real treat that runs like a hot knife through butter. Mad Max is optimized within an inch of its life and I never encountered a single issue bug wise with the game. Mad Max was one of the few games for me that simply just worked out of the box and for that I am incredibly grateful...so much so that I will be pre-purchasing Just Cause 3 based on my experiences with this game. Avalanche Studios needs to be commended for putting out a game that wasn't a complete train wreck at launch. Mad Max, while employing sparse environments, looks absolutely stunning and makes use of an excellent in game weather system that really cranks up the excitement levels when storms approach (which are often brutal experiences to ride out).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=524705382
Mad Max is officially my sleeper hit of 2015. Seriously, and in all honesty, I was not expecting much from it but I was pleasantly surprised by the game at most turns. Criticisms aside you could honestly do a lot worse with that hard earned cash of yours and for pure unadulterated fun - it doesn't get more insane or trippy than Mad Max. While it may not necessarily have the full mighty roar of a must have AAA title you would be silly to pass this one up.

If you enjoyed reading this review please follow my curator group at:-
Curator Rater

reviewText:
A bit of Far Cry mapping, big world, Batman fist fighting mechanism with a raw street fighting feel that makes you want to fight more and more, oddly the same kind of feel of Assasin's Creed Black Flag when you're driving your car in this endless waste , instead of a boat and lots of water in Black Flag, and take care of enemy vehicles (including storms but we have sandstorms here), collecting this and that along the way (reminded me of Just Cause), the way they made driving and racing a whole lot of fun in this kind of game (hello Rage!) , upgrading your character and car by doing things...and there are a lot of things to do in this world.....you would almost forget the story. And that's also very good so far. Voice acting is top and the whole scenery and atmosphere is great. It's Mad Max. And you can be Mad Max.

So let me make this clear. It's not a shooter. There are guns and you can shoot them but the focus is not at shooting. The driving and fist fighting takes the most of it. And what a pleasure that is!

They took a long look at some very good games out there and mold it together to make Mad Max look great. They succeeded. Great game, lots of fun.

Yep, after 5 hours of gameplay I can see where this is going. Another lots of sleepless nights.

After 45 hours of gameplay: Yep, it's a very good and addictive game. I saw some reviews with a bit of complaining 'bout that it gets the same after a while. Taking a break now and then will help. After an 8 hours work shift everyone wants to go home and do something else. But after a view hours of 'doing something else' it's great to step in Mad Max's shoes again. They get comfortable the more you wear it.

After 80 hours of gameplay: Woh, time is getting abstract playing this game. That's always a good sign when you're having fun. There are some very good missions here. Got the heart pounding and the adreneline rushing. Almost have completed the map but still not sure how much more I get and I realy don't wanna know. As far as I'm concerned this game can go on and on and on. I got 73% of the achievements so the end must be near. My advise is to don't rush the missions and first clear out the regions one by one and do the missions when they are in the regions you cleared out. And take your time and enjoy searching for all the goodies! It'll be over too soon. Very good game this is.

reviewText:
Something is happening here.  A lot of review sites, you know, the ultra progressive authoritarian ones who think that gamers are dead, gamers are over, and gamers don't have to be your audience; are telling people that this game isn't worth playing.

Are they all upset that gamers have finally woken up to their lies, attempts to control a narrative, and utter contempt for us?  Are they now telling us that games that are fun and worth playing aren't fun or worth playing?

I am having fun with this game.  There's a lot of mechanics at work here, I enjoy how the car is something central to you that becomes more powerful as you progress.  The combat is a bit simplistic, the shooting controls will throw you off (until you realize that shooting is more of a 'power attack' than a standard attack),  but the world is gorgeous, the gameplay is compelling, there are lots of things to collect without it feeling like overload (I'm looking at you Assassin's Creed 4 and Dragon Age Inquisition).

The questions to answer are:

Do you like games in the vein of Just Cause 2? (same production team)

Do you enjoy a post apocalyptic setting?

Do you enjoy an action game with RPG elements?

Do you remember that playing games is supposed to be fun?

Count up your yes" answers and if they're 50% or more yes
date: then that's your answer on whether or not to get this game.\n\nTrust the gamers

reviewText:
Mad Max is an intriguing game to review, and a tough one to succinctly assess. It captures the atmosphere of its source material very well, presenting an open world of majestic dunes and industrial wreckage, replete with anarchy, chaos and quasi-spiritual linguistic quirks. Avalanche toss players right into this turbulent land, and the game thrives in the moments where Max is jostling with War Boy raiders on the open road or tossing ignited cans of gasoline into their scrappy fortresses. But it’s also a title which seems, at some point, to have gone through significant changes (perhaps related to its delay in 2014), and some of the hastier joins around the story pacing, resource systems and progression mechanics still remain.

Befitting of a Mad Max game, the vast majority of the plot concerns Max’s tireless quest for a V8 engine. He’s forced to build a new car (with the help of the irrepressible sidekick/acolyte Chumbucket), after his famous Interceptor is stolen by a roid-abusing chap with the very Mad Max name of Scabrous Scrotus. Though this encounter leaves him bruised and bereft of car, clothes and equipment, Max does at least leave a chainsaw blade in Scrotus’ forehead for good measure. In order to piece together a vehicle worthy of Chumbucket’s ‘Magnum Opus’ moniker, Max needs to roam the dusty wastelands, scavenging scrap, trading favours with local warlords, and ramming or punching every War Boy, Buzzard or general road filth who tries to get in his way.

Pretty much everything in Mad Max is upgraded through the scrap resource (including, somewhat bizarrely, Max’s combat skills), so any of the open world activities that reward scrap are potentially worth doing. Luckily, that’s basically all of them; so unless you have a worrying compulsion to clear the entire map of icons it’s possible to almost exclusively stick to the things you enjoy. A few of the story missions will force you into owning certain upgrades or tackling specific side-areas, but this is kept in moderation.

Avalanche’s art team have done just as tremendous a job as their technical division (the game runs incredibly well even on minimum-spec PCs), creating a dozen or so desert zones that actually look distinct from one another. Red, Mojave-like scrublands border rolling dunes, which in turn become rockier, mesa-filled landscapes, or areas pocketed by vents of near-luminous sulfur. For an area of land that’s ostensibly barren, it offers a palette of bold colours and striking, post-civilisation landmarks.

Roaring through these realms in pursuit of a convoy, harpoon primed to pull wheels off escorts, War Boy boarders tumbling in your wake, and a well-aimed shotgun blast turning another wheeled foe into a spinning, combusting ball of debris, is one of Mad Max’s most exhilarating diversions. The versatile Shadow of Mordor-esque photo mode isn’t just in the game for moody shots of the desert, it’s also for snapping some of the magnificent explosions in full bloom.

The various camps, hide-aways, and ramshackle dwellings scattered across the wastes do eventually end up seeming over-familiar. For a decent while though, it’s a delight to roll up on a new location, comb it for scrap, engage in some un-gentlemanly BatMax fisticuffs with the locals, and explore whether there are any unique, handcrafted little dioramas contained with. Such encounters are only enhanced by the random events of Max’s world. You may end up having to deal with a honking patrol showing up while you’re on foot and vulnerable, or a powerful dust storm bellowing its way across the dry earth.

Of such things are the finest of Mad Max’s moments made. There are some shonkier aspects though, which aren’t gigantic problems in themselves but are amplified by being repeated across hours upon hours of playing. Max has a bit of a case of ‘Geralt movement’, where the weight of his animation will often carry him beyond the ladder, box of scrap, or weapon you’re trying to line him up with. A great many things in this game demand that you stand somewhat perfectly in front of them and hold down E (or equivalent) for a bit, so that gets rather old.

It’s also extremely aggravating to have to watch an almost-cut-scene every single time Max tips gasoline into something or refills his water canteen (effectively your back-up health potion, and probably preferable to the other options of consuming maggots and dog food). This is borderline crazy, because I’m pretty sure it all still happens in-engine. Having the game cut to black after those actions makes very little sense. If modding is ever possible, the removal of these repeat irritations must be a priority.

Though it doesn’t directly detract from a lot of the fun, Mad Max shows various signs of features being hastily changed or wrapped up before they were quite ready. The game’s opening tries to impress the importance of fuel and water for survival, when in fact those resources are now found in abundance across the wasteland (I never ran out of fuel, and having an empty canteen has no additional penalty).

Every ‘Top Dog’ mini-boss looks basically the same, attacks in the same manner (a couple do have assistance from underlings), and may even use the same voice actor. Encounters in the wasteland offer ‘intel’ on these fights, vaguely hinting at a sort of Mordor Nemesis system of particular weaknesses, but it’s obvious stuff like ‘he doesn’t like being shivved in the neck!’ The same tactics which work on all of them. Clearing minefields seems like a hold-over from a time where Max was intended to regularly use a wider selection of vehicles than the Magnum Opus. You can still collect a full set of cars, but outside of races or a sneaky plan to drop mines in front of a convoy, only the mine-clearing buggy (and attendant dog) has such a specific purpose.

Unfortunately, some of the Magnum Opus upgrades are tied to the reduction of ‘threat’ in different regions, and that can mean having to take time off from your campaign of chaos to settle into some familiar busywork. Getting the top level harpoon (the only one which can reliably yank down the most hardy ‘scarecrow’ structures dotted around the land, and one of the most hilarious weapons overall), means sniffing out a whole lot of minefields.

Some of the unlocking methodology may irritate, but the way upgrades for the Opus are handled is quite novel. Later armor and ramming options are not automatically the best way to go; they’re heavy, and become a trade-off with speed and handling. In this sense, you do actually have to design a workable car to some extent. It’s refreshing that the ‘last’ upgrade in a chain isn’t automatically superior by default, but is instead a new variable to consider.

Mad Max has its fair share of quirks and odd design decisions, but creates a sandbox of anarchic chaos that’s both wonderfully rendered and, on PC, a technical marvel. A word on the sound design too, which is just as responsible as the art design and animation for capturing the whump of explosions and jaw-breaking punches alike. There’s much to revel in. But although it’s appropriate that a game from this universe should feel like some aspects are misshapen or hastily bodged into shape to fit a grander vision, the annoyances really peel away at you over the course of a title as long as this one. Like the original 1979 film, Mad Max seems destined to be a cult classic; beloved by many, in spite of the components that appear to have been ripped out and reassembled, or otherwise abandoned to the desert basin.

reviewText:
Story is you are Max, left stranded for dead, vehicle taken and dismantled to scraps, and left with nothing but your clothes.
Now full of vengeance and teamed up with your hunchback sidekick Chumbucket, it is now your destiny to rebuild a better machine called the Magnum Opus, something that the wasteland will tremble in fear from decades to come.

That is basically it as you will have to travel the wastelands going into uncharted territory to build and upgrade your new vehicle from scrap all the way to making the Scrotus clan eat your deadly wheels as you will have to fight to survive by gathering food and water, taking over enemy clans camps, and racing your way to collect scrap as you upgrade.
The vehicle has much to offer as you upgrade everything from wheels with better traction, harpoons to destroy enemy vehicles, paint job, armor, and all the works.

You can also upgrade Max as well from his looks to his uniform to upgrade in combat as well, combat system kind of reminds me of Batman, only with shotguns and plenty of satisfying German Suplex's to even make Brock Lesnar jealous.
Other form of combat comes from your vehicle as you the other half of the time you will come across gang of other vehicles looking to demolish, this all comes in handy as you can use your shotgun to shoot the enemy fuel tank in on kill or be strategic and use your harpoon to take off portions of the vehicle or lasso the driver out and flip him to oblivion.

Now this may not be a popular opinion and I do apologize but to me, the racing and the driving controls in general were just way too stiff and clunky for me, I know you can upgrade for better traction but even half way through the upgrades my vehicle still felt like it was swimming through Crisco. Also, good luck with racing in the game, if you even as much get hit and swerve into the rocks while driving, you might as well restart the race because it takes forever to catch up to your enemy drivers while avoiding hazards to make sure your vehicle does not spontaneously combust while skating through the crisco wasteland. That may not happen to others, I don't know but that is my opinion.

The other little minor issue I have is the weak ending. Throughout the game you will also have your share of boss battles which they all fight in the same pattern pretty much, either dodge out of the way to avoid their powerful attack or click the mouse to counter their attacks and lay into them with a series of punches and kicks as you will also go into fury mode which turns you into a ninja and you become a buffed up one man wrecking crew..but yeah the bosses were kind of weak, especially the ending boss, oh god the ending boss, which made the ending feel anti climatic..
I mean here is the build up for the Lord of the wasteland called Scrotus, built up to make him look like a complete bad a**, and what do they do? Oh let's just put him into a car playing scaredy cat as we toss like 3-4 harpoons at him..and thats it..thats the last boss. Also the ending story just came out of nowhere as I felt like it was rushed, once again, maybe it was just me but they could have done something more to it.

Other than that, graphics are great, I love traveling through the desolate wasteland to the creepy tunnels.
Music and everything else is pretty good.

So on this game it is kind of in the middle for me, but I do recommend it, just let the price go down a bit and then see what you guys will think. It is a good game with a decent length of 15-25 hours of gameplay depending on how many missions you go on.
So yeah, a little repetitive but still something worth checking out.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a third person, action game set in an open world environment, based on the Mad Max film series. It was released on September 1st 2015 on PC, PS4 and Xbox One. The game is set in a post-apocalyptic setting, much like Fallout New Vegas, we have plenty of deserts, canyons, wreckage and tunnels to explore.  You play the character, Max Rocktanksky on the story to regain your lost car, and along the way you will build your own car, The Magnum Opus.

Game play within Mad Max is very heavily focused around vehicular style. Half the game is based inside of your car and you are having to deal with other enemies in their cars as well as on foot. You can use a series of different techniques, whether it be simply ramming the opponents, using your shotgun to blow tires out, or your harpoon weapon to take down the threats.  The other half of the game is done in a commonly seen third person action style - this is extremely similar to the style of combat on show in the Batman Arkham series of games. The hand to hand combat is simply brilliantly put together and you can pull of some amazing combos, blocks and parries, and it all looks so fluently done.

I played this game on 4k resolution, so of course the game looks good, but seriously, this is the best looking game on PC I have seen. It just looks gorgeous, every single one of the textures is high resolution, the animations are perfect, some amazing screenshots can be taken. One would probably expect that when on 4k, but it still looks amazing when playing on the lower resolutions, I'm not even going to say 1080 is low, it looks gorgeous even on that.  It's easy to see why they pulled production on this game being released on the PS3 and Xbox360, I would think even the current gen consoles would struggle with this.

The story in Mad Max is a stand alone and is in no way related to any of the films. As someone who has only seen the recent Mad Max film, I didn't have much nostalgia going into this game, but I can honestly say that I was drawn into the plot from the get go. I got attached to the characters straight away, Chumbucket (your cars mechanic) becomes your friend as you progress through the game and quickly turns into a friendly companion. There are some scenes which really take your breathe away as they are very unpredictable and some of which had shouting out in sheer horror as to what was happening, that is just how invested I got into this game's plot.

This game is not exactly a difficult game to play. The Arkham style combat mechanism is very easy to pick up and pretty much master and the art of vehicle combat can very easily be learnt after a few trial runs. The boss fights in the game can be pretty challenging, as they should be, and you will probably have to redo a few of them until you nail down the perfect fight. You will more than likely die more from accidentally blowing your self up, driving down a cavern which has no bottom, or something silly which you weren't really meaning to happen. As with most open world games like this, you can really make your character way too overpowered for the stage in the story you are on with upgrades and stat increases, so if you too much, you can soon make the game have no challenging aspect at all.

The open world side of this game is truly awesome. I have never seen a map so full of things to do, areas to explore, items to find, hidden objects to locate, side quests, everything. There is literally never a minute in this game where I was bored. If you don't feel like doing a story mission, go for a drive into the dessert and kill some bad guys for more scrap to upgrade your car. Want to go do some exploration? Go digging in an under ground cave for that hidden object to tick off the list. There is literally something every 30 seconds of traveling in game to see or do. Some open world games feel like they are as vast as an ocean, but as deep as a puddle. Mad Max completely blows that theory out of the water. Not to mention the world is absolutely huge, there is so much depth to whats in it, you will never struggle to find something to do.

On the topic of side quests, another nice little mechanic which I really loved in this game, was the ability to upgrade towns and strongholds which you venture into, by completing Projects"

reviewText:
I am very much enjoying this game so far!
I've never seen a Mad Max movie. But I don't think that would matter. The game exists as a standalone entity.
The game world is huge. As one would expect from Avalanche after Just Cause 2.

You have basically full freedom to explore the world, and complete challenges at your own pace, while the story will still guide you along.
Much of the game consists of driving to various scavange points, and hunting for all the Scraps, and defeating all the enemies at each location.
Combat is fairly similar to the Batman Arkham games.

Yes, it can sound pretty repetitive, and it may be. But the characters are interesting, and the world is vast and full of things to explore and discover. Upgrading your car, unlocking new abilities.
It's a very satisfying experience.

If you're looking for something to play while waiting for Fallout 4 and/or Just Cause 3, this is the perfect game for you.

reviewText:
Avalanche are to be praised for distilling everything a Mad Max game should be into an incredible whole. It's got fantastic atmosphere, controls, graphics and sound design. Very loving and true to the source material, it demonstrates why Mad Max has really just been a videogame waiting to happen.

Also, for the PC version specifically - this is how you do games on release day folks. Silky smooth and gorgeous graphics, not even a stutter. The opposite of Batman: Arkham Knight.

I utterly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Why couldn't Arkham Knight have been this good?
Grand Max Auto: The Arkham Wastelander


The Good~

+ The rich and engaging story of Mad Max~

+ 18 hours in, at the time of this writing, and I've only just barely upgraded the first of five strongholds and explored about a fifth of the map. (This is a plus because it means at least 100+ hours of  game play.)

+The driving feels solid, and the collisions are very satisfying.

+ The combat is very similar to the Batman Arkham series, with powerful combos and counters, taking on 5 - 10 people at once.

+ The game map is massive. I couldn't tell you how many miles it is, but at full speed in a car with nitro it takes about six minutes to go from Jeets (East) to Pinky's (West.) And it's a relatively short distance on the map.

+ DOZENS of upgrades for Max himself, and the Magnum Opus (your car.)

+ Your actions feel like they influence the world, and have weight on it's people and economy.

+ The lack of guns has no impact on the game. Even with a single home-made shot gun the game is always fast past and action packed.

+ Awesome graphics

+ Awesome voice acting

+ You get a bomb sniffing dog!

The Bad~

- Exploration is limited to scalable area's marked with yellow paint. You can't climb just any ledge or rock. Due to there being so many of these areas, however, the game does not feel linear at all.

- The Sniper Rifle Mod for the car is more of a tool than an actual weapon. Yes, it kills people, but you can only use it from the Magnum Opus. You'll end up just using it for reconnoiter and safely taking out key defenses.

- With any massive open world game there is a bit of repetitiveness. Collecting scrap can become tedious in the beginning, but eventually people will help you when you build up the strongholds.

- Chumbucket can get a little annoying. But that's not really a bad thing on the game's part. Just my preference for his character.

- I've found a few bugs. But not many.

Sometimes the map won't open and you have to exit the game to reset it.
Stomping out rats and lizards for food can sometimes launch you into the air, which will result in you dying upon hitting the ground.
The pause menu can get stuck on a bio entry, even if you've read it. But it's easy to just click out to where you need to go.
The game doesn't like it when the car rolls........ .... ..... ..
All in all, the game is awesome. Pick it up if you can. You won't be disappointed.

~Love and Peace

Ok so after finishing the game and spending some serious quality time exploring the world it's time for my review on Mad Max cause it really deserves one!No spoilers ahead and  don't worry i won't be making it long! :)

I bet you've all heard about Max,an iconic character,who during the world's oblivion has no one to trust,but his car and seeks redemption!Game starts with you losing everything but your life and starting from zero to collect scrap and build up a car-beast,your Magnum opus to aid your journey and mostly protect you from the various dangers!The wasteland is just vast,oh i mean it!You'll spend half of your time driving from one point to another,collecting resources,flying hot air balloons and liberating camps!

Another part that might really concern you is the story!Well the game starts quite slow but it's really interesting moving on and i like that in order to progress through story you have sometimes do side quests and scavanging in order to upgrade Max and Magnum Opus.The story itself is pretty descent BUT the only disadvantage of it for me is the ending!Yes it's kind overdramatic and not quite rewarding as you'd expect!it's just a sad mind♥♥♥♥!Overal pretty descent though!
Last but not least the sounds are amazing so detailed as well as the atmosphere!Find youself lost into the deadly sandstorms hunted by Scrotu's boy!And the game engine is phenomenal!So well optimised since Day 1!!!It's simial to the one Shadow of Mordor uses and offers some amaaazing views while it's really gpu-cpu friendly!

reviewText:
I've been a Mad Max fan since long before the days of Fury Road, and no one was more afraid of this game than I was. The pre-release gameplay videos didn't impress me. They didn't look like the movies. I wanted to play the movies!

I'm proud to say that this game is a genuine Mad Max experience. I played Mad Max as if it was one of the movies, and it was ♥♥♥♥ing great.

The obvious highlight is the car combat. It's the greatest. There's a mini road war around every corner, and they make for the best screenshots. This game has a photo mode. It kicks ♥♥♥. Look at my screenshot library. Come on, do it.

The on-foot combat uses the Arkham system, but you can't win by closing your eyes and mashing left-click. I've tried it in Arkham and Mad Max. It didn't work this time. This pleases me. Somehow, large volumes of enemies actually can become overwhelming, at least until you've upgraded your melee skill.

You can make your own Magnum Opus! Your own car! You can deck it out with spikes, rams, hood ornaments, and pretty colors. There's also several sets of pre-made vehicles, called Archangels." They suck. You'll hate them too. They ought to leave them out of the sequel (a sequel? Yea
recommended: this next bit split the critics from the average gamer-- the wasteland is loaded with an endless amount of activities to enjoy. I love this. Too often will I play a sandbox game and grow bored when I discover there's absolutely nothing to do but shoot at cops (Grand Theft something or other). Mad Max gave me enough distractions to have fun for at least 50 hours.\n\nOh

reviewText:
What we've got here is an open world game made by Avalanche Studios, the people who developed Just Cause 2. They've focused their attentions to the escapades of the iconic Max Rockatansky, but they haven't done the best job at it because this is a frustrating, inconsistent game that never reaches its full potential and relies on a familiar bag of tricks to get the job done.

How do I sum the whole thing up? Well  Imagine someone taking elements from Far Cry 3, Assassin's Creed Blackflag, Batman Arkham Knight, Watch Dogs or just any open world game, throwing a bunch of those elements into a blender and slopping the result into a neat little package.

Overall there IS a good game here, you just need to invest in a lot of grinding to find it.

reviewText:
You are Max. A wasteland-grifter hybrid of Tom Hardy and Mel Gibson who can be upgraded to look like a member of the Duck Dynasty cast. You are on a mission to do righteous work.

Accompying you on your journey is a Igor-like wrench jockey with some sort of weird fetish problem. This man will follow you along on your missions by riding in the back of your car and assisting you with repairs.

This will come in handy because at every turn there are cars with floating health bars that will not go away and are determined to ruin the incredibly immersive [buzzword] environment. Speaking of the environment it at times is one of the best you've ever seen and at other times is something you'll think looks like it should have released 5 years ago.

As you progress in your Farcry/Shadow of Mordor inspired quest you will unlock new abilities for your car which drives like it's on rails and your character who fights like a bar brawling version of Batman. Press A to attack, press Y to dodge. Originality doesn't end with Max's combat however, oh no no, there are tons more original and immersive [buzzword] features. Such as; all ladders in the entire world being the same color, repeated NPC dialogue, button mashing, mini cutscenes for the most mundane of moments like getting water or pulling out pliers to disarm a mine. I could go on but I don't want to spoil to many of these innovative new concepts.

The desert is what really pulls all of this together. The game sports possibly the best looking sky and cloud effects ever and they can look stunning against the open desert with it's jutting rocks and the reddish-orange sun rising behind. They are so good that they are almost not totally ruined by the non-removable or resizable HUD and constant objective reminders.

Car combat can be fun and some of the weaponry is cool. Dragging an enemy behind you while you drive away is awesome especially since the enemy stays highlighted with bright white the entire time completely removing any confusion that the model is supposed to maybe represent a human being.

You will level up by clearing enemy settlements and other lived in locations that are within walking distance of each other but seemingly unaware of each other. That type of overcrowded and oblivoious atmosphere really sells the authenticity.


You will go mad as you slowly realize the unfulfilled potential of this game. As another glorious moment is ruined by a bad camera angle or text blasting across your screen. As you go to take a screenshot with capture mode and realize the stupid health bars appear over the vehicles still. As you listen to another line of canned corn dialogue and watch another cinematic knock out that you've seen 1,000 times playing Batman. As you listen to the score which sounds like it may possibly be comprised of tracks that were cut from other games. As you drive around aimlessly while listening to your Igor Look-a-like companion creepily sexualize your vehicle as he begs you to work on it.

As you drive into the sand you see hope, a man with a bandana, a dog and a cyborg arm approaches. But alas he is only an apparition, an illusion of heatstroke..... you really spent your money on this instead.

reviewText:
There once was a guy named Max,
Who didn't know how to relax,
Some guys stole his car,
but they didn't get far
before he cut off and flossed with their sacks.

Max is not a happy guy. His car gets stolen, and a lot of people want to kill him, his only friend being a crazy mechanic who is basically Smeagol high on Petrol fumes. Walking around a desert with sand in your boots all day would make anyone mad.

This sets Max on a quest to build the perfect car, the Magnum Opus, which draws a lot of comparisons with how the game plays. Like the Opus, the game itself is incredibly well optimised; it runs smoothly, at a very high frame rate, and has clearly been crafted with a lot of care and attention. The downside to this is that I feel like they could have used those spare resources to do more with the game engine, to make the game look better than it currently does - it's not ugly, but there is definitely room for an upgraded Definitive Edition" later down the road. AA does a mediocre job of eliminating jaggies and it would be nice to have an MSAA option

reviewText:
I ate Dinki-Di dog food from an open can lying on the ground.  I ate maggots from a corpse.  I stomped on an iguana and ate it.  AND IT WAS GOOD.

Based more off of the recent reboot than the original films, this world will still be familiar enough to older fans even if you haven't seen the new movie.  Max is still Max - the reluctant, passive-agressive antihero who can't even remember why he keeps going day after day.  He simply goes as he always has, because no matter how much he wants to stop he just doesn't know how even if the world would let him.

It will be more fun for fans of open-world scavenging and OCD completionists than those who want an amazing plot.  And that's why you should buy it on sale, because $60 is too much.  it's a good game that oozes atmosphere and has some interesting characters.  But the story is barely there.  Not something to complain about in, say, a $30 game.

reviewText:
Great game. Fun and has a lot of mission s in an open world.
I'm not gonna dwell on the story cause it's just there to be there and to give you a purpose. Nothing special to it

The gameplay is where this game shines, you have a car with a massive list of parts that you can upgrade you have three main aspects to it: Speed, handling and strength. You can either have a car that is good at all of them or a car that is great at two and weak at the other. the customization is also complex and fun, it's not just you trying to max out every category, you also have to keep in mind the down side to every upgrade.

Upgrading Max himself is also just as fun. Learning new combat moves never felt like I'm wasting scrap (the currency in the game). Each move felt unique and useful from reversals to wall slamming to limb breaking. The game is also VERY violent and gory which makes it even better for me. You'll face different types of enemies that will require you to use most of you moves along the game.

The open worlds of this game is one of the best I've ever seen in any video game. All the roads connect to each other and it's extremely nonrestrictive which is a huge plus. Each area has a big balloon where you can spot landmarks and Threats" that you need to lower in order to unlock new upgrades for you and your car

The graphics in this are superb

reviewText:
Prepare thine buttox, ye who enter this realm of criticism.
I'm not trying to be a prick here, I just want to be honest about what I actually think and experienced.


While this game has cool GRAYFIX and all that, gameplay is lacking pretty hard.

Here's the generally good stuff;

*Very nice visuals, as I mentioned.
*Even though the world is mostly sand and rock, each territory has nice variety and cool locations to check out.
*Melee combat has a lot of fun moves and contextual things like slamming heads into walls or pushing people over rails to their doom.
*Vehicle combat is satisfying and visceral.
*Story is fairly good, not much to complain about here, except the ending is a bit anticlimactic in my opinion.
*Characters are interesting and memorable.
*Voice acting is superb.
*Low usage of invisible walls, instead uses level design and deadly storms to create boundries, that's a plus in my book.

And here's the rest;

*Poorly balanced, very easy to get very overpowered.
You can reach close to Max (ohoho) level before you leave even the first territory of the game, obviously designed towards being rushed through, which is a bit sad.
*Supplies are extremely abundant, fuel, water, food, ammo, whatever.
Never once did I run out of anything other than water, which I promptly refilled moments later.
Skill upgrades are detrimental to the game, making supplies 'even' more abundant, giving you a ton of health turning you into a tank (combine with good armor and you'll be unstoppable), making combat even easier, etc.
*The only thing that ever got me killed was me being silly where I fell off cliffs or such, oops.

*Melee combat is pizz-easy(yay censorship), even if you use no combat upgrades.
Melee combat also had potential to be a bit more interesting, but for no actual reason everyone fights with their fists, nobody except you has a gun (not counting snipers), and melee weapons are fairly useless and magically break after a handful of hits.
You also can't store melee weapons, not even in your car.
*Vehicle combat is pretty fun and provides some challenge, only real complaint here would be that you'll never ever leave the main vehicle to drive any of the other tons of vehicles available, because you can't bring cumbucket with you on anything else.
*Vehicles handle poorly with keyboard controls, so get a controller if you wanna have more fun driving.
Additonally, vehicle physics are a bit strange, with vehicles uprighting themselves constantly and being near impossible to flip.
*Some vehicle upgrades are a bit silly, for example Armour upgrades where you stick a few guard rails on the side of your car and suddenly it weighs enough to warrant a military tank licence.
You also can't even unlock and purchase the V8 stuff until there's like, 5-10% left of the game to play.

*Gameplay is very (VERY) repetative, all bosses (yes literally all) are copy-pasted with different colours and voice lines.
That is a huge point deduction in my little book.
*Side missions are fun for the first few times, until you realize they're all copy-pasted as well, sadly.
*Sub-par freedom of movement, unbefitting a modern game with a modern engine,
you can only climb specially marked areas, nothing else, not even a belly-high fence.
It feels very primitive and unorganic, especially for a modern 3rd person game.

*Racing is, as you probably would guess by now, pizz-easy.
You either outrace every other driver within 20 seconds or shoot out all their tires within 10 seconds ( ͠° ͟ʖ ͡°)
I can't write much else about it since it nullifies its own existance so quickly.

*Exploring can be fun for eyecandy alone, but don't expect to be rewarded with anything substansial, only generic supplies, and Project Parts here and there, but..
Projects makes the game, once again, even easier, giving you infinite fuel, ammo, water, health refills, etc.

But hey

recommended: as I assumed it actually had purpose

but yeah..

Supposedly

reviewText:
Mad MaxNote: Each field is weighted differently, and thus affects the overall score differently.
Field  Rating  Review    Graphics  8  A strangely beautiful wasteland to explore, with some extremely satisfying explosions. The storms you encounter in the wasteland are something to behold, especially as they come rolling towards you in the distance. The textures could stand to be a higher resolution, and occasionally glare out at you. But for the more part, Mad Max has done a great job crafting a desert that you're actually interested in exploring. Also of worthy note is the audio. Voice acting is well done, though Max himself can sound kind of strange at times. Sound Effects are fantastic and satisfying. Guns sound like they're actually powerful, explosions are wonderful to behold, and sandstorms are ridiculously intense. The combat animations in the game are also quite well done.    Gameplay  8  If you have played Shadow of Mordor, that's a great game to compare Mad Max to, gameplay wise. You spend the majority of your time exploring locations for scrap, destroying enemy camps, and competing in the occasional race. Combat is a simple combination of buttons to punch, execute, block, dodge, and shoot. Even after several hours of combat, I've found it still very enjoyable to smash some War Boy's faces in. There is no stealth in this game, and the variety of weapons is mediocre (shotgun, thunderpoon, harpoon, occasional melee weapons on the ground which all function the same way, and your fists). Driving your car is at the heart of this game, and Mad Max knows this. It can take a little bit to get used to driving your car, and sometimes you'll find yourself wondering why it spun out the way it did, but for the more part it is an entertaining ride through the wasteland. Car Combat is also very well done, with satisfying impacts as you smash into other vehicles, and a few options on how to take them down (shoot out the tires, pull the driver out with a harpoon, dismantle the car with a harpoon, etc). Of note is the upgrade system for your car. Max's upgrade system feels almost pointless, as it simply serves to make him stronger. However, your car is where the upgrades shine, with each upgrade offering different advantages/disadvantages. There is plenty of customization on the car to fit your style.     Story  6  I am not yet done with the storyline, but thus far it has been relatively engrossing. I won't say to much as to spoil anything, but Mad Max does do a decent job of keeping you curious what will happen next. The story does take many hours to complete, so there is plenty of content there.    Multiplayer  N/A  This game is single-player only.    Replayability  6  This is a toss up. While a very enjoyable game to hop into and beat folks up/destroy some cars, I don't see Mad Max as a game that one would come back to over and over. This is simply because of the fact that anything other than the main quest in the game can become somewhat repetitive. Mad Max's redeeming factor in this field is how satisfying the combat is, both on foot and in the car.    Overall  7.2/10  While a solid, mostly bug-free, wonderfully optimized game, Mad Max suffers from being a little to repetitive at times. That being said, I would recommend Mad Max to most any gamer, as the gameplay is very well done, and as a whole the game is fun experience. Take the chance to explore a well-crafted wasteland, and some of the best car combat I've seen in a game.
If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:
The Tipster

You are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:  The Tipster

reviewText: From nearly start to finish I enjoyed my time in the Wastelands with Max.  Yes, the missions and tasks were repetitive and, yes, the combat was more of the same from Batman or Shadow of Mordor but the world was immersive enough, attractive enough (in its own wasteland way) and just plain fun enough to keep me returning.\n\nNearly every repetitive" aspect managed to find a way to stay interesting.  Melee combat felt heavy and brutal and slamming a guy's head into a wall or suplexing him never got old for me.  There's a hundred or so locations where you can seek scrap metal or water but they varied from tents to old subway cars to cliffside villages to abandoned restaurants to deep caves.  You're tasked with tearing down giant metal "scarecrows" but
recommended: I enjoyed flying past (or through) them
hoursPlayed: launching a harpoon and collapsing them behind my racing vehicle.  You'll do a LOT of driving but the landscape is wonderfully created as you progress from dried ocean bottom to ravaged desert towns and upland desert to the mountains of waste and scrap surrounding Gastown.\n\nVehicular combat is a special joy and from early on you are armed with a harpoon that can tear off armor
voteText: tires or doors or pull a War Boy out of his car or a sniper out of his tower.  Further car enhancements allow you to attach grinders to your wheels Ben-Hur style or launch explosive spears to quickly end a fight.\n\nThe game certainly isn't perfect.  Boss fights are almost all copies of each other

The plot is nothing special and this game is definitely more about the journey than the destination.  But Mad Max and the Wastelands kept me coming back for more days on end managed to never feel "old"."

reviewText:
Just finished 100% on this game. Your gamepad skills will be tested to the MAX.

Learn to master skills like:

Pressing the A button for one second
Pressing the A button for two seconds
Rapidly pressing the A button

Once you have mastered the above, you will learn previously unknown advanced techniques like:

Smashing the Y button out of combo fear
Yelling at yourself for accidentally pressing the B button and wasting valuable ammo
Pressing the X button twice as many times as necessary to use repeated boosts

Once you have adequately destroyed the pad of your right thumb, you can sit back and feel satisfied that you have mastered the art of Mad Max combat and collection techniques. All will bow before your 1337ness.


On a more serious note, this is a game that overcomes repetitive tasks with the sheer fun of playing in the environment and enjoying the atmosphere. The story won't blow you away, but the Mad Max universe stories never really did to begin with. Is it a great game? Maybe not. Is it fun? Absolutely.

reviewText:
Madmax is a great atmospheric, immerisve and intense open world action game that has some fun driving gameplays and moments but suffers from some progressive issues in difficulty of gameplay
where some mechanics downright break later on in the game.

Pros + Colorful Dialogue and decent voice acting
+ Really well optimized and blew people away into thinking it was going to be a Mad Disaster like Arkham
+ Immersive world with a day and night cycle, Windstorm, Dust storms, and lightning storms pure chaos and fun
+ Great graphics and backdrop. The post apocalyptic world of when the ocean receedes
+ Plenty of activities placed throughout the map, Blowing up towers, Strongholds takeovers, Random events request from wastelanders.
+ Combat melee system similar to Arkham, easy to play and understandable controls
+ Driving Combat system is fun and intense. Has good assortment of customization and weapons to handle destroying your enemies and objectives.
+ Nice selection of car bodies and max customization
+ Satisfying to see Cars blow up and the physics behind them as doors fly off and parts, Able to aim at thier section to gun them down or
+ The capture option and movie option included lets you make awsome shots and movie moments.
+ Cool guys don't look at explosions moments. Full of explosions everywhere

Cons - The plot and story is weak and non existent and characters are not as memorable except for ChumBucket and Max
- As max level up the game becomes easier and stays easy, Lack of difficulty slider and challenge.
- When fury is leveled up completely it only takes a few combo to activate it, your character will constantly be in fury mode even when you don't want to be in it to execute some of the other finishing moves.
- Enemies never get any different in stronghold nor strongers, Always same group of mobs of warcrier and mobs
- Boss fights uninspiring, All the sequences pays out the same to destroy them, dodge, hit you're done.
-Fast travel to upgraded stronghold can be used anytime and less use of gas makes the scavanging completely useless and not needed. Max level makes collecting gas and this entire aspect of the game completely obselete as you will never have to collect gas anymore.
-  Activities are fun but becomes a bit tedious as it is required to do to unlock car parts and accessories, to even get any unlock you have to do many many of it to advance your vehicle or progress it.

reviewText:
Simple and fun
Games based on movies usually suck. I didn‘t expect much when i first saw the trailer. But the game came out and it‘s pretty good. I love the postapocalyptic setting, i love Mad Max movies, especially the old ones.
This is not a Fallout and it‘s nowhere near it. It‘s a simple, quickly made game. No one expected a good game so maybe that‘s why almost nobody got disappointed by it.

The game begins when you lose your car and you need to get your car back. That‘s the story. Yeah it‘s crap, same as the latest movie. But this game is not about story. It‘s about doing repetitive tasks and it‘s kinda fun no matter how ridiculous it sounds. You drive around gathering scrap which then can be used to upgrade your skills and car. The combat mechanics are simple but fun. It‘s very similar to Batman games, you mash one button and press another one to counter attack. There are guns in the game but you rarely use them. Shotgun can be used to shoot the gas tanks to blow up the cars and also shoot bad people in the face then eat some maggots from a dead person‘s rotten stomach to replenish your lost health.
There‘s also some racing which is quite fun but sometimes can be really frustrating.
Resource gathering is simplified to the maximum. The gas will never end, you rarely will be out of bullets or with no health. You can replenish everything just by going to the base. Or you just find every resource on every step.
Graphics are beautiful in this game. The scenery is amazing. I have never thought that desert could look so beautiful. There‘s a screenshot feature similar to Shadow of Mordor, where you can stop the game and take the screenshot. This should be available in all the games. reviewText:
I usually avoid AAA games like the plague. They often feel sterile, clunky, and have too much emphasis and effort (read: money which translates into final asking price) put into the high-end graphics.

While Mad Max has its fair-share of some of these traits, its darn good and quite addicting. It is a pleasant surprise, honestly. I find myself returning to it again and again.

Essentially, this is a sandbox game where you collect-and-conquer to have bigger and better stats. The upgraded stats are mainly focused on your car and your avatar. The game plays and feels like a movie - and is fairly well done in that regard. You have a companion through most of the game which reduces how lonely the world could feel. It works quite well. There is a lot to do and a lot to look at - and oh boy is it beautiful. It runs so butter, too.

Pros:
+Amazing atmosphere and graphics - and it runs so great. Not a hickup in performance to be found.
+Very addicting, especially in shorter play sessions. Collecting scrap and gaining upgrades that really make you more powerful is so awesome. I even recently built something that collects scrap when I'm not playing. Its going AdVenture Capitalist on me, and I'm loving it.
+The storyline and characters are all well done. The voice acting is top-notch, and they all fit in the atmosphere.
+The companion makes the game feel much more real and alive.
+Lots of random events and gangs are roaming the world, which make it further believable.
+The sandbox is huge. Over 10 hours in and I haven't even visited 60% of the map.
+Tons of vehicles and they all feel different.
+Metric tons of unlockables.
+The difficulty level is fairly easy - which, at least for me, is a breath of fresh air from tough-as-nails indie games that I usually deal with.

Meh:
=Some people report camera problems when fighting - I didn't find this to be the case. I did find the camera is as equally annoying as it is in any 3D AAA game.

Cons:
-Like many AAA games, the core mechanic is very simple. For the most part you only need like two buttons lol. Press 'A' to do most things. This is partly why most find this game best played in short play sessions.
-Missions can get repetitive, which again, is why this game is best played in short play sessions. Its fine, and definately adds near infinite replayability (new missions spawn constantly), but they can start to feel meaningless over larger time.

Overall, this is a great game, that is likely worth the high price tag. You can often get it on discount, which is great. There are a lot of hours to get out of this, particularly if you like large open-world sandbox games where you grind and upgrade.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lEsg-ZUjzrs

The video game world is by no means short on post-apocalyptic wastelands to explore but unless a game comes out based on A Boy and His Dog comes out, none of them can claim to be based on one of the most influential pieces of Post-Apocalyptic media of the past 35 years. In this sense, Avalanche Studios’ Mad Max is an exciting licensed property in the game world and the prospect of playing another post-apocalyptic title, even amidst a market full of them, has only been sweetened by the most recent film in the Mad Max franchise: Fury Road. Given Avalanche’s mastery of creating exciting sandbox gameplay with ample opportunity for organic, play it your way hijinks, Mad Max seems poised to be this year’s Shadows of Mordor style sleeper hit.

Much like the films, Mad Max’s narrative is sparse but unlike the films, the supporting cast lacks the charisma to carry the events forward in a satisfying manner. Beginning with an overlong cutscene depicting Max’s clash with the game’s antagonist Scrotus. Their encounter ends with Scrotus suffering a major wound and Max stripped of his gear and left to wander in the desert. In typical video game fashion it’s up to Max to rebuild his car, re-acquire his gear and end Scrotus’ violent reign over the wasteland.

While its narrative is certainly in the spirit of the films upon which it is based, the weak supporting cast and unfocused objective make for an underwhelming narrative experienced, especially when paired with 40 hours of gameplay. Early on, Max encounters a mechanic named Chumbucket who helps him rebuild his car and suggests the next wasteland leader to ask for assistance. Upon encountering each leader not much interaction occurs between them and Max. Their trust and tolerance is easily gained and there is very little narrative surrounding them. Each leader has a handful of side missions, referred to as wasteland missions in the game, but these amount to petty errands rather than building a plot around each character. The NPCs stand around like props exuding zero personality and failing to reflect the kind of society that each wasteland leader has built. In this sense, Mad Max takes the scenic route to its conclusion, introducing you to various people of interest but doing little to make your encounters with them seem essential to your fight against Scrotus. Amidst the endless diversions in each of the game’s regions, you soon forget why you are there and what your objective is. Aside from Chum’s crazed banter, there is little reason to pay attention.

Upon receiving your bare bones vehicle and enlisting Chum’s assistance, Max’s journey begins proper and a routine is quickly established where players enter a territory, meet its leader, destroy Scrotus’ infrastructure in the area, obtain a vehicle upgrade that permits passage to a new territory and repeat. Mad Max relies on a series of mechanics familiar to those who have played open world games over the past five years. There are enemy strongholds to topple, weather balloons to utilize for reconnaissance and fast travel, loot caches to pillage for upgrade currency, races to partake in and convoys to smash. In addition to these activities there are special parts to be on the lookout for that allow max to upgrade the stronghold of each wasteland leader he encounters. Constructing these upgrades allow Max to replenish his supplies which would otherwise have to be scavenged. The problem is each stronghold requires the same upgrades and by the midway point, hunting down components for each stronghold feels like a chore. Likewise, once the allure of taking out the strongholds that dot each of the game’s regions grows tiresome after the novelty of their sometimes intricate designs ware off. These strongholds are in particular a point of frustration since in many ways they are some of the game’s most interesting set pieces but by being populated with the same handful of gimmicks and gameplay choices they grow dull long before the credits roll. Some of these strongholds are also home to bosses, none of which come close to living up to the eccentric antagonists of the films such as Toecutter, Humongus or Imortan Joe. Instead, expect to fight muscular men in gimp masks wielding polearms ad nauseam.

Further hampering the game’s mechanics is the mind numbingly dull combat lifted from the Arkham series which relies on counters and timed button presses. If you have better dexterity than a three toed sloth with rheumatoid arthritis, expect to yawn your way through the game’s uninspired enemies with barely a scratch. The combat system tries to spice things up with new abilities that Max can learn, melee weapons that break after a short period of time and finishing moves executed with shivs but due to the ubiquity of its design, combat simply doesn’t stand out.

While it may seem that Mad Max is another throw away game based on a licensed property it does manage to redeem itself with engaging vehicular gameplay. Your car, The Magnum Opus, starts as nothing more than an engine on a chassis, but as you explore the wasteland you can locate new car bodies, and lower Scrotus’ influence over each region to unlock more upgrades. At first, taking control of your car is an irritation; it’s slow, handles poorly and tends to spin out easily but after a few upgrades the Magnum Opus becomes a speedy death machine allowing you to terrorize your foes. What’s more interesting is that the upgrades in each category can have a negative impact on other performance categories so having the heaviest bumper may allow you to deal major damage but it’s weight also makes the car slower. You can shove a massive engine in your ride but it’s going to negatively impact the vehicle’s handling. This makes it worthwhile to have all of the upgrades and swap between them when the situation calls for it. The visual and performance enhancing upgrades prove to be the perfect carrot on the stick to motivate players to complete some of the game’s more tedious activities. You can also unlock additional vehicles by driving captured enemy cars back to friendly strongholds or by winning races.

Ultimately, Mad Max’s gameplay falls short by not featuring any gameplay mechanics that give the game a unique identity. Most of the gameplay elements featured in Mad Max can be traced back to half a dozen other games that share the same mechanics—two of which are also published by Warner Brothers. It’s easy to run headlong into a convoy of eight cars, turn them into a scrap heap in less than a minute and reflect back on both Just Cause 2 and Fury Road… Where are the massive war rigs? Why can’t you hop aboard other cars? Shouldn’t taking out a convoy be something more than blowing up a few cars? Your interest in playing mad max will likely only last as long as your enthusiasm for driving around the wasteland in a four wheel drive rat rod leaving a trail of destruction. Mad Max is a case of competency over excellence and it doesn’t help that the open world action adventure game has usurped the third person cover based shooter as the go to game design template. This isn’t the sleeper hit it could have been but it isn’t exactly a game to ignore if you are a fan of Mad Max or open world action games.

reviewText:
It is quite ironic that the critics find the game mediocre while the game gets an overwhelming positive feedback from the gaming community.

If there is one thing that I could say about the game is that it is really pretty. From the setting sun, to the raging sandstorm, to the colorful explosions, the visuals of the game is really well done. You might be expecting that everything is a bland hue of brown and you are mostly correct but they did splash some color in the game and I mean bright colors too. Blues, oranges, violets, are all there. Nothing is quite a giggling inducing as beating the crap out of a bright blue wasteland baddie.

The voice acting in the game is good. They actually got an authentic Australian to voice Max and not the movie type Australian like you're listening to Steve Erwin, you got a proper Australian accent going on.

The game has a huge map and there are tons to do. Destroying camps, scavening scraps, pulling down scarecrows, and more. There is the feeling of being a janitor as you sweep all the icons off the map. It can be tedious if you have been at it for a couple of hours.

Vehicular combat is were the game shines. It is violent, primal, and full of excitement. Your car is a veritable moving arsenal. The Magnum Opus (your car) is highly customizable. If you want a rolling fortress or a speeding bullet, you can configure it to your heart's content.

The game uses the same system as Batman and Shadow of Mordor. You can counter attacks with button prompts and mash the attack button to wade in a fight. If you are used to Avalanche's fighting system, you'll be right at home here. If you are looking for something else, you'll be disappointed. It's good but nothing innovative.

There were some (a lot) of people that were concerned about how well the game is optimized for PC users. Well, I'm glad to say that the game works wonderfully. Being that the game was developed in house rather than outsourcing the porting to another company ensured that the game is properly optimized though I feel that I should not have to talk about that because since when does proper optimization have to be a positive of a game? This should be the norm not an exemption.

With Metal Gear being released on the same day, is Mad Max worth it? I would say yes. I bought it for $30 USD so I think I'm getting my value's worth. If you are a fan of the Mad Max universe then I say play the game.
If you are new to the Australian wasteland, give it a try.

reviewText:
Although there was a bit of hassle with the midnight release. The game is finally out! I haven't spent to much time with the game, but enough to say that this is by far one of my favorite games this year!

Pros:
- Excellent Optimization (I'm getting 100-120fps with everything MAX'd out(pun intended) on a GTX 980Ti)
- Great Graphics
- Fluid & Meaty Combat, the punches Max throws feel so heavy and hard hitting
- Story seems solid from what I've so far experienced
- The open world is PACKED with things to do, you're never 20 seconds without finding some sort of camp or loot stash
- Cars control perfectly
- Extensive Graphics options
- Outstanding Voice-Acting
there is so much more, but I won't spoil anything else!

Cons:
- Anti Aliasing only has an On/Off function, you can't set it to FXAA/SMAA/MSAA, not a huge problem, but would be nice to have that option.
- For some reason the refresh rate option doesn't seem to save sometimes. But it's working for me now.
That's all!

Overall I would give this game a solid 10/10.
It's probably the most optimized AAA PC title to come out so far this year, it has a well written story and enough content to keep you busy for 10's of hours!

reviewText:
In many ways 2015 was the year of Mad Max. We got the excellent film Mad Max Fury Road earlier in the year closer to May, and in September we recieved Mad Max 2015 by Avalanche studios. The devs behind the Just Cause series.

When I first heard about this game I hated the idea of it. I didn't really think in the era of Fallout that we really needed another derivative post apocalyptic open world game. When I heard Mel Gibson wasn't involved at all that really made me less interested in it. Then after Fury Road I relaxed to the idea of more Mad Max. And I was surprised by how much I liked this game and what it set out to accomplish.

In many ways the Mad Max Film series is almost the perfect concept for an open world driving game. You have a post apocalyptic sandbox filled with hostile enemy raiders. You have a core driving experience with car combat and upgrade trees to customize your hot rod. What I was surprised by the most with this game in particular was how much detail was paid attention to. There are numerous little callbacks to the previous films, and the stylistic decisions they made with the game were spot on.

The wasteland of Mad Max was perfectly nailed. Unlike the Fallout games, the world feels very handcrafted. Nothing feels copy-pasted and throwaway locations like enemy outposts all look scenic enough to take a dozen screenshots of. The game also boasts an impressive draw distance and it runs extremely well on PC. The gameplay is solid enough. With car combat being a highlight in the game. There's a very noticeable focus on scavanging. Your car requires gasoline to keep going, you require water inorder to heal yourself. You only ever find individual shells for your gun and can only carry a handful at one time. I really do feel more like a vulture picking at a corpse of a dead world than a super soldier like in most modern sandbox games.

But with all that said, the game isn't for everyone. I feel alone when I say this but the things people dislike about this game, like the heavy focus on sidequests, the general minimalistic storyline and lack of gunplay are things that appealed to me about it. I actually think the laundry list Assassin's Creed formula benefits this game greatly. Your grand objective in this game isn't a pointless revenge story or a pointless revolutionary story. You spend the vast majority of this game looking for ways to upgrade your car. I like how the game focuses on that rather than a more generic storyline and mission structure.

As I said the game isn't for everyone. If you're not a fan of the Mad Max films and you get turned off by a heavy focus on sidequests with a game I'd suggest looking elsewhere. I'd wager less than 10% of Mad Max is actual story content and if that sounds like a bad thing, you will probably find a lot of this game very tedious.
