reviewText:
http://youtu.be/gLTnbhbv1gQ
Game: Mad Max
Genre: Third-person Open World
Developer: Avalanche Studios
Publisher: Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment
Copy supplied by Steam

Mad Max is the new movie-licensed open-world action game developed by Avalanche Studios and published by Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment.

STORYIf you are a fan of the movies, the story will be right up your alley. Mad Max is driving around the wasteland, and one day he his hunted down by the evil Scrotum and his minions and his car his taken. After that he finds Chumbucket, an hunchback that sees him as the saviour who is destined to drive the Magnum Opus against the evil Scrotum. From that point, Max's begins a journey in which he helps different settlements to fight back and get revenge against Scrotum.
The story isn't all that complex, and the characters are mostly one dimensional, however they are all peculiar and wacky, with Chumbucket being one of the best video game sidekicks out there, always giving you advice on what to do.
Similarly to the movies, most of the Wasteland's backstory is told visually: you will see collapsed bridges, dry docks, buried cities. If you are looking for something more complex, you won't find it here.

GRAPHICSFor almost every PC users, this game performs extremly well: Avalanche optimised the engine to make it work at rock solid 60fps, also thanks to the presence of the wasteland. If you are playing the game at the highest or lowest settings, the environment is beautiful. Every enemy camp you explore feels unique, every faction has different vehicles and enemies and there are enough landmarks to make you understand where you are going without always checking the mini-map.
The particle effects are also amazing: the explosions are pure poetry, and the sandstorms manage to make your jaw drop the first time you encounter them. Hardly have I ever played a game about a post-apocalyptic future that looks so good.

GAMEPLAYThere are two types of combat: hand-to-hand and vehicular.
Hand-to-hand combat is pretty similar to the Arkham games, however it feels different: while Batman is more agile and can parry almost every attack, Max is heavier and stronger. While doing an heavy attack, you can't parry whose attacking you. You can also pick up enemy weapons, or use your shotgun for one-hit kills.
Vehicular combat is where the gameplay shines the most: since the game is set in a wasteland, you will hardly ever crush into a rock or a wall. You can use a grappling hook to pull parts of the car, from the wheels to the driver himself, as well as revealing the gas tank to blow it up with a well-aimed shot. Whenever you aim, the game enters slow-motion, making things easier and less frustrating.
The more you play, the more you can customize Max and the Mangum Ops: from new jackets, hairstyles, ammo belts and moves for the former, to new weapons, engines and armor for the latter. If you enjoy customization, there is a lot of it here. You can also use enemy cars to infiltrate camps without alerting anyone, adding a bit of strategy to the game.
However, the open world missions can become repetitive pretty fast: you can destroy scarecrows, capture camps, explore locations for scrap, use air baloons to scout the areas and destory enemy convoys. Sometimes you will have the task to go somewhere and free some prisoners, but other than that there isn't much variety. However, the combat always keeps things interesting, especially when fighting bosses or destorying convoys.

CHALLENGEThe game isn't particularly challenging: the camps feature many checkpoints and water stashes to recover health, and the car fights can be won by just pulling the driver out of the vehicle. Still, some missions are harder than others, and the bosses that you fight require more thinking than button mashing, so it all balances out.

SOUNDYes, Mad Max is voiced by an Australian. And he acts very well. All the other characters are very cartoony, just like in the movies, and Chumbucket's voice actor does a great job at being funny and never annoying. However, the soundtrack is pretty mediocre, especially compared to the one in this year's Fury Road. But the sound effects make up for it: every punch you throw, every explosion you witness pack enough punch to satisfy the violent spirit inside every one of us.

REPLAYABILITYAs with most open world games, you get quite a lot of content here: between completing all the missions and destorying the enemy outposts, there are many objectives that will keep you entertained for most of the game. You can also try your luck by exploring the Great Nothing, a infinitely big desert with ton of scrap to take.

Overall, fans of the movie franchise and open world games will spend a lot of time playing this game thanks to its solid combat, beautiful wasteland and great performance. If you are on the fence, I recommend waiting for a sale.

Story: 7.5
Graphics: 9
Gameplay: 8.5
Challenge: 7.5
Sound: 7.5
Replayability: 8.5

ENJOYMENT: 8.5
FRUSTRATION: 5

reviewText:
First off I would like to say that I am a huge fan of the Mad Max franchise, and when I first heard of this game I was thrilled. I expected a lot from the game after watching it's trailers, and I was not disappointed.


Pros:
Absolutely amazing vehicular combat, completely surpassing my expectations!

Really fun ground combat! As a lot of you probably know the combat is very similar to the Arkham series of games, and that's definitely not a bad thing. You feel like the badass wanderer that Max has always been.

Nice graphics! On max graphics the game looks beautiful, though my computer can't run it at max quality without a significant drop in framerate.

Good voice actors! While some of the characters feel pretty lackluster, the majority of the characters are really brought to life by the actors.

Powerful Story! I know some people might disagree with me here, as this game definitely isn't The Last of Us". However
date: the game does a fantastic job of capturing the old story of Max regaining his humanity in the wasteland.\n\nBig (and beautiful) World! The world is big with plenty to explore
recommended:
as well as tons of enemies to take down.

Cons:

The game can become somewhat repetitive as you grind away at clearing minefields or carrying gas can around trying to blow up every last transfer tank. However the game keeps things interesting with plenty of combat during these events so this isn't that large of a complaint.


Overview:

Really this is just a great game
hoursPlayed: and I highly recommend buying it whether you're a fan of the series or are just looking for a good open-world game."

reviewText:
An open-world adventure game, full of salt, gasoline, blood, crushed metals and souls. Bitterness prevails above all of it. Still, this one is the helluva fun ride, all the way down the road.

You can finish it in 10-20 hours, going straight through quests, but that would be a waste of time, from my point of view.
Like I said, the game has bitter taste, and the story line will not give you satisfaction after final screen. So I beg you: play it like open-world adventure. Don't mind major quests, until you really have to. Just get yourself a decent car, and go for exploring this land. Eroded, crumbled to dust, but still striving for survival.

Some time ago, I was really fond to Far Cry 2, which was baptized as horrid and bleak by the majority of players. But I found in Far Cry 2 one thing, for it can be loved: the driving part. Here in Mad Max, the same feeling of driving through wasteland, where there are no actual roads, only directions, and it goes 10 times better than in Far Cry 2!

Let's settle pro and contra:

+ Graphics and optimization are very good parts. All is smooth and fine with that.

+ Driving is the selling point. It is one of a kind experience, I suggest everyone to get at least some of it.

+ Fighting part is very similar to Batman's games, or Sleeping Dogs - strike and strong strike, parry&reposte, combo... It goes fine, for the most time. Although some moves Max showing are certainly not fit the realistic setting the game's narrative assuming. But the same can be said about the whole game: the realism is here, but steps away to make some emotions brighter. Still, after about 200-300 broken jaws, it is finally not that fun, as with Bats or Wei Shen... The Shadow of Mordor gives much more contentment, than Mad Max, at this point.

+ The gameplay main features certainly looks familiar. Fighting from Batman, scrap collecting and gear tuning from Tomb Raider... you can proceed with the list, but here's the main thing: it was blended alright. Unlike Watch Dogs, Mad Max gameplay is not seems like Frankenstein style. All things there at right places, so the final expression the game gives is pure. You're getting a fresh new game out of long-known features. A good deal.

- The only strong point I have against this game is amusingly overall accolade to Death. All those skulls, achievement for eating maggots nesting in the rotting corpses... All that gore is an over-act, an over-kill and exaggeration of the Apocalypse theme. I felt disgust sometimes during playtime. So I'm certainly not recommending Mad Max to kids or to sensitive persons.

- The game is open-world, but it contains almost none of any sandbox experience. After you clear the given territory from the enemy presence, there are absolutely nothing to do. So you can't play this game by hundreds of hours, like Skyrim. Unless you really like driving in wastelands over all other gaming experience, of course.

In sum: Mad Max is pure and solid action game. Very brutal, and quite entertaining for some time. You ride a death car, right in the middle with the real world and hell. And while your good deeds somehow fixing something around you, your hero goes deeper and deeper on the dark side. Very nice and very grim adventure in the post-apocalypse crack of world we used to know. Give it a go, but leave any hopes before entering.

I mark it as 7.9/10. I like it very much, but it hurts something inside me. Let's just pray we'll never see this dream come true.

reviewText:
Beating people up is incredibly satisfying.
Blowing things up is incredibly satisfying.
Upgrading Max and the car makes a visible difference to both driving and combat.
Pretty much all missions affect the overall game, whatever side mission you choose to do, it will end up helping you in the long run so the incentive to play the entire game is clear and fun.

You can't filter out the icons on the map.
A lot of upgrades are limited to story missions.
Hallways and caves can get confusing and you can easily get lost in the maze.
In combat, enemies attack one by one which makes things relatively easy and they run after you one by one so you can easily spread them out and kill one by one.

Farcry meets Shadow of Mordor meets Batman meets Rage.

8/10 would dodge rocks all day

reviewText:
A perfect example of what optimisation means.  GTX670 running almost maxed out with no frame drops.  Smooth as silk.

I am very early in the game but it looks great and plays great.

Audio mix is spot on and the vehicle exhaust notes are awesome.

I use a controller for the driving and kb and mouse for everything else.  Like everything else in this game you can interchange with zero issues.

I have only one con so far and that is, there is no option in the settings to invert the mouse y axis.  You can invert the y axis for the controller not the mouse.   This is easily fixed by going in to the settings.ini file and manually change the mouse invert y to 1.  It really should be an option in the settings imo.

I can see many hours spent on this game.

A def purchase in sales times, if not now.

reviewText:
The apocalypse made Australia slightly more liveable, none of the wildlife tried to kill me. Traffic is still murder though.


But seriously: highly recommended. I couldn't stop playing this game.

It's a sandbox game with a whole lot of sand, a great atmosphere, visual design taken straight of Fury Road and made by fans of the whole series or at least people who really documented themselves, with lots of details and easter eggs about the three first movies. As a fan of the Mad Max universe myself, I had a blast.

However, just as in a real sandbox, it's mostly up to you to make your own fun. The story is a bit weak, and while there are a ton of locations (over 250 I think), all of them unique, all you do is drive and fight, either in a vehicle or on foot with a Batman Arkham clone system which is very brutal and satisfying and offers quite a bit of different possibilities once you've unlocked skills. You can upgrade your vehicle to make it tougher and meaner, get a few weapons for your car and unlock fighting skills for Max, but the core experience stays the same. If that appeals to you and you like to explore every nook and cranny in a game to find stuff (it's always scrap, but you need it for everything), go right in. If you need to be poked every five minutes by narrative to stay interested, it isn't the game for you.

There a over 16'000 reviews already, so there isn't much I could say that you can't find elsewhere. I'm just going to say watch the trailer"
date: for once it isn't just an empty cinematics showcase filled with buzzwords but it shows you most of the gameplay and really shows you the game and what to expect.\n\nDisclaimer: I am a fan of the Mad Max universe since The Road Warrior
recommended: back in the days where there was no videogames and where it was the only post-apocalyptic experience around
hoursPlayed: so I'm probably biaised.\n\n"

reviewText:
TL;DR - Entertaining enough but doesn't justify its price tag.  Pick it up for $19.99 or less.

Mad Max is a game attempt by Avalanche to leverage the legendary narrative from Kennedy-Miller with the aim of creating an action-packed open-world style game with vehicular combat and Arkham-style fisticuffs.

While the game is entertaining enough - at least for a while - it gradually becomes apparent that Avalanche really don't grasp the reasons behind the design choices of other games and the importance of building complete systems rather than facades.

And this is the essential problem.  Most of the wasteland's life is a simulacrum of reality where the seams are very much showing.  Now some might not regard this as problematic, however I'd argue they're missing the point.

Take, for example, the convoy system.  Now taking down convoys is one of the more thrilling aspects of the game and many consider this a high point.  However standing back and taking a look at it reveals the completely shallow nature of this experience.  The convoys - the narrative tells us over and over again - are an essential component of the primary antagonist's war machine.  They take crude oil to Gastown and return with fuel for the outposts.

The only problem with this is that every single convoy travels in a giant circle making no stops along the way.  The gameplay experience directly contradicts the narrative.  And worse still, the player's reward for taking out a convoy is a shiny hood ornament (which buffs the player's car in an indeterminate fashion) and the reduction of threat" - a completely nebulous concept which supposedly determines the probability of your wasteland travels being disturbed by howling madmen screaming for your blood.  (Basically your convoy efforts affect a multiplier for Avalanche's random number generator.)

This - and this is my primary impression of many aspects of this game - is a lost opportunity.  Gameplay is about choices and in particular
date: it's about allowing the player to make smart
recommended: innovative and creative choices.\n\nThe convoy system COULD have been a network of convoys with real impacts upon the other systems of the game.  Convoy routes could be determined through observation and/or intelligence-gathering.  With that
hoursPlayed: the player would also need an understanding of the risks and rewards of attacking a given convoy.  Convoy A might impact fuel availability for roving war patrols in a specific area - thus reducing their ability to chase you - whereas convoy B might starve a fortress of the fuel necessary for defenses.\n\nAll of a sudden
voteText: you elevate the convoy system from being a purely repetitive experience to one with strategic implications.  You enable the player to plan at a higher level and - more importantly - you make the convoy experience start to matter more in the strategic and narrative context of the game.\n\nThe base system suffers from similar facile gameplay systems.  Perimeter base defenses consist of snipers
helpfulPercent: a wall of fire
votesHelpful: thunderstick launchers and molotov launchers.  Each of these has problems.\n\nA) Snipers DO NOT EXIST until you get within a specific range at which point they pop into being and conveniently shine a blue light allowing you to pinpoint them with minimal effort.  The color of the light changes depending on how close they are to firing upon you.  Now while sniping is a fun activity
votesTotal: this particular system requires minimal skill.  In the entire game
votesFunny:
not once did a sniper ever come close to killing me.  I got hit about 5 times.

B) The wall of fire requires you to hunt for the attached tank and destroy it.  Not very challengine and adds little to the experience.

C) Molotov launchers can be taken out with sniper fire.  Thunderstick launchers cannot.

All of these elements detect the player whenever he moves within a specific radius.  Irrespective of line of sight.  Thus
commentsCount: while bases often have secret entrances
column16: these entrances often require you to disable the perimeter defenses anyway and all you end up doing is bypassing the main gate.  (There are exceptions but these are few and far between).\n\nOnce inside
column17: the player has no option for stealth and pretty much has to plow through the place with his fists while simultaneously searching for completely optional and zero-impact-upon-the-world collectibles.  (One of which is scrap
column18: one is historical oddities and the other is antagonist insignia).  Sure
column19: Max can always use more scrap - it IS the currency of the world
column20: after all - but is he really going to care about insignia or postcards?  Those last two are pointless busy work - and I became thoroughly sick of it.\n\nEssentially
column21: the promise of an open-world environment is undermined by incredibly linear - not to mention repetitious - design.  And while I do have to give the level designers props for inventive use of 3D space - the levels are fairly well constructed - and kudos to whomever came up with the idea for the War Crier
column22: the base clearing mechanic itself is a simplistic version of what it could have been.\n\nThe system for building projects inside strongholds initially seems cool - until you realise it's just a bunch of fetch quests which you repeat four times (once for each stronghold).  The idea is good but
column23: once again
column24: the implementation is facile and the repetition is lazy and unforgivable.\n\nThe minefields - oh dear God
column25: the minefields.  This is absolutely the worst part of the game.  Not only must you hope to stumble across these (literally
column26: there's no other way of finding them)
column27: but then you have to ditch your car for a buggy with zero offensive capability in order to defuse the mines.  Apparently the mine-detecting dog you've stumbled across is unable to detect mines unless he's in a buggy.  Or something.  The rationale for this was never made clear
column28: but it - like all aspects of the minefield clearing - was intolerably stupid and inconceivably boring.\n\nThe scarecrows are more threat-reduction devices
column29: present no challenge and require nothing more from the player than the ability to aim a harpoon in slow motion or crash effectively.  The balloons are good enough
column30: but far too slow and the vague attempts to inject puzzle mechanics (by requiring the player to find fuel or navigate his way to a particular point) are trite and uninspired.\n\nThe wasteland encounters were largely a waste.  The intel encounters at least brought a little more depth to the base destruction system
column31: but not much.  The others were optional and merely required the player to show up and say hello.  Boring
column32: repetitious and unnecessary.\n\nThe long-term encounters (buzzard hole destruction
column33: jumps
column34: catapult destruction and gas valves) were standard open world fare but with a worthless payoff.  Ways to waste the player's time but with zero narrative payoff and an almost insulting player reward.\n\nThe voice-acting runs the gamut from good (Griffa and the stronghold leaders) to mediocre (Max himself) to the downright awful (every other Australian in the game).  In particular the female Australian voice-artist is dire.  She's not helped by the god-awful scripts she's been given
column35: but she has no talent for voice-acting whatsoever and I cringed every time I heard her.  (I'm Australian
column36: so more than familiar with our accent).\n\nSummed up
column37: Mad Max is a game of disparate experiences with elements of fun
column38: but which fails to come together into a coherent and enjoyable whole.  It is primarily a catalogue of lost opportunities with the main issue being a lack of depth.  It's this lack of depth which undermines the open world experience.\n\nGame played to completion
column39: threat reduced to 0 in all areas.   Recommended buy for less than $20.  Ripper DLC has no impact on the game.\n\nScore: 6/10."

reviewText:
I like Mad Max. About 12 hours in I got a solid feel of the overall game.
The important thing to know about Mad Max is that it's fun. And that's the whole point.
It is far from perfect, lacks in many departements but it also has a lot of positives which make it a good enjoyable game.
The over the top action makes you want to play a little bit more all the time.
Completists will have their hands full.
The game focuses a lot on driving and does it well, there are so many upgrades for your vehicles, and so many of them.
The on-foot action is also good, fighting is a little simple (like batman) but its fun nevertheless. I do wish there was more weapons and customizations for them. It is very thin in that department, and you barely find any ammo in the game so you practically never use your shotgun.
The acting is good but the story is week. You don't feel like you're switching gears between the main story and side missions, they both feel the same, so you don't get that change of pace that breaks the monotony of tasks.
The game feels a little sand boxy but that doesn't take away form the fun of playing it.
The worst issue of the game is the character animation and movement. It's horribly done. The jumping in particular is the worst I've seen in any game the last 10 years, super clumsy. And the falling animation feels like you're a floating leaf.
They really needed to work on that departement to make max feel heavier, with the ability to jump and grab etc. All of which aren't there and hurt the gameplay.


The Positives:

-Great Atmosphere overall. Enviroments are spot on and so is music.
-Fun gameplay, fighting, driving and effects are satisfying.
-Tons of upgrades and mods.
-Lots of things to do.
-Pretty good acting.

The Negatives:

-Weekish Story. Even main mission feels like a side mission.
-A Little repetitive at times.
-Abysmal character movement for a current gen game. Jumping in particular is terrible.

Still, you will get a good 60-70hr atmospheric fun and thrilling gameplay out of this game.
I'm enjoying it to the Max :)

reviewText:
I tend to only write reviews if the game pisses me off to no end... Or if the game meets almost every expectation i had.

Mad Max is definitely the latter.

Pros:

Brilliantly made port
Wonderful Performance (I have a little better than a mid tier computer and and able to run the game on the highest settings and havent yet dropped below 45 frames)
Beautiful to look at (this is the only game where the cutscenes do the game no justice)
Driving is fun and feels well developed
Motor sounds (they sound loud af just like in the movies) <3
Enviornment (everything is made with the steam-punk vibe that the game should have. There aren't quest items that look brand new)
Sounds (from the wind to the guns to the engine its great)
Item rarity (food and water, which replenish health faster, are very hard to find. Gas is also a moderately rare commodity

Cons:

The sand storm sound is like earrape and you can't choose to only lower that sound.
No difficulty levels (combat is easy most of the time)
Nitro feels almost useless when you first get it
No stealth (A stealth option would have been fun. I would rather not run head on into 10 guys in a camp)
Accidental cutscene skipping (when a cutscene is triggered the game says press E" to skip... That's a lie... if you click anything at all it skips the cutscene. Because of this I've missed a few cutscenes D:)


Overall the Pros outweigh the cons quite a bit! I would definitely recommend this game :D"

reviewText:
Mad Max is a open world, action, post-apocalyptic, survival type game. Mad Max is a third person, action game set in an open world enviroment, based on the Mad Max film series. It was released on September 1st 2015 on PC, PS4 and XBOX One. You can explore plenty of deserts, canyons, wreckage, tunnels, hills. In the story, Max's car was stolen in wasteland by Scrotus. Then Scrotus beaten and threw him into Chumbucket's region. After few minutes Max wakes up and found Chumbucket. Then Chumbucket helps Max to build a war machine for Wasteland War. After all this, journey begins.

Mad Max featured with massive open world map. We can do several things in Wasteland. Like terminating Snipers, Camps, Stop Dogs, Scarecrows. Even we can play Death Run races. Like Time Bomb and Finish The Line. We can earn cars by winning Death Run races as reward. There are many types of cars available for our collection.

We can make better and proper progress if we play this game accordingly. There are quiet numbers of Side missions. We can earn great numbers of scraps for upgrading Magnum Opus, Max, Chumbucket, Weapons.

If you wants to upgrade everything then you have to increase your legend rank.  Making progress of legend rank will unlock new upgrades for Max. Terminating Camps, Convoys, Minefields, Snipers, Scarecrows will reduce threat meter to 0 from 5. This will also unlock new upgrades for Magnum Opus.

Pros :::
1. Realistic Graphics Quality.
2. There are few things to do in Wasteland.
3. Plenty of Side missions.
4. The fuel system and filling my cane with water is really amazing way for better focus in this game.
5. This game featured with massive open world map.
6. Highly Optimized Game. I am really impressed with it's optimization.
7. Story feels really epic and emotional.
8. Really a great style of combat with Fury Killing Ability.
9. Driving Magnum Opus feels really comfortable.
10. We can upgrade Max, Magnum Opus, Chumbucket, Strongholds.

You can rebuild strongholds by Project Parts. You have to collect Project Parts after tracking them on your map. Like if you build Scrap Crew then this Crew will collect scraps from all over the Wasteland while your game is off. But you must need Internet Connection for collecting those scraps from Crew.

You can play this game better if you upgrade your harpoon to level 6 which is max level of harpoon weapon. Also try to upgrade Max's Knucles and Jacket for his better defence.There are many types of enemy out there with upgraded in highly power. So you need best defence for Max that he can fight longer and defeat them.

This game is highly optimized. You can play this game smoothly with low mode settings in your low config. If you got Intel Core i5 with 8GB RAM and 2GB GDDR5 then you can explore Wasteland in Ultra High Settings.

Let me tell you that i am the 1st finisher of this game in Bangladesh. I got a best name for this game. Name's The Rising Legend. I found a best game after many years later. Like Assassin's Creed II, Assassin's Creed Revelations, Life is Strange, Tomb Raider, Metro Last Light, Deus-Ex Human Revolution. Really it's a amazing game with epic and emotional ending. The ending of this game made me so much weak. The price of this game worth it highly. So that's what i want to say about this game.

reviewText:
I'll try and keep it as much straight to the point as possible. First off it's not tied directly to the films as such, you are not Tom Hardy's Max and you are not Mel Gibson's Max so think of the game maybe seperate from the films, it is it's own thing here.

Best part so far, it works! It's not broken, there are no game breaking bugs. In 10 hours of game play I have had zero crashes or glitches. On top of that I'm about to do all this fully optimized with a 980 GTX. However do remember this will make your GPU work, so you may want something like msi afterburner to get those fans going faster to keep it cool. The first time around my card jump from 30c to 60c and that's without water cooling. I do have the water block for it I've just been too lazy to put it in.

So what's the game like? The best way to think about it is, take concepts from Far Cry , Assassins Creed, Borderlands Humour and a Batman Arkham style combat system then this is what you get. And I've gotta say so far it's a success.

Is it perfect? Of course it isn't, some would argue any game is perfect. For one I personally feel my controls are restricted for an open world, I want to be able to walk and run. I also want to be able to jump over and around things like you can in Assasins Creed and the Witcher but at times you can't jump over simple obsticles because you wern't meant to. But still, it's pretty minor and by no means a reason to give it a negative review.

I say Far Cry and Assasins Creed because in this open world instead of using radio watch towers and high pirches you have hot air balloons that go up and you use binoculars to scower the area yourself. If you rush it, you could miss unlocking something on the map. And Batman style combat, well because that's what it is. Fun, quick and easy to learn and really awesome to look at especially with finishers and other moves you can pick up as you upgrade Max along the way.

Ammo is scarce as it should be, it's a post apocolyptic world and there isn't exactly gun factories about so you have to concerve your ammo and use it wisely. If you take your time in the game and go to all the scavaging areas on the map then you'll come across plenty of ammo, and as long as you're not a ♥♥♥♥ it won't be a serious issue. You can upgrade certain perks by finding this myterious traveller following you about (looks familiar to!) who gives you upgrades and you can increase the amount of ammo you find amongst other things.

One nice touch here is the levellng system. Think of Max as having a bunch of ranks. You start off at the bottom and you level lets say 10 times by completing various tasks and goals such as killing x amount of bad guys this way or that way, or running so many people over. As you rank up you get to unlock more and more powerful upgrades. Naturally the final rank is Road Warrior".

The actual map is interesting
date: it's done in such a way where it would be really easy to knock out expansions and make additions
recommended: it could never end if they didn't want it to. Also it is quite large
hoursPlayed: after a few hours in the game you'll quickly realise there's a lot of things to do.\n\nYou get to upgrade your car

votesFunny: yes. Right now I'd say the game is worth the money (just). Let's hope we get some decent DLC for this to keep it alive for a number of years at least as it has potential to do so."

reviewText:
Mad Max is a third-person action game made by Avalanche Studios and published by Warner Bros. Although WB are getting a lot of hate for abandoning Batman: Arkham Knight and Mortal Kombat X on PC, this game is not the case! Avalanche Studios optimalised the game for PC perfectly!

What surprises you for the first time immediately, is the game world. It's not as big as in Just Cause games, but that doesn't matter, it's still huge. You'll be able to explore through the wastelands, see all 50 shades of sand, kill many mad warriors meanwhile and collect tons of scrap.

Scrap is the resource (or the currency) that is used in Mad Max for everything - you upgrade your weapons, your car or even Max's clothes with scrap. And there's plenty of upgrades for everything, so if you don't plan to get 100% achievements, you won't even unlock every upgrade the game offers. But the scrap isn't the only thing you need for unlocking the upgrades, most of advanced ones also require completing a specific mission or a simple task, like: Lower the antagonist's (Scabrous Scrotus) influence in area by taking over his camps or destroying his scarecrows (pylons that should let people around know who rules in the wasteland).

While you can have about 5 basic car constructions (upgradable in any way you want) there are many more vehicles in the game, and you can control all of those! You'll find use for them in racing (death runs) that offers few types of races.

The combat is similar to Batman Arkham series, with many similar animations (punching, kicking and jumping groups of enemies) and practically same controls. You mash the left button for attack and when anyone in the enemy group attacks you, you have to parry the attack with right button. With exception for knife attacks and finishing moves, that's all. Anyway, it's not any significantly hard and it's fun.

What's also a great pro of the game is the attention for details that aren't mentioned much when people talk around the game. There's a specific weather (random) event that'll make you impressed, but I don't want to spoil the details. Through the world you'll explore, you'll be finding photos of the old world (before the sandpocalypse), usually with something written on the back side. Those lead you (and the Max) to thinking about what in the game world is already lost.

The story is not bad for a game based primarly around combat, racing and exploring, it even tries to play with your emotions. But it'll most probably fail, because Max is stonehearted, so you'll get over all bad events like it was nothing. There's few really interesting characters that have interesting backstory, but there's also characters that you meet without any proper explanation of sympathies.

I think that every player will be really excited to explore everything in the beginning, every small camp with scrap. But that doesn't last forever and most players will later find the breaking point" where they found exploring being too much repetitive
date: leading to sticking just with the main story missions (they'll require you to do some regular exploring few times anyway).\n\nThe content recycling in the game (repeating enemies
hoursPlayed: with exception for one thing that ended up pretty bad - the bossfight(s). There are many bossfights in the game (especially for the side exploring - beating the Top Dogs) but they all are the same
voteText: the bosses even still use the same weapon! Only thing that changes is the arena where they fight and number of other NPCs that spawn around to help the boss.\n\nThe world of Mad Max has a day/night cycle
helpfulPercent: which is great but feels half-baked with the fact that you can't rest until specific part of the day comes. As there are few missions that requires to do them at night
votesHelpful: you might end up having to do something else for about 90 minutes
votesTotal: while waiting for night.\n\nIn the end
votesFunny: I was really entertained for more than 20 hours thanks to Mad Max. As a current AAA game I got enough satisfaction out of it and even though I have not found motivation to complete everything that's not mandatory in the game
commentsCount:
I still think it's a great game and definitely deserves my recommendation.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a game I'd highly recommend. It does so much more than most games and is obviously lovingly crafted.

From a story perspective it's there and it's in perfect quantity. You can rush through the story if you want and have a nice compact experience, or you could play for 15 hours after you get done with the intro not touching the story at all and just focus on clearing camps, taking out snipers, taking down scarecrows, clearing minefields, searching for scrap, taking out a convoy, or upgrading a fortress to its completion before you decide to take on another mission. The ending while I can imagine it being divisive is my favorite since Red Dead Redemption. I won't spoil it for you but I will advise you giving it some time to sit with you and reflect on how fitting it is.

Touching a bit more on those optional objectives. I've heard complaints about the grindy aspect of it, and I will admit that if you don't enjoy a grind it may be a bit tedious for you. I am the kind of gamer though that enjoys a nice solid grind with a reward at the end. When I completely lowered the threat down in someone's territory I felt accomplished, I had a much faster and more dangerous vehicle, and my Max had gotten much better as well.

Visually the game is gorgeous. To me the beauty of the Mad Max movies (particularly The Road Warrior and Fury Road) is the contrast between the deep blue sky and the browns/oranges of the desert wasteland and this game pulls it off perfectly. The visuals are also somewhat varied with white sea beds, tan dunes, orange earthy deserts, black tarry oil pumps, and black/gray dumps. Color isn't muted either and when you see a brighter color from a flare or an enemy covered in paint it's a very pretty sight.

The sound is very top notch. The bass of the shotgun or the roar of your engine (especially when you get a V8) is very deep and a pleasure to listen to. The higher sounds like the scraping of your vehicle against another or the screech of your tires also comes off as real and fantastic.

Your gameplay is going to be split into driving and on foot brawling. The driving is a lot of fun and is quite the spectacle. Taking out a convoy is a blast as you grapple off tires, shoot explosive harpoons, or use your shotgun while driving to blow up an enemy's gas tank. Driving feels fast and fluid and is a lot of fun on its own, the combat is great and is the perfect icing on top. When you're on your feet brawling around a camp it's very gritty dirty and fun fighting that's a blast. You'll be body slamming, drop kicking, and gut punching enemies into submission, and you can even dirty it up with a shotgun to the stomach, taking an enemy melee weapon and quickly disposing of a group, or a shiv to the throat when an enemy lets their guard drop. Brawling mostly consists of parries, hits, and dodges with an indicator above enemy heads to signal what they are about to do, if you're familiar with the Arkham series or Shadow of Mordor you'll feel comfortable quickly.

Mad Max is a game that deserves a lot more recognition for the amount of fun fullfilling content it provides. It had a very unfortunate release date but if you ever get a chance it's definitely a fun game that dips its toes into a lot of genres whilst also making them fun and unique to fit its tone. If putting on some music and driving and fighting around a wasteland on a quest for a better car and better gear sounds like fun to you it's a definite must buy.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a really fun open world experience.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VhxGYWOyqBc
I'll start off by talking about the world itself. It's beautifully designed. Sure the environment is just an open and empty desert for the most part, but they really crafted some interesting scenery. Cool canyon formations, rubbel from the old world like destroyed ships, or wrecked buildings. The game's graphics look beautiful, and can actually be cranked up quite a bit considering the game is fantastically optimized.

There are tons of different objectives to complete while out in the wasteland, all decently unique to keep the game from getting stale. Sometimes you can compete in a race, or scavenge some ruins for scrap metal, or infiltrate a base. Something quite interesting about the bases, is you occasionally have the option to get some intel from a nearby wastelander surveying the location. It's not necessary, but they might give you some useful tips such as a hidden entrance, or the Base leader's weakness.

You use scrap metal for upgrading Max and your vehicle, and you gain it by doing basically everything. You can find it scattered in buildings, or pick it from the wreckage of a destroyed vehicle, or dropped from a defeated enemy.

Something I love about the game is there's quite a bit of choice when it comes to a few things. Apart from allowing you to choose how to infiltrate a base. For example, gas cans can be used to refill cars, or lit on fire and thrown to blow up doors.

The world is very dynamic. There's a full day and night cycle, and occasionally tornadoes will form. They're not very dangerous, but still freaky. Sometimes gigantic dust storms will sweep the land. You have the choice of either getting to shelter to stay safe, or drive right into the storm and attempt to survive flying debris, lightning hitting the ground in order to grab some valuable scrap metal boxes flying through. I love that the game allows you to risk it for the biscuit like that.

Now to get to the focus of the game, vehicles. You can upgrade yours a very large amount. You can choose between car body shapes, colours, decals, engine types, spikes to stop boarders, rams and so on. It's very satisfying to see your car turn into a badass killing machine. Apart from ramming into your enemies, you can also use your arsenal of weapons. Either shooting the tires, or exposed fuel barrels with your shotgun. You may harpoon doors off a car, and then pull the driver out, or shoot a stream of flames.

The combat when you're on foot is very similar to the Batman Arkham games. although it has a few stuff to keep it unique in its own ways. The better you time your counters, the more bone-breaking opportunities you have. In melee combat you can still use your shotgun or finite knives to quickly dispatch an enemy. As you fight you fill up your fury meter, which basically just makes you stronger and gives you more chances to instantly finish off an enemy with stronger attacks. It's some very satisfying fighting.

Overall, I've had so much fun with the game, and even after the main story I've continued to 100% the game. My only real complaint would be the fact that in order to unlock some car upgrades, you need to lower the threat of certain regions. In doing so, less enemies are driving around that area, but that means you don't get to have fun killing those enemies with your newly upgraded car. A new game+ mode would be perfect for this. Apart from that though, incredibly fun experience, very well polished and generally awesomely fun carnage!

Overall 9.5/10

reviewText:
Amongst a multitude of open world games with maps littered by icons for collectibles as a substitute for gaming content, Mad Max does something with the genre: it turns all of these collectibles into exploration pieces. This doesn't exactly solve the problem; exploring over a hundred of tiny settlements becomes as tedious as hunting down a hundred of other collectibles, but it does turn what would be a collectathon into a series of adventures and the resulting product is that much richer for it.

Mad Max is at its best whenever it turns into a dungeon crawler in post-apocalyptic Australia. Imagine Middle-Earth: Shadows of Mordor where instead of gaining intel on orc warlords you gain intel to take down enemy bases. Scout enemy camps from afar before taking out their perimeter defenses in your V6 engine car, then battle it out inside while seeking treasure troves of metal scraps.

The features are what sets Mad Max apart from other games. There are definite improvements to the traditional Batman-style melee while car combat has a range of over-the-top special attacks such as the harpoon slam, drive-by shootings, THUNDERPOONS and flaming jets of incineration. Meanwhile, the weakness in the main story actually made me wistful for the Assassin's Creed franchise! Say what you will about their game balance; you knew absurd action hero ♥♥♥♥ was gonna go down the minute you accepted that Story Mission! Here it's the opposite: Story Missions are quite tame and most of the value comes from investigating non-essential camps and hunting down enemy convoys.

One must enjoy the greater changes Mad Max brings to the genre if they are to appreciate their purchase. This could've just as easily been a negative review if I nitpicked every little thing that went wrong: Top Dog bosses follow identical patterns, the vehicles you collect from the enemy serve no purpose, ditto the archangel alternative car builds"

Neutral Rating

Really not sure about this Game... It HAD potential, but I think a lot of it was missed. For me, the Game had more Negative aspects to it. I'd only recommend this during a Sale, and only recommended for someone who wants a Game to mess around in.

The Story itself is extremely short with just 15 Missions which take no time at all to complete. Not only is the Story short, but it just bored me and not once did I really even care for it. It just felt like an empty shell. The only thing that made this Game have some length was the fact you have to complete tasks to unlock Story Missions. Complete so and so amount of Wasteland Missions, complete so and so amount of Stronghold Projects.

None of the Characters were interesting, and although the Voice acting was decent, the cut scenes were just short, and quick to the point with no context.

Surely the Gameplay would make up for it though. Unfortunately the Gameplay is hindered with the horrible Auto Camera [slow Manual Camera], and slow response on the Controls which felt like it had a slight lag after pushing in a direction.

The Game has the usual Assassins Creed style combat, punch punch, counter when you see the Marker, but unfortunately, the Game doesn't allow you to turn the Counter Markers off, which just makes the combat so easy and boring after awhile. Infact, NOTHING in the Game was a challenge... Apart from fighting the Camera and Controls.

The Game has 9 Boss Fights in total, 3 with Scrotus [the Main boss] and 6 Mini" Boss Fights. However 4 of these Bosses is someone wielding a large Mace

reviewText:
Real life Australia simulator: A giant wasteland desert full of criminals and vegabonds where everything can kill you.

If you like the films, or just enjoy fun open world games you will find a lot to enjoy here. Think of Shadow of Mordor's open world system getting married to the combat of Batman Arkam Asylum/City/ect  with a touch of survival game, and then dumping those elements into the MAD MAX universe. That is what we have here. It may not do anything outstandingly new to the genre, but it blends several really good and fun elements together in a very enjoyable game with a game world that is both ridiculous and entertaining (Just like the flms.).

If that isn't good enough, the game is also INCREDIBLY well optimized, right from release. Everything works, no visible bugs in my hours of play, and with only a single GTX 960 the game runs on MAX (The games Ultra setting.)  at a fluid 60fps regardless of the action going on on screen. A welcome feature in a world of games which release unfinished.

reviewText:
This is an absolutely wonderful game from Avalanche Studios. The same guys that did Just Cause 2.

While Mad Max shares the title name and protagonist of the Mad Max movies, the world and story is actually completely non canon to the film franchise. Max here is based on neither Mel Gibson or Tom Hardy's Max Max. Completely original, and leaving the player to their own interpretations on how to play as Mr. Rockatasnky.

Max starts out the game having his trusty V8 stolen, and sets off on a grandiose apocalyptic adventure through the wasteland in an attempt to get back what is rightfully his. Early in the game you meet your sidekick and comic relief for the game in the form of a hunchback named Chumbucket. Chumbucket is also your trusted mechanic, who helps Max by creating a car for him called the Magnum Opus. A vehicle which Max can customize through Chumbucket a number of ways. It is also the vehicle Max will use for a large portion of the game.

Mad Max takes place in a massive and barren wasteland, that shares no settings with the movies, but has completely original areas. And though the game has a lot of what you'd expect in a wasteland setting, it still seems to have a diversity lacking in most open world games. The world is as depressingly dreadful as it is also artistically wonderful. Luckily, Avalanche included a built in screenshot tool with editing features to capture some magnificent shots of the world.

The gameplay is a mixed bag. On one hand you have a combat system that is reminiscent of games like the Arkham and Assassin's Creed games as well as Shadow of Mordor, with it's attack attack attack parry attack system, with little in terms of depth. This system has been found to be quite simple in other games, but Mad Max kicks it up a notch by requiring much better timing from the player. This might be a little frustrating for some players. And others might find it a bit boring. Luckily, the gameplay has you about 80% of the time in the vehicle, and this is where the game really shines. The vehicle combat is incredibly satisfying in this game. You will find yourself ramming into other vehicles, using a harpoon to tear vehicles apart, and even shooting a modified rocket launcher of sorts to cause even more chaos all across the wasteland. And it is all executed wonderfully. What's even cooler is that while the Magnum Opus is indeed your vehicle of choice, you can steal and even collect for later use any of the other vehicles found in the game.

The structure of progression is pretty simple, but the amount of content in it is still quite massive. You have your main story progression, which sends you off on various missions to do this, collect that, kill that person. Pretty standard stuff. But you can not progress through the story entirely until you start doing some stuff on the side, like clearing out the threat of major gans in different areas, by eliminating them, taking over special convoy routes, taking over bases, and more. And there are still plenty of even more side diversions, like tons of places to loot for supplies, races, and more. Though the world may seem barren, it still has quite an enormous amount of things to do.

There is a good deal of customization also to be found in the game ranging from your vehicle to Max himself. You can change the appearance of Max himself with unlockables you gain through a progressive ranking system, and also equip him with new moves for combat, new armor, and more. You can also do your usual upgrades to the Magnum Opus which involve different body types, armor, paint jobs, engines upgrades, tires, and more. The game also has a gas system, which means you can actually run out of gas while driving too much. Luckily gas is not hard to come by, and I have never actually had the displeasure of running out. Water is more scarce, but you never dehydrate. You only need water when you get injured in combat. you can also even feed on maggots from old corpses to regain health. Sick! There is not much realism in the gas and water system, but it's still kind of neat.

anyone looking for a realistic game (I've heard the complaints), please look elsewhere. This game does not strive to follow the movies to the letter, but rather create an extremely fun and extremely chaotic game for fans of the ACTION from the movies.

reviewText:
Introduction:Being the first game of the series this is an amazing game. Love the fact that it was paid for by Warner Bros. who also made Tomb Raider which gave it the perfect feeling. A lot of the mechanics are similar to Tomb Raider games. This game didn't disappoint once.

Pros:LOTS OF DRIVING (pro IMO, could be a con for you)
Good graphics
Long story
Good plot
Good selection of cars
Ton of upgrades for cars and Max
So many side missions and collectibles
Huge map
Extremely optimized
Mostly bug free
Great special effects (smoke, fire, sounds)

Cons:Only single player
Really hard bosses with no difficulty setting
A few times certain sound effects were mute
Sometimes the game isn't clear with your objective
You can drive any car you find but can't use it as a primary vehicle

Conclusion:I had a lot of fun playing game especially after reading the book and watching the movie. WBs did a very good job with this game. When I saw the movie this was exactly the game I imagined. There's nothing I thought was missing except the multiplayer aspect. Especially after the story is done there isn't much. It would be cool if they made a The Crew type online mode where you see others. But other than that its a masterpiece.

For more reviews check out  Original Curators Group

reviewText: I got this game on a Friday.  Put 50 hours into it by the next Friday.  Yeah, it's that good.  The game is very addicting and the tasks that you complete are so much fun.  You get to destroy camps full of enemies with Batman style combat, drive around the Wasteland seeking different parts that are essential for upgrading your camps/vehicle, all wrapped up in a great story.  I highly recommend this game.  It has been a while since I picked up a game and played it exclusively until I finished it, and I'm glad this was once of them.  I had so many Mad Max withdrawals once I finished the game that I started watching the Mad Max movies.  Great game.

reviewText:
I will keep this review short, because I don't want to write about everything good that this game is, but rather let you experience the game yourselves.

Mad Max is a 3rd person, post apocalyptic, survival, action game with large open world, brutal hand to hand and vehicular combat. You play as Max, a survivor in harsh and unforgiving Wasteland, controlled by bandit gangs.

Laying almost dead, and bleeding on the burning sands of Wasteland. Beaten down by the bandit gang with all of your hard earned possessions stripped from you. Max must find strength to get up and take the Mad to the bandits.

This game is basically Tomb Raider + Uncharted 2 with Carmageddon vehicular madness in post apocalyptic Wasteland. Thus you get similar movement, platforming (to extent), survival, looting and equipment upgrades as in Tomb Raider / Uncharted 2, with more refined and brutal hand to hand combat. And all the crazy vehicle madness from Carmageddon, in addition to the upgradeable vehicle parts and body modifications.

Controls are responsive yet tad sluggish, but you get the hang of it fast so there's nothing wrong here. Voice acting is good, with great lip sync in cut-scenes, but not so much out of them. You drive your car mostly through sand so it's understandable it will feel a bit unresponsive, but you can modify so many aspects of your vehicle and fine tune it to the handling you need.

Environment is mostly Wasteland, so rocks, sand, sandstorms, occasional dust devil, as well as some nice view distance on landscape. Once in a while you see some eye catching scenes at night or by day that make you stop the car and soak in the beauty, even though it's just barren Wasteland.

Main currency in game is scrap, similar to Tomb Raider where you come across some crates with parts, here you pick up metal scrap that is hand placed through environment and also can be dropped by enemies and destroyed vehicles. You use scrap to upgrade your car, pay for Max's upgrades, modifications and gear.

Main gameplay besides story is to capture, destroy different points on the map, to eliminate bandits and reduce gang presence in that area, so less bandit patrols, higher rewards from survival ally camps who take control of the camps you free.

Hand to hand combat is brutal and often pleasant to the eye. You fight more than one opponent at the time with counter indicators that let you plan your attacks, defenses. The higher combo you keep, the stronger attacks are, you can combo fast and strong attacks with ground and weapon takedowns, and also with body to surface detection. So you can sprint bash someone into the wall and then beat him silly holding against it.

Vehicular combat is all about ramming sensitive parts of enemy vehicle, ripping off car parts with harpoon to either get to the driver or just have fun and tear off tires from vehicle to continue the fight on foot. Enemies can jump on your car and get to you if you're not careful, so plan your car upgrades and invest in less defended areas.

I already talked too much, even though I wanted to keep it short. It's very well made game, runs on Havok engine which is awesome. You can fine tune the settings to match your hardware, personally I didn't have any issues with it even being below recommended and playing on High. It looks like majority of players who bought this game are happy with it, and for the low price (not on steam) it's well worth the money spent.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=510204277

P.S. Took me 75 hours to beat everything, with 48 out of 49 achievements. Didn't bother with last one because you have to do ALL in game challenges, and there are A LOT of those. In the end (with not trying to do them) I didn't have around 20, and I don't feel like wasting time completing those. Other than that I'm very happy with the game, I enjoyed it a lot, and it was money well spent.

Enjoy.

reviewText:
Fantastic game so far. I keep planning to only play for an hour or two, and then I look at the clock and 6-7 hours have passed. Really addicting to just roam around the map finding scrap to help upgrade my car.

Huge open world, fun to drive around in and explore, great combat (both on-foot and in the cars), great music, solid voice acting and decent story with many small nods to all the films, and it's very optimized to boot! Avalanche did a great job on the PC version.

Highly recommended!

Edit:

After 31 hours I've beaten the game. To be fair, I did a good bit of side missions and exploring, but I'm not even close to finishing everything the game has to offer. I haven't even bought most of the upgrades! I've put 31 hours into this game since it came out 7 days ago, and I still plan to put dozens more hours into this. It's so much fun just to roam around the wasteland, scavenging for supplies, taking over camps, stealing enemy cars to add to your vehicle collection.

This game is damn good, and I can't wait to play more tomorrow.

reviewText:
Mad Max is my GOTY for 2015. It's a fantastic open-world action game and it's everything I hoped it would be.
I would highly recommend it. Prior knowledge of Mad Max is nonessential.

+ Extensive character and vehicle customization and upgrades.
+ Vehicular and on-foot combat is fun, challenging and engaging.
+ Solid amount of content and things to do. I was never bored while playing and I enjoyed all 35 hours of the game.
+ Fantastic art direction and visuals.
+ Great breadth of enemies, both people and vehicular.
+ Very well optimised like every Avalanche game up until this point. (Runs great at 1080p on High on my GTX 560).
+ Story is quite good, although I have experienced better.
- Voice acting in some encounters is rather poor but does not detract from the overall experience.

reviewText: All I remember of Mad Max was a dusty Mel Gibson, a big bad car, and feeling a connection to the desperate wanderers he came across.  In a way, it's one of the first apocalyptic worlds I'd ever seen.  It has it's appeal.  Thunderdome and Tina Turner with the crazies and bloodlust.  These days it's all post-apocalyptic hell with zombies, so seeing a wasteland in a new but familiar universe of Mad Max wasn't hard to process and a nice change for all the end-of-the-world-ness in games I see.\n\nWell then, what's it all about?  Giant open world areas, some fun car caravan takedowns, the usual batman-eque fighting, using a  fast car to destroy stuff, and mostly enjoying the world of Mad Max in a video game.  A first I thought, Ok

reviewText:
Only played the game for a short amount of time but i am already loving it (not that i am biased or anything)

PROS:

It has been extremely well optimised, its visually stunning and still keeps a constant 60fps.

The car combat is fun and i thrilling, there is nothing more satisfying than ripping enemy driver out of their car with the harpoon gun.

The hand to hand combat is reminiscent of Shadow of Mordor and the Batman games, i know not everyone likes that style of combat but i think it fits very well into this style of game.

I love richness of the upgrade system for the car, aswell as the items and clothing that you can unlock for Max himself.

Cons:

To be completely honest i haven't found anything that i dislike in the game as of yet. In certain open world games i get tired of the hugeness of the maps but by having the car to travel around in its not like it takes you that long to get you from A to B and engage in some vehicle combat inbetween.

Overall i am thoroughly enjoying it so far. In my opinion i feel its a shame that it was released on the same day as MGSV as i feel that a lot of people will play that first and probably try and pick this up later on in the year.

reviewText:
I was able to finish the main story on the lowest settings possible on these specs:
CPU: Intel Core i5 3210M
RAM: 8.00GB Dual-Channel DDR3
Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 4000
2048MB ATI AMD Radeon HD 7600M Series  Plot  – First of all the game is not directly connected to the movie even though being released on the same year. Max’ ultimate quest is to reach the Plains of Silence, a fabled land where he might find solace from his madness. But instead, he finds himself getting his V8 Interceptor stolen by the War Boys of Scabrous Scrotus, Immortan Joe’s third psychotic son. With the help of Chumbucket, a blackfinger, Max embarks on a journey to get his vengeance and take back what is his.

The main plot and some scenes may be predictable to some, or maybe even a cliché to at least. But it doesn’t mean it’s bad. In fact, I personally enjoy the story all throughout and I’m pretty satisfied with how the story went.

Gameplay  – The game showcases two types of gameplay. First off is when a vehicle, the gameplay is somehow similar to Vigilante or the Twisted Metal series. Though you have the option to use other faction vehicles, nothing is compared to what the Magnum Opus, your own vehicle, can offer you. Other than the harpoon, sniper rifle, and the thunderpoon, you also have the freedom to customize your vehicle the way you want it to. And it is actually balance and just. Not because you have all the high-tier upgrades, it doesn’t mean it’ll be the best vehicle out there. No. And that is actually great in my opinion. And the upgrades can actually be seen in the vehicle, you can style the Magnum Opus any way you want it.

Second is when you’re on foot. If you have played any Batman Arkham games, you’ll most likely be familiar with how this game works out. And this is one of the most brutal games I may have played not just because of the blood, but because of what can Max do to his enemies. I’ve been hearing multiple cracked jaws and bones everytime I beat someone and it is very satisfying. I have mentioned that there are upgrades for your vehicle; well there are also multiple upgrades for Max to help him out in his fights.

Environment and Design  –  The whole map is huge, at least for me. To be honest, I am more than surprised to see how amazing the world is. Sure, in a rough glance the world may seem too flat or bland. But wait until you start exploring side quests and maybe just roaming around. There are lot of stuff to see in this game.

Controls  – I’ve played this game with a controller, I feel like it would be easier beating up enemies and driving the vehicles with a controller instead. For problems, I’m glad that I didn’t run into any major ones to ruin the game for me. Though there is a thing that may become annoying to some as you progress through the game. Most of the time, the game will require you to hold the interact button or key for you to take action. It gets annoying because you will be doing it a lot of times.

Conclusion  – I may have finished the story of this game, but there are still numerous areas undiscovered, many camps aren’t looted yet, many towers not yet taken down, some snipers are still hunting. If you’re interested in games that still offer something even when the main story is done, then this one deserves to be in your wishlist. Even with the fps that I’m getting, I really had fun playing this game.

A fair warning to those with OCD, when you’re in a camp, the game will show you the total scraps there is in a specific camp or area. And guess what, I used YouTube twice on two different areas just so that I can achieve a 100% on that specific camp and move on to the next one.

reviewText:
This is my first review on steam.  I don't write reviews becuase I am rarely pleased, let alone excited like I am with Mad Max.

I have gotta hand it to the developers.  They did a great job making this game.  I have been playing for 32 hours so far and there hasn't been a single crash.  There has been the occansional slight stutter and drop below 60fps (according to FRAPS).  I am running WIN7-64 with a 3.4Ghz i7 with 32GB ram, RAID 10 SSD array, and dual AMD 290x's in crossfire(stock-clocked).  They are PCIEX 3.0 (one at 8x and the other at 4x, due to the RAID controller using the other 4 lanes)  I have a 4K monitor and I have everything set to MAXimum :-)

I am very pleased with the gameplay and the performance.  I have been playing PC games as long as PCs have been around (Yes, I have some grey hair -- maybe more than *some*).  This is the first game in a long time (since DOOM 1.0 and early WOW) where I have been sucked in and immersed in the game.

The overall experience, strategy and the pace of the game keep me coming back for more.  I find myself looking forward to playing and letting other responsiblitles slip in order to keep playing...

I wish all of the last 10+ games I have purchased were even 1/3 as enjoyable as Mad Max.  I hope other publishers and developers learn from the Mad Max experience.

I can't wait to see how things go now that the enemies and missions are getting tougher,..

reviewText:
Mad Max The game follows loosely story of the new Mad Max Movie.

Gameplay 8 of 10
You play Max Rockatansky in a dystopian world full of not quite normal people. Collect metal scrap (the new currency) to update your car, a hideout or climb the skill tree that is available for Max. Fight your way through hordes of enemies, either with your shotgun or barehanded. The combat system is a little like the one from the Batman Arkham series. So a little simple, but works quite good for me. And it feels somehow a lot more realistic than in Batman. Infiltrate hangouts, race wild sand races against some quite tough opponents, do little side-missions, collect relicts of the past...and so on.

Graphics     9 of 10
I LOVE it! From the sandy dunes with the beautiful sunsets to the starry bluish nights. Absolutely amazing. My friend is playing it on a 4K tv screen and it's just amazing .The footprints in the sand, the incredible storms, the water. BIG thumbs up. And I might say it’s graphical wise quite a competitor for Fallout 4.

Music          8.5 of 10
The music is generally quite soothing and somber. Very fitting for this post-apocalyptic world.
The part where it really shines is the sound of the car engines. You really feel the V8 engine roaring.

Final Verdict 8.5 of 10
A great game based on a movie. The graphics, the music and the gameplay form an overall nearly perfect game. Why nearly? Sometimes the fighting is a little repetitive and the taking of the hideout as well and the story is not that breathtaking. Still I strongly recommend it. Rarely has any games atmosphere sucked me in that much.

reviewText:
I, like many others, was poised to be disappointed by Mad Max.  The ridiculous pre-order deals (I got it for 36 dollars at GMG), and the publisher connection to the recent Arkham Knight debacle had me worried I'd wasted my money.  I've never been so wrong.  This game is:

1.  Fully functional from the start.  No stuttering, no texture pop-in, no frame-rate cap or issues, no glitches or bugs.  The optimization is the best I've ever seen for a AAA launch title - I was able to play at reasonable FPS at 4k with one GTX 970.

2.  Achingly beautiful.  I said I was able to play at 4k, but I didn't have to because the game is so perfectly crafted that it looks suitable photorealistic and jawdropping even at 1080p.   Special emphasis on the lighting, shadows and particle effects (the explosions are phenomenal).

3.  Raging fun.  The melee combat is smoother, harder, and way more engaging than in Batman: Arkham.  It requires attention and quick reflexes and feels intense and deeply powerful.  The sandbox world is massive and filled with violent activities.  The general goal of these can get repetitve towards the end of the game, but the devs did a marvelous job of making each and every location look and feel different to keep the excitiement to the MAX.  One issue here is that the boss fights at some of the camps are more or less identical.  There are four main strongholds that can be upgraded and expanded through what are essentially fetch quests, but still just as fun and varied as the story missions.

By far the best part of the game is the vehicle combat, analogous to the recent cinematic masterpiece Mad Max: Fury Road.  Along with random open-world encounters, there are convoys around the game world and you take them on singlehandedly using not only your car as a weapon but shotguns, harpoons, thunderpoons (grenade harpoons), and flamethrowers.  These convoy battles  get progressively more intense as the game progresses, and are a highlight of the playthrough.

4. All about the cars. They could've totally screwed it up and made a Mad Max game where the cars were a sideshow.  They did not.  Basically the entire plot centers on Max's desire to be reunited with his Interceptor, and in the meantime to build the most outrageous war machine possible with the help of his master mechanic hunchback companion Chumbucket.  Throughout the game you upgrade your car (The Magnum Opus) with body styles, engines, suspension, tires, exhausts, armor, weapons, custom paint and ornaments.  You can also collect any car you find in the wasteland for further use.

5,  A sonic experience.  The car sounds are gloriously rabid, and each engine and exhaust mod makes your Magnum Opus all the more ferocious.  Play it in 7.1 surround and the vehicle combat comes alive, with earblasting explosions and roaring v6 and v8 thunder.  Voice acting for the main characters is sublimely realistic and emotional; wish there were more Australians in it though.

6.  A surprisingly engaging story.  For me, the ongoing love story between Max and his Interceptor was enough, but the later portions of the story were unexpectedly strong and well-written.  No spoilers, but Max gets realllllllly mad.

7. A true addition to the Mad Max canon. This is a faithful and yet inventive new venue for Max.  His character is portrayed just right, with minimal dialogue and just enough haunted memories to make us believe we're really Max Rockatansky.  Visually, he's a hybrid of Mel Gibson and Tom Hardy, and his upgradeable clothes and weapons are legit and very cool to use and look at.

To conclude, I finished the main story at about 25 hours of play, I've put another 10 in so far to complete the car upgrades and clear out enemies from the world.  The average player will probably get 20-30 hours out of this, but being a massive fan of Mad Max I'm not even close to leaving yet.  I recommend it to both newcomers and fans of the series -  its an action sandbox tour-de-force.  Enjoy.

reviewText:
Releasing a movie tie-in game usually goes one of two ways: either it’s a rush job thrown out with the movie to get some quick bucks, or the developer actually has the time it needs, regardless off the potential loss of income because of a later release date. Thankfully, Warner has allowed Avalanche the time to make a solid, vast open-world that is a lot more fun than the colour palette might suggest.

And there is an enormous amount going on in Mad Max; just so many systems operating at once. You can upgrade Max, or his beloved car, The Magnum Opus, whenever you like from the pause menu with scavenged scrap (the currency that runs the world), but there are core abilities that you can only level up using tokens received from completing challenges. These are the important ones, really, as they increase things like Max’s strength, or health, or even how long a full tank of fuel might last. But you can only upgrade these at set locations. They’re not hidden and are on your map, but it’s a little odd to have a conceit like this in play when there are so many moments that flaunt how gamey it is.

Take Max himself, for example. Once the car takes a certain amount of damage you’ll have to get out and wait while your companion, Chumbucket, fixes it up. But the enemies don’t care, and will keep coming at you. The AI here is quite smart (elsewhere they will expertly dodge you as you drive around engaging them), and will just try to drive right over you, but if you have a decent amount of health, you’ll stagger a bit but not die. After a few dodge rolls and a bit of running round in circles (get used to doing this, by the way), you can jump back into your ride and get moving, harpooning a Wastelander out of his car to certain death.

These moments are as stupid as they are cathartic. The way you can take damage is obscene, but all is forgiven when you enter slow-motion, harpoon a guy right in the chest and tap circle to quickly pull him from his vehicle, whereby he whips towards you, which lets you ram him head-on. The harpoon gun is a triumph, and the most Avalanche thing here. Driving around firing it into sniper towers and pulling them down never gets old, and the sniper rifle mechanic is interesting, too. Rather than giving you a sniper to run around with like the shotgun you have, it’s fired from the back of your car. Chumbucket can drive the car for you (though you control it) and you can creep up to enemy bases, slowly picking off their snipers. Again, it never gets old.

Thankfully the wasteland survival ideas are well implemented. Water is scarce, sure, but most of the time you’re in a situation where you’ll need to use it to heal, it’ll be some kind of stronghold (small or large) so there will be a tap, or pool to fill up your flask. Gas is needed to keep your vehicles running, but it takes a while to use it, and again, tanks can be found at populated areas. In a nice touch, you can put a spare canister in your boot just in case you run your tank dry, but you can also pick it up and throw it at enemies, exploding it with a shotgun burst.

The combat is the Batman Arkham melee method that, quite honestly, I’m nowhere near tired of. Mad Max’s world is a brutal one, and although you can happily pummel away at combos with the square button, and counter with triangle, things are mixed up with the addition of unlockable extra moves. A particular good one (early on) is simply to hold the attack button after two hits for a strong finisher. You can pick up weapons and integrate them into your move-set, too, and if you’ve collected any shivs you can finish people with them. Or, should you buy the skill, you could just get in close for a shotgun to the gut – it’s a one-hit kill, obviously. It makes for a violent, bloody system that feels damn good.

Car combat is less successful at first, but not bad. Depending on how upgraded your vehicle is, you can use the harpoon to differing degrees of success, but you can also target the red barrels in the trunks to quickly blow them up. On top of that, another option is to simply ram into your enemy – which has varying degrees of success depending again on what you’ve spent your scrap on. There’s a lot of car combat, though, and the slow motion aiming is a Godsend that removes most of the frustration. But you’ll have to get used to it, as you’re a sitting duck if you leave the Magnum Opus for too long.

It’s a very a-typical open-world game, in many ways, but one that’s faithful to the source material, especially when it comes to the characters. Max is an utter ♥♥♥♥, but a badass with it. No matter what people do to help, he’s never nice to them. You could argue that this is because of the harsh, barren world he inhabits – everyone here wants to kill you, or use you for a deal. But the character you warm to the quickest is Chumbucket, so it’s hard to hear Max continually abuse him with his negativity. The voice acting is fine, for the most part, but the downtrodden, gruff Max is a little hard to like. It’s a very comic-book like universe, and the people are designed to match: burnt skin, tattoos, and even one guy who has razors cut into his skin – I’m not sure if that’s for effect or so he can keep his face beard-free.

What Mad Max does best, however, is never, ever take itself seriously. The opening cut-scene (which I won’t spoil, obviously) is over the top, but also features a gruesome chainsaw scene. As you take control for the first time and realise the person in that scene isn’t dead, you realise exactly what kind of game this is. There’s no logical reason how he can be alive after what you saw, but there it is, and he’s the main antagonist you’re fighting back against.

The story is generally fine, but nothing special. Most main missions see you have to chase something down and take someone out, and although there’s an attempt to make you care now and then, it falls flat. The fun is to be had just exploring, maybe getting caught in a horrendous storm that nearly takes your life.

Technically, there are a few frame-rate hiccups that are seemingly par for the course with open world games, but otherwise the only way Mad Max suffers is because of the source material. Fire, sand, metal – the trifecta of the world. You can’t blame Avalanche for keeping to that, but it does sometimes make for a bland looking game. There are some excellent moments, though, like those storms, or when night is setting in and it gets cold. Particle effects and explosions are fantastic, and there’s a real sense of style despite the brown look, especially when it comes to the gorgeous sky.

Mad Max is a fun game. You’ll happily lose an hour or two here and there, and feel great about it Nobody quite does that open-world charm like Avalanche, and the harpoon never stops being a source of mirth. The combat is great, and if you’re after an open world third-person title, you could do a lot worse.

Pros:
Harpoon gun is brilliant.
Visually stunning at times.
On-foot combat is great.
Cons:
Story is a bit dull.
Car combat won't be for everyone.
My Rating: 7.5/10
