reviewText:
Difficult to reproduce the atmosphere of Mad Max world. This game, instead, succeeds admirably.
Varied, fun and a lots things to do.
Enjoyable fighting mechanics.

Good variety of side missions, could be a little more, the map is very large, and although the locations may look the same, it offers a good variety of places.

I suggest to buy it when your price idea will be ok.

reviewText:
Combine the following for Mad Max:
1 part Grand Theft Auto
1 part Fallout
2 parts Just Cause
1 part Batman: Arkham Asylum
1 part Borderlands
1 part Elder Scrolls

I've got over 20 hours into this game already, have completed around 30% of it, I've completed the game, and have decided to write recommending review because it has been an absolute blast to play.

The game starts off a little slow, but the variety of environments, the enjoyable and satisfying combat (vehicular and on foot), and the Fury Road situations and lore make me loathe having to turn the game off for the night.  The game runs like a dream (and my computer is below the recommended specs), the explosions and visuals look incredible, and the sound effects are amazing.  Jumping in the Magnum Opus, firing up the engine, and slamming on the gas is enough to give you an adrenaline rush worthy of a War Boy.

They really put a lot of thought into this title.

WITNESS ME!  9/10

reviewText: Well... after 21 hours, I must say picking up scrap and dismantling camps - got very repetitive. They story was short, not that thrilling and the hand-to-hand combat was a childs play without creativity just demanding alot of button mashing. I would really have liked to see more variation and tactics required in hand-to-hand combat. Throughout the wasteland I was dying for more interesting quests and events, but they are simply not there. The explosions and action though, are top notch. And the game runs solid as hell on PC. It's an easy buy for 20£, but not worth 50£. Maybie I'm just open-world spoiled after playing Witcher 3, but this game has little to discover between A and B once you scratch through the surface.\n\nEDIT: Worst part in my whole Mad Max time, was when I spent 3000 hard-earned for hours scrap on upgrading a Stronghold's stockpile to maximum level, just to find out its just a pure cosmetic upgrade and it didn't give me ♥♥♥♥ in return. Instead of buying nice car parts or upgrading Max I literally spent a hefty amount on not getting ♥♥♥♥, I mean seriously what the ♥♥♥♥ was that, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game developer design meets evil of its pure form? reviewText:
Mad Max is probably the single most, 'I'll just do one more mission - still playing many hours later' game ever. Time vanishes. What you thought was maybe forty-five minutes, was four hours. I think part of the reasoning behind this is because it's repetitive in every way. I am surprised it doesn't get more criticism for this. Everywhere just about looks the same. The camps which you clear are all similar. Scavenging destinations are all similar.

The really only parts that are not all similar are the main missions. However there are not many of those.

Mad Max has other issues too. The engine-exhaust noise of the car is diabolical. I wear headphones and it screams albeit mid pitched (not high pitched) almost all the way through. I play on speakers too and it's as bad. Only later when you get the V8 engine is car noise acceptable.

It is unfortunately nothing more than a long grind, and is possibly the grinder of all grinders. Salvage scrap, unlock upgrades, use scrap as currency to upgrade. From start to finish that is all you do.

It has plus points. It often looks good. Bosses are all the same technique: wait for charge, dodge, attack for a bit; repeat. In other words there is no googling every boss encounter because you can't work out what to do. Gameplay is straight-forward. In fact all the gameplay is relatively easy. It's filled out by there simply being masses of it.

Although I mark it 7/10 I could not in all honesty say to a friend, You must buy Mad Max". Meaning no recommendation. However if you are fully aware of its format
date: you will have fun maybe half the time playing it."

reviewText: Did you like Tomb Raider? What about RAGE? And possibly Batman? If you like all of those three games then why are you even reading this...go get it NOW!!! This is a game with a likeness to all three IMO. It has the same look and feel to Tomb Raider with very similar game play experience. You have plenty of neat little underground worlds to explore and if you dont want to go underground then mix it up like the Wombles did and go overground too. Why not try driving up to some deserted places like a crashed plane or sunken boat or deserted train stations and trains in the hills or far out in the desert. The combat is very satisfying with excellent effects and even better noises and bone crunching sounds. Visuals are fantastic on a high end rig. It has the same satisfying RAGE effect when driving a car. As in, you can blow stuff up...a lot. There are some great little upgrades you can add to the Magnum Opus car. These include flames coming out the side, spikes on the body to prevent enemies jumping on and boarding, a powerful shotgun, harpoon and rocket launcher (in essence) and some normal body and engine upgrades. You can have so much fun with the harpoon pulling building structures down, ripping wheels off cars or ripping a man out of his car and dragging hi, around like a rag doll! Combat and sound is very similar to Batman and the way it feels. Overall this was such a surprise for me this year and is easily in my top 3 games only behind GTA V at the moment. Wonderful experience and I am still no way near complete with 40 hours of game play! 10/10

reviewText:
It would be easy to nit-pick Mad Max to death for its repetitive design, flimsy plot, sometimes painfully slow upgrade progress, and Max’s pathetic little jump. However, when the chips are down you have a game that is just a lot of fun to play, even when you are doing the fairly mundane side tasks. The game plays well, runs well, and doesn’t make you worry about whether you should really be spending thirty minutes chasing down a convoy in place of going off to do the next story mission. Instead, it actively encourages you do deviate from the main path, and you will probably find yourself gleefully doing so, constantly getting distracted by scrap-transports, camps, convoys and scavenging locations; even when you tell yourself its finally time to drive to the next story quest marker.

Read Full Review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

As a side note, I'll mention that I probably enjoyed MM more than Far Cry 4, Shadow of Mordor and Arkham Knight which are all more critically acclaimed. The game is just wierdly, compulsively addicting and fun to play.

reviewText:
Okay, so lets get this out of the way to start with, yes, this game is a huge collection of fetch quests, however, it's what you do while fetching that makes this game so much fun.

A solid fighting mechanic, excellent driving combat, a great story and interesting characters in a nice open sandbox world.

Lots to find, upgrage and generally do, this game will keep you occupied for a good while if you decide to do the side quests, if you just want to blast through the main game (why would you want to do that?) then the game is considerably shorter.

reviewText:
After playing for 30 hours, Mad Max is everything I hoped it would be and then some. That being said, I have a hard time understanding why reviews have ranged from the 5 to 8.4 range. 96% positive reviews on Steam means gamers have spoken for themselves. With a cool combination of Fallout, Borderlands, Far Cry, and Just Cause, Mad Max has stunning visuals, engaging combat in-car and on foot, and a great variety of characters.

While I haven't found the story particularly enthralling, it is still fun. The open-world environment, however, is where this game truly excels. As I head towards an objective, I frequently find myself distracted doing other things, such as disarming a minefield with my trusty dog Dinki-Di, clearing out a camp, or being ambushed by a group of enemy vehicles. It is these types of fun distractions that make Mad Max shine.

Everything in this game is upgradeable. Fortresses can be upgraded to give Max refillls on Fuel, Ammo, Water, and Health. The Magnum Opus has millions of possible combinations, from colors and insignia to the body, to engines and other parts. These upgrades make a noticeable difference to the feeling of driving the car, as well as to the way it actually sounds. Max himself can be upgraded in two ways: by visiting Griffa to enhance health or a variety of other attributes, or by adding armor, etc. that gives Max a boost in combat.

I have not found the bleak, postapocalyptic landscape to be repetetive or dull. The graphics are extremely high quality, espcially with Nvidia SLI and AMD Crossfire support right out of the box. The sky and weather visuals are fantastic, especially when a tornado or huge sandstorm occur. Additionally, these storms never seem to be the same, with some looking like the lightning/tornado from Fury Road while others look like a sever haboob in New Mexico.

There are some things I have not enjoyed about the game, and which I feel should have been included right out of the box. Despite his reputation as a road warrior, Max is not able to jump over simple obstacles. While he can jump, he will often need to find the predetermined route into a stronghold, generally marked by yellow paint. Something else that has bothered me is the low quality of graphics in Jeet's stronghold. Avalanche seems to be going for a rising heat effect, but the result is blurry textures. Despite these flaws, the game is still very satisfying.

Driving is an absolute pleasure. As you upgrade your Magnum Opus, you won't want to fully upgrade everything. Putting a heavy ramming bar or armor on your car, for example, will lower your acceleration and handling, making the car less nimble. Upgrading your engine, tires, or suspension will have the opposite effect.

Hand-to-hand combat is both gritty and brutal, with Max using objects in the environment to beat his opponents to a pulp. Fans of the Arkham series will be familiar with the controls, but the combat still has a unique feel to it. Anyone can button mash their way through this game, but there are huge rewards for using the special combo moves available to max. Players who take the time to learn and practice these will find their satisfaction with the combat increases greatly. Additionally, Max can build up a fury meter to unleash Fury Mode, which greatly enhances his attacks and allows for special Fury finishes.

Mad Max doesn't break any new ground in the saturated open-world genre, but it is a rich, immersive game with fantastic graphics and satisfying combat. Reviews have been quite varied, but if you are looking for a new game to play, listen to the gamers themselves and pick up a copy of Mad Max for PC.

Verdict: 8.9/10
A few flaws diminish the experience somewhat, but this is still a AAA title worth investing many hours into.

reviewText:
It is a hell of a ride.

The game is definitely more than the sum of its parts, and it can be pretty rough in some parts, but man, what a damn ride.

The game's on foot combat is pretty much just doing a Batman/Sleeping Dogs thing. Not as fluid as either, and somehow less brutal than Sleeping Dogs's. It gets old. There are nice ways to avoid it, since  the shotgun is pretty much a end this fight" button

they  feel like puzzle platformers at times.

reviewText:
At the beginning I have to admit that Mad Max is very stereotypical game, contains a few unimportant bugs, the plot is not the best (but not the worst) and unfortunately the potential has not been excavated to the maximum which this open-world game totaly deserves.

But, you know what.. Let me introduce you seven fundamental reasons why the game forces you to play it!

1. Optimalization. What a perfect optimalization!
... forget on Batman´s epic fail. On the highest settings the game runs like a Swiss watch. Many thanks to Avalanche studios for really good job.

2. Wasteland. What a atmospheric wasteland!
... really big, really large and variable.

3. Details. What a impressive details!
... fortresses, various locations, points of interests and more.

4. Sandstorms. What a real sandstorms!
... I can´t remember better processed video games sandstorms. Maybe in Spec Ops: The Line, but in Mad Max sandstorm appears randomly in two variants.

5. Ride. What a rough ride!
... feeling of riding is really enjoyable. Not only in Magnum Opus.

6. Combat system. What a brutal combat system!
... simple but effective. You know his older and better brother from Arkham series.

7. Visualization. What a sexy visualization!
... nice graphics, effects of explosions, mentioned locations.

After 15 hours of gameplay, Mad Max caught a second wind, gets momentum and simply will not let you go. Despite the fact you´re doing the same thing all the time.

I´d like to support devs by purchase upcoming Just Casuse 3. They deserved it in times of terrible console ports.

reviewText: After managing to purchase for only £10.45 instead of the £34.99 pricetag and muddling through the graphical settings to fix the slowmo this game has been a delight. Guns, demolitions, Batman style fighting dynamics, a friendly dog, an overactive hunchback, sarcastic enemies, hugely upgradable vehicles driven at break-neck speeds over a post apocalyptical and beautifully rendered landscape, unbeleivable weather dynamics, an accurate starry night sky and the delight of dropping too far to twist your ankle and hobble for a few steps before regaining focus, are all part of the wonder that is this game. Add to the the graphical delight and DaVinci styled perfection to watch we have what is 500% better than the new movie was and takes us back to the wonder that was the original Mad Max movies within a modern timeframe. Purchase it when on sale or from another cheaper reputable vendor as the full price is a little rich. Otherwise 7 thumbs up.

reviewText:
Summary:
Mad Max is a collection of a variety of strengths and weaknesses that range all over the spectrum, and it really comes down to what kind of gamer you are. The game's strengths comes in short play sessions of an hour as the car combat is great with the use of the Harpoon, and the strong characterization of Chumbucket as he comments about what's going around you will keep you interested. It's got a great variety of level design, and the PC performance is exactly what you'd want for a PC game in 2015: It runs smooth and can get the best out of the top-end systems. But on the flip side, ground combat doesn't play to its own strengths as the camera becomes a major problem in the counter based fighting, and frankly, the game has a lot of repetitive elements to it and can really feel like the gameplay has been extended to the point of breaking. You get your moneys worth, but in the end, Mad Max is the perfect game to get on a discount: there's nothing that forces your hand to get the game right now.

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://youtu.be/wEkJnV8_XMo

Lists:

+:
The car combat is reasonable, with the harpoon being fun to use on almost everything. In fact, just the Harpoon alone at times makes for some chaotic fun.
Chumbucket, the mechanic, shines as the most interesting character by far, with his religious devotion to automobiles and his excitement about all things combustion.
Base Level Design keeps things fresh over the long haul. Reuse of elements are done in a way that it never is noticed.
The world is beautiful in particular with the sand locations.
Character design takes advantage of the license in terms of visuals and voice acting.
Power comes in the name of upgrades, and opens up combat and options to a considerable degree.
The amount of hours you can get out of the game is high and has a bang for buck.
-:
Missed story elements that really could have taken the game to another level, overall the narrative is poor and doesn't do well with the license.
Ground combat doesn't have enough variety to it, and doesn't understand the strengths of the system in place. The camera is a major problem.
Focus on “realism” can hurt the game at times, with it hurting gameplay pacing in terms of naturally taking advantage of the open world.
Repetitive nature of tasks really becomes more of a chore. While there's a lot to do, there's a lot of the same thing to do.
Ending actually fell a little bit flat for me, despite others liking it. Very minor.
voteText: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Mad Max is the dirty big trashy sister of the Mordor series, it plays very similar to Shadows of Mordor minus the Parkour, but that isn't really a bad thing.  The game itself plays mostly without any hitches,  I had a few minor issues and one random crash through-out the entire playthrough, whilst I wouldn't say this game is perfect by any means and does get repetitive after a while, but it is something worth playing if you enjoy post apocalyptic open world driving/fighting games.

Personally, I would have liked to have more varition of the activities and more bases to conquer, but for the the price I paid it was a really good deal for the amount of time I've spent playing and enjoying the game.    Now, there are some points to be made here, the game does have glitches and bugs, especially with defense which sometimes significantly bugs requiring you to reset equipment to get the stat 'working' again,  and the cars handling sometimes is strange - very easy to spin-out or lose control of the car and crash into one immoveable object in a large open world...the game loves to do that for some reason.

Because of the cars handling, I'd really recommend playing this on a gamepad, especially the driving portions of the game which make up a large part of the game.   Overall, I still recommend this game even though it has a few short-comings.

reviewText: TL;DR - 2015's Game of the Year\n\nI'll start by saying that I knew nothing about Mad Max before jumping into this game. From what I can tell, I didn't have to. I didn't plan on focusing on the story anyway because I was purely looking for gameplay. Holy ♥♥♥♥, did it deliver. If you thought Rockstar put a lot of detail into GTA V....Avalanche put more thought and care into this game than Rockstar could ever dream of. (for example, when you're looting an area it will tell you when everything has been looted and if you're missing anything. As someone who plays games to find EVERYTHING, this made me very happy). First off, it's an amazing port (as long as you have updated drivers) aside from the menu controls on keyboard/mouse. They seem to have their querks, but it's nothing too bad. It performs great and I only encountered one crash and that's because my drivers weren't updated. The audio struggles a bit on Windows 10, but it's nothing major at all. The combat is very Arkham-ish but that's okay with me because it works and it feels good. I personally didn't even expect hand-to-hand combat, but there you go. The driving will take some getting used to; at least until you get your car upgraded and then the car handles beautifully. The vehicle combat can be a bit tricky early on, but here's a tip - level your harpoon as often as you can. You'll use that more than anything else (at least I do). There's plenty of map to explore, too. At the time of writing this review, I'm almost 9 hours into the game and I have only done roughly 4-5 story missions. To conclude, this game is beautiful and you should get it at all costs. My only problem is that Warner Bros. were involved with this game...but thank you, Avalanche, for another great title that IS NOT broken. I'm looking at you, Arkham Knight...

reviewText:
My name is Max.

PROS:

+ great graphics
+ optimization
+ the wasteland
+ sheetloads of collectibles
+ the magnum opus

CONS:

- race missions
- plot

Paradoxically, the game's weakest spot is the driving.
Enjoyable as hell while roaming through the emptiness of the wastelad.
Painful and clunky while completing story missions and some of the side quests.
If you appreciate post-apo, open world games, it's a no-brainer.

Personally, I hate all types of games which include driving vehciles.
This time around, I really had a blast trespassing the desolate landscape.
If you don't feel like driving, you can always complete the game on foot.
Good luck with that.

reviewText:
After putting 50+ hours into this game and pretty much doing all that I can, I have to say that it was worth what I paid. The reviews online that complain about all the fun things you can do in game seems to punish you and make you NOT want to play the game are from people who havent unlocked any of the upgrades for the most part. Yes flying off high cliffs or even small jumps will heavily damage your car when you first start. Yes slamming into cars full speed or walls will make the Magnum Opus explode fairly quickly as well. When enemy cars hit you from the sides or the rear yes you get damaged very easily.

So what do you do? Play the game and start to unlock upgrades. There is alot to do in game from looting camps for scrap, car bodies, unique cars, and car upgrades. Alot of collectables that give history of the down fall of man and destruction of the world. The people you interact with are as they shouldbe all on the ragged edge no hope completly untrusting....at first. When you get to your first stronhold its little more that a hole in the ground with nothing to help you other than a place to store all your cars you start to collect. The first thing id recommed doing when you can start to upgrade your strongholds is seek out each of the parts required to make the, gas tank, water collector, ammo table (in some cases this will happen as you complete story or a wasteland mission), maggot farm, scrap pallet, and scrap gathering team.

The various things you can do include races for Crow, attacking camps (doing this will put wastelanders in them that give you free scrap at diffrent intervals in game), wastleland encounters that range from intel on camps, to free scrap, Legenday encounters giving you much longer missions to do. On this not alot of the encounters are avaliable at the start many others will unlock as you do story and wasteland missions.

Combat in your Magnum Opus is pretty stale at the start. Harpoon doors, rip them off, then harpoon the drivers, you can shoot the fuel tanks for instant kill, blow out the tires and ramming the cars is also another way to take them out. After you get the thunderpoon upgrade to blow up cars, upgrade the harpoon to rip the wheels off, get the flamers for burning the cars on the sides of you, and of course upgrade the bumper to do more ramming damage its alot more fun. When you get access to the sniper rifle you can only use it from the car but you can thin enemy ranks and blow up camp defenses pretty easily with it. I reccomend killing warcriers ASAP they make melee combat a real pain if the get everyone amped up increasing there damage and attack speed.

As far as defense in the car goes adding body armor and boarding spikes is the way to go. No other upgrades in relation do defense.

Ok on to melee combat. At first it will feel alot like just block, attack, block, attack, over and over......and it is. After you start to upgrade max you can truly get to having fun with diffrent combos, finishers, takedowns, usings shivs and melee weapons. Shivs break after 1 use, you start being able to only carry shiv, your starter shotgun only has one shot before you need to reload so only use them both when you really need to. After a few upgrades you can carry more shivs have a shotgun with up to 4 barrels and can carry many more shivs and alot more ammo.

Suviving in the wastes and finding water is not TOO hard to get after you get your first strong hold up and running with all the upgrades along with fuel and ammo. You can get a full reload of everything about every 15 mins. After you unlock multiple strong holds you can jump back and forth to stay replenished very easily.

The story is good and really starts to explain why max is so messed up mentally, hearing voices, and makes you really feel for Max. I wont go into what happens to ruin the story for you but it is well done.

I would like to see some extra areas added to the game like Bullet Farm or the Citadel so mabey WB's will release some DLC's with them in it if we are lucky and this game does well. Thats my only real complaint about this game.

Thats about it I hope you got somthing useful out of this review and enjoy playing Mad Max.

As far as defense in the car goes adding body armor and boarding spikes is the way to go. No other upgrades in relation do defense.

Ok on to melee combat. At first it will feel alot like just block, attack, block, attack, over and over......and it is. After you start to upgrade max you can truly get to having fun with diffrent combos, finishers, takedowns, usings shivs and melee weapons. Shivs break after 1 use, you start being able to only carry shiv, your starter shotgun only has one shot before you need to reload so only use them both when you really need to. After a few upgrades you can carry more shivs have a shotgun with up to 4 barrels and can carry many more shivs and alot more ammo.

Suviving in the wastes and finding water is not TOO hard to get after you get your first strong hold up and running with all the upgrades along with fuel and ammo. You can get a full reload of everything about every 15 mins. After you unlock multiple strong holds you can jump back and forth to stay replenished very easily.

The story is good and really starts to explain why max is so messed up mentally, hearing voices, and makes you really feel for Max. I wont go into what happens to ruin the story for you but it is well done.

I would like to see some extra areas added to the game like Bullet Farm or the Citadel so mabey WB's will release some DLC's with them in it if we are lucky and this game does well. Thats my only real complaint about this game.

Thats about it I hope you got somthing useful out of this review and enjoy playing Mad Max.

reviewText: Mad Max is ultimately a quite solid sandbox game, with some flaws. The driving controls, at least on keyboard seem a tad bit off, I tended to just spin out on the most innocuous terrain. Also enemies tend to cheap shot you during execution moves which just feels cheap. There's a lot of collectibles to find and while I think they could have upped their value exploration is still worthwhile because they don't repeat layouts for camps and scavenger locations, Elder Scrolls this is not. The atmosphere is really good as well. Writing is pretty cliche and not good though, but Chumbucket, your hunchback mechanic is nicely written. It also lays the grimdark on a little bit thick, which is rather glaring considering that the movies aren't. Mad Max is one of those games that never truly achieves greatness though, it could have really been enhanced by stuff like Shadow of Mordor’s Nemesis System. (I have no idea why they didn’t seeing is that WB published both.) Regardless if you’re looking for a good sandbox game, Mad Max will definitely deliver and while it’s not PERFECT IN EVERY WAY, it’s not MEDIOCRE as the reviewers are saying.

reviewText: I stand on top of a burned hill, watching the sun move across the sky. The sound of motors fading in and out in the distance, a zealous hunchback rambling on in the back seat of my all important four-wheeled conveyance. I wait for the sun to go down over the course of minutes, pondering the vast wasteland before me. It’s a quiet and peaceful moment, which is striking in a game filled with screaming war boys and magnificent explosions. Sometimes the best parts of an open world game come between missions, when the mechanics and controls fade away and you are just in a new place beautifully rendered before you. Mad Max has its flaws, but its wastes are highly suited for wandering the roads in search of excitement, and the game does a great job of gradually making the player understand the titular road warrior.\n\nWant to know more? My full review is now up for all to see over at TechRaptor! http://techraptor.net/content/mad-max-review-praise-angel-combustion

reviewText:
Even though I haven't finished the game yet, I've seen enough of it to put my thoughts in writing.

Mad Max is pure bliss.

The first thing you'll notice is, of course, how absolutely gorgeous it looks. This is one of the best-looking games ever made, and it performs flawlessly even on middling hardware.

The sound design matches the visual quality and enhances the wasteland's hostile atmosphere.

Melee combat is heavily inspired by the likes of the Arkham series and Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, which to me is a good thing, but some may find overly simplistic.

But obviously what sets this game apart from other open-world action titles is vehicular combat, and it's as fun and enjoyable as you'd expect from a game set in the Max Max universe. Your car - or should I say, the Magnum Opus" - itself is a weapon (with which you can ram and grind enemy vehicles)
date: but as you progress in the story you'll equip it with a grappling gun
recommended: a sniper rifle and a makeshift rocket launcher
hoursPlayed: making it the ultimate dispenser of death and destruction.\n\nThere is
voteText: however
helpfulPercent: a distinct lack of motorcycles and larger
votesHelpful: truck-sized "war rigs"
votesTotal: such as the ones seen in Road Warrior and the recent Fury Road.\n\nOpen-world games have been criticized lately for excessive reliance on inconsequential side-missions and collectibles
votesFunny: something that has been referred to as the "Ubisoft school of open-world games". Mad Max has side-missions
commentsCount: collectibles
column16: strongholds
column17: camps: the whole nine yards. But none of them feel like fodder. Every little place you visit has its own unique design and backstory
column18: giving a sense of immersion that is sadly quite rare these days.\n\nThroughout your adventures you'll be assisted by Chumbucket
column19: the horribly disfigured hunchback mechanic. I won't call him a sidekick because he's every bit as important as Max himself
column20: and is really the heart of the game.\n\nAnd he's just one of many interesting characters you'll meet. Friends and foes are all equally well designed and voice-acted. It helps that the dialogue is great
column21: too.\n\nAnyway
column22: there's so much else I could say
column23: so let me be perfectly clear and be done with it: this is not just a recommendation. It's a ringing endorsement.\n\nBuy Mad Max."

reviewText:
To be honest i was sceptical at first, another movie licensed title hits the gaming world and i sincerely hoped that mad max would not join the rest of the terrible titles the post movie game adaption pile of death. Humbley and happily Mad Max will avoid being classified as another movie licensed failure but instead of one of the more successful and sound examples of not onyl a good movie licensed game but a good game in general.

Mad Max seemed humble and a little slow at first, until i came across the major plot sequence and central focus of the game. Customising and building your very own wasteland beast. Not only do you get to customise a pre-existing frame of a vehicle, but have the option of many different vehicles, and on top of that many vehicle body, engine and wheel modifications, that combined in different arrangements make deadly combinations to tear other vehicles apart. This is without a doubt Mad Max's strongest feature, alongside its gritty and earthy combat system in both hand to hand and vehicular. The hand to hand combat feels viseral and real, hitting someone in the face with a wrench makes a satisfying sound, and a believable reaction. The vehicular combat, can be tough but damn is it satisfying, running a car off a road into a rocky out crop and see it break into pieces and blow into a flaming heap of spoilt chrome.

Mad Max is a solid game, with a great level of optimization across the board, and great gameplay. Its only setback in my Lore loving eyes of the mad max world is its realtively weak Storyline and weak central protagonist, in both voice acting and overall appearance. All in all, this game is truly exceptional and i give it a high recommendation.

Blessed are the melee weapons and finishing moves: for they righteously kick butt.

Blessed are the chain kills: for they shall be called the Extenders of Fury.

Blessed are the enemy convoys which may be crippled and humbled for righteousness' sake: for in them is a warehouse of goodies.

Blessed is the Angel Max, when Warboys shall revile him, and attack him, and shall say all manner of evil against him as they charge, for he'll wet the salty dust with their blood.

Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for smooth and detailed is this PC version: for so botched they the optimizers which came before it.

reviewText:
I will admittedly say that because this game was inspired by a movie, I was half expecting it to be a flop... I was pleasantly proven wrong.

This game provides a nice open-world experience with plenty to do and a fun combat system that makes running around doing things that seem tedious actually quite fun.

The story is relatively minimal, and the way the game lays out your objectives" leaves a lot of interpretation up to the player as to how you go about completing your missions. Many missions will have criteria that must be met for you to start (such as previous objectives
recommended: etc.) that will force you to go out and complete tasks in order to earn those upgrades and progress further into the story.\n\nThe game is based very heavily on driving
hoursPlayed: specifically
voteText: your very own car that you upgrade with you like a man and his dog. The car will become your primary source of combat
helpfulPercent: means of travel
votesHelpful: as well as the ability to reach new areas. One aspect that I thought was pretty intuitive was the introduction of the fuel gauge-- that's right
votesTotal: your car has to run on actual fuel. At first
votesFunny: it seems like the fuel supply is low
commentsCount: restricting your ability to go anywhere and do anything
column16: but there are numerous ways to increase the efficiency as well as find spare fuel all over the place (you can also get special projects in each stronghold that will give you an instant full tank)
column17: so I never actually had an issue keeping the tank full.\n\nThe gameplay and the controls are pretty well implemented
column18: following gameplay style like the Arkham series and Shadow of Mordor (both WB productions)
column19: and with the detail of Just Cause 3 (same dev). The only complaint that I'd have about the gameplay
column20: is the jumping... your character can jump
column21: but not more than a foot of the ground. You rarely have to use it
column22: that it just seems like it's there to keep some semblance of realism. It's more of a gripe in that it somewhat restricts your ability to go "anywhere".\n\nThe music is also very well set to the game
column23: it provides an ambience that puts you right in to a savage wasteland with some creepy inhabitants
column24:
and never feels like it gets in the way.

The menu system is pretty comprehensive but I will give a summary of my pros/cons that will address a few quirks I noticed.

tl;dr

Pros:
+ Fluid gameplay mechanics
+ Interesting combat system (both on foot and in car)
+ There's lots of content that can be accessed before completing major missions
+ Upgrading your car and customizing the builds are satisfying to your type of play (speed
column25: attack
column26: weaponry
column27:
etc.)
+ Fuel is plentiful (you just have to be observant)
+ Map and fast-travel system is very useful
+ Engaging story and fun missions
+ You can cheat in death runs (races)

Cons:
- The main side content is just different takes on the same few concepts (which can get repetitive quickly)
- Finding large quantities of scrap is annoying
- The game can "hold your hand" in places (look for yellow everywhere to indicate where you can go)
- The menu interface can be annoying when you find a new part and you have to switch back and forth to effectively compare two parts (hood ornaments mostly)
- The jumping mechanic is just filler

Overall

reviewText: Everyone's already probably heard that Mad Max combines elements from Far Cry 2 & Batman Arkham, while being the spiritual parent to Borderlands. I liked all of these games, but the combat and cars reminds me the most of the excellent Sleeping Dogs. Gameplay is solid. On the ground you can hold your own but you're no superhero. Even the weakest enemies can overpower you if they are too numerous or your reactions are too slow. The best part is the cars. Three of the initial 5 car bodies are reminiscent of the classic Interceptor, so you can play the campaign in a heavily customized ride that feels" right. Max's legendary set of wheels are automatically unlocked after completion of the campaign. Depending on your level of devotion to this world you can take your time with the story or just putter around exploring the barren landscape to hunt for treasure and fight bandits. If you are a completionist Mad Max could be a grind
date: particularly the vehicle combat. To accomplish all challenges
recommended: it is recommmended to avoid clearing areas totally to keep enemies spawning. Movie adaptation games are usually in the "miss" category of hit or miss
hoursPlayed: so I'm very happy how Mad Max turned out. Being fond of the original film & the excellent Fury Road made this experience all the more enjoyable.\nedit: 100% after 80 hours roughly."

reviewText:
Superb addition to the Mad Max universe & a wonderful game.

This game proves that a Warner Brothers produced game can be wonderful on PC. It's a solid PC port & that's good to say. Unlike the latest iteration of Batman this game offers virtually everything you want from a console to PC port. Full mouse and keyboard integration, endless graphical settings including refresh rates of up to 144Hz on multiple resolutions all the way down to 640p.

The game is stunning to explore and enjoy & so far (10 hours in) it has kept my attention. While there could be more activities to do & the looting is somewhat repetitive at this stage, the storyline is as you'd expect from a Mad Max game.

If you're familiar with the franchise, this game is a solid entry, not quite as rocking as Fury Road was as a movie, but very remiscent of that title.

If you aren't familiar with the franchise, this game will open up the world of the movies to you. Oil is scarce, cars are becoming a thing of the past, they are weapons, a show of power, an extension of your last remaining remnants of humanity. Which is more important to you? Water or Oil? You're constantly reminded of this throughout the game as you are in the movies.

It's an apocolypse that's all too real. It turns people insane & one which unsurprisingly could happen in the not too distant future.

reviewText:
This is a good game… but also not a good game. How do I explain? Quick thoughts below:

Just a line on the graphics and the performance of the game, both are excellent, it is a lovely ,looking game and it runs flawlessly (bodes well for Just Cause 3), now onto the game itself.

Mad Max about 3 things, Driving, Fighting and Upgrading your car, everything else in the game is merely a vehicle (no pun intended) to allow you to do one of those 3 things. Tasks in Mad Max are repetitive with copy and paste quests and objectives as you explore the map, which some people, including myself would describe as busy work, or padding, or even grinding if I were to be harsh.

Thing is though, they are all tasks which let you do three things;  Almost always you’ll first be driving around meaning you’ll be blowing up, ramming and dismantling other cars with your harpoon gun whilst hurtling through an apocalyptic Australian outback complete with dried up seabed’s and places to explore and scavenge.

You'll then get to where you're going and you'll be Fighting, usually against multiple opponents in an Arkham style fighting system with brutal animations and sound effects, Max isn't a well-trained ninja but a brawler, handy in a fight and able to look after himself and that really comes across.

After that you'll have earned some scrap to upgrade your car, as well as Max, buying new engines, tyres, armour, weapons, special moves etc etc.

And... rinse then repeat. It is this pattern over and over with some slight variance here and there for story missions. Whether you like this game or not comes down to how much you enjoy those 3 things, and for me, I really did. That's why I played it for 41 hours and finished a lot of the game before doing the story.

Of course it isn’t totally as simple as that, there are other things for you to do and even the above 3 activities are wrapped up in narrative driven reasoning or have a tagged on objective, but trust me when I say you’ll always be driving, fighting and upgrading. That is the meat and potatoes of Mad Max.

Those 3 mechanics might not work for some and therefore they would bounce right off it and think it is an average or even a poor game. Not in my eyes, one of the most enjoyable games in 2015 for me and I hope you think the same should you give it a go.

reviewText:
Mad Max is an open world game that puts you in desolated post-apocalyptic world of Mad Max universe.

The thing about Mad Max game is that it goes with a play safe" approach to everything - from world and quests to mechanics design.
There's not a one new thing in this game - everything that you'll find here has already been made in pretty much the same way by a lot of companies (say
date: Ubisoft's open world games).\nBut don't take that as a bad thing. On the contrary - if you do like open world game
recommended: or if you like Mad Max universe - you might easily find yourself enjoying this game (just as I did).\n\nIt's true - there's nothing new in it. But all existing things are executed so well
hoursPlayed: you can almost see the competence of Avalanche Studios oozing from every polygon.\nThe combat is very similar to batman/shadow of mordor combat
voteText: but has a little less variety (again
helpfulPercent: probably because of that "play safe" approach).\nThe towers from Ubisoft games were replaced with balloons that you don't have to climb
votesHelpful: just fly up (they are pretty awesome vistas though).\nCamps are camps - you either have to kill anyone inside or blow stuff up to "capture" them. Sadly
votesTotal: that's all you can do with them
votesFunny:
no additional bonuses are given from them.
And that actually goes for most of the side activities - all of them feel kinda useless (unless you are grinding for that next car part).
I wish Avalanche Studios had more time (or freedom?) to try and go crazy with this game - there's so much potential and possibilities of fun things in there.

And then there are those little details everywhere - like burning send left from fuel flying out of your old car's exhaust. Or like storms (that are very rare)
commentsCount: but damn terrifying to be in.\nOr like the explosions that looks absolutely gorgeous. And capture mode that makes exploding things and making screenshots very fun (I wish there was a way to get into it using a hotkey
column16: not through pause menu though).\nVoice acting's pretty good too. Oh
column17: and don't forget the optimization - game runs perfectly well on just about any config that's close to recommended one.\n\nSo
column18: to sum it up - if you are OK with your typical (I just can't force myself to say "classic") open world game in Mad Max universe - go for it. It's pretty good
column19:
just more of the same good open world stuff in another universe.

Watch the video for more detailed look here:
https://youtu.be/L_Uo3h3nnyE"

reviewText:
Short but sweet.
Story was bad, didn't care for anyone in it, not even Chumbucket. Wish the dog were more involved. Ending sucked too.
Gameplay is tight. Car combat is sweet, combat is fluid, upgrades are fun and actually make a huge difference. Kinda OP that you can change your car parts on the fly, really trivializes otherwise dangerous encounters.
Overall, good time-sink, great for fans of the franchise. Get it on sale.

reviewText:
Superb addition to the Mad Max universe & a wonderful game.

This game proves that a Warner Brothers produced game can be wonderful on PC. It's a solid PC port & that's good to say. Unlike the latest iteration of Batman this game offers virtually everything you want from a console to PC port. Full mouse and keyboard integration, endless graphical settings including refresh rates of up to 144Hz on multiple resolutions all the way down to 640p.

The game is stunning to explore and enjoy & so far (10 hours in) it has kept my attention. While there could be more activities to do & the looting is somewhat repetitive at this stage, the storyline is as you'd expect from a Mad Max game.

If you're familiar with the franchise, this game is a solid entry, not quite as rocking as Fury Road was as a movie, but very remiscent of that title.

If you aren't familiar with the franchise, this game will open up the world of the movies to you. Oil is scarce, cars are becoming a thing of the past, they are weapons, a show of power, an extension of your last remaining remnants of humanity. Which is more important to you? Water or Oil? You're constantly reminded of this throughout the game as you are in the movies.

It's an apocolypse that's all too real. It turns people insane & one which unsurprisingly could happen in the not too distant future.

reviewText:
This is the only game in the last 5 years that I bought at full price that was actually worth paying for. If you're wondering if you should wait for a steam sale to get this game, don't. It really is worth sixty dollars.

IS IT AWESOME?

If you're a Mad Max fan, you've been waiting your entire life for this game. ♥♥♥♥ing everything is in it, down to the actual brand of dog food that they ate in the first Max movie.

I'M NOT A MAD MAX FAN, IS THIS STILL COOL?

Okay... So do you remember the best part of Borderlands 2? That one desert zone with the white trash clans, and the bandit trucks running around, and you could hijack convoys and steal loot chests from them? Imagine someone just took that zone, made it an entire game, and then filled that game full of hilarious toys for you to murder australian skinheads with.

ALL THE CRITICS HATE IT.

Yea, and Kojima's next sixty dollar movie about an old one eyed dude in a bandana is gonna get editor's choice and game of the year. The difference is someone is gonna pay those ♥♥♥♥s to like Metal Gear, nobody paid them to like Mad Max. Read all these reviews from people who bought it, the fan response to the game is unanimously positive.

I'M A MAD MAX FANBOY, CAN I GET ALL THE ICONIC MAD MAX ♥♥♥♥?

Yes. The game starts out like every Max movie ever- You're driving along minding your own business and then some dudes ♥♥♥♥ up your ♥♥♥♥ and wreck your car, and you're ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because your car is badass. But it doesn't take long for you to get back all your original Max gear. You always have a shotgun, you can choose a Ford Falcon XB body to be your car, and you unlock the leather jacket pretty early.  Also, the reward for beating story mode is an unlock for the pristine V8 interceptor completely canon from the films.

I'M NOT A MAD MAX FANBOY, WHY SHOULD I GIVE A ♥♥♥♥?

Even if you're not a Max fanboy this game is just fun as ♥♥♥♥. It should be called NEED FOR SPEED: PSYCHOPATHS. It's an Australian murder car simulator. There are hotrod driving skinheads all over the desert and your job is to run them over with flamethrowers, harpoon guns, and spiked wheels. You can rip the doors off of cars and harpoon guys out of the driver seat and pull them through the windshield. You can ram the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything until it explodes. When guys jump on your car, you can just blow them into meat confetti with your shotgun. The people who made this game are truly sick. It's WONDERFUL.

You will chase down and murder a dozen human beings and blow up their cars just for the sake of grabbing a can of dog food, some shotgun shells, and a hood ornament.

WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥, NO MULTIPLAYER?

This game should never have multiplayer. The amount of death and destruction one person in one car already causes in this game is beautifully horrendous. If they let us all into the world in our murder cars we'd all be harpooning each other and exploding. The devs at Avalanche would be arrested and put on trial for war crimes.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic.

I have said that I will never again buy an EA exclusive title or an UBIsoft Port because of all the dishonest and incompetent things they have done in the past. Well, the door swings both ways. After Shadow of Mordor and now Mad Max, I will make it my business to buy as many Warner Brothers products as I can. Seriously, they show respect to the industry and this game is yet another living testimony to that fact. Avalanche studios (the developer) has outdone themselves and Warner Brothers (the publisher) had the respect of the industry to publish it in this fashion. Excellent work.

So why pay money for this title?
1)	The design is conducive to the player having a lot of varied and dynamic fun. Driving, exploring, running, fist fighting, knife fighting, car rallying, hot-air balloon riding, sliding, talking, car upgrading, character progression…you name it, this game has got it. The best thing is, it all comes together seamlessly.
2)	The detail in the world is amazing and the attention and respect of the lore is equally worthy of praise. You fight someone, there’s a complete description of how that character or enemy fits into the world. You see a base, landmark or resources centre, there’s a complete description of the site’s function and strategic significance. You pick up so-much-as a flash-light, and there is a complete run down of the object. Brilliant detail.
3)	The dialogue and voice acting is top-notch. I have enjoyed the characters and cut-scenes in this game more than the film on which the game is based (and I loved Fury Road). The genius incorporation of Mad Max discourse and specific idiomatic terms makes you feel part of the world.
4)	The graphics are great. Not perfect but amazing non-the-less. The fire, explosions, and smoke effects are nothing short of brilliant. It runs on my system at 80 frames per second with no lag while running fraps and Xsplit in the background. Amazing optimisation.
5)	The driving is extremely cinematic as the combination of graphics, sound design and game-flow produce extremely stimulating encounters.
6)	It’s a big game. You really do feel like you are embarking on an epic adventure and you are getting plenty of content for your money.

Bravo to the folks at Warner Brothers. Bravo you amazing game designers at Avalanche Studios. The only criticism I can possibly muster involves the voice actor for Max. He does a truly great job but his voice is a little too deep. Seriously, that is as negative as I can get and I append the qualifier that the voice actor still does an amazing job within his scope of ability – not his fault he has a deep voice.

Keep it up WB!

reviewText: I am pleasantly suprised how optimized this game is. I'm running a GTX 760 2GB card and yet I am able to maintain a constant 60fps with everything maxed out. ON A WB GAME at that. So far, I'm loving the atmosphere and supreme graphical fidelity of this title. Impressive voice acting and believable wasteland helps to immerse you into this apocolyptic world. Fluid combat brings memory to recent title MD: Shadow of Mordor and the widely known Batman games. This combat system is effective and more games should implement it as long as they pour a little of their own flavor into the pot.\n\nI haven't played too much yet but I definitely wanted to let people know that the game is worth buying so far if you wanted confirmation on optimization. Well, I'm about to dive back in, pulling myself away to write this short review was hard enough as it was.

reviewText: You play as the Australian version of Jesus who roams the Outback shanking bogans, stealing their stuff, and welding it to his car. He also eats maggots and gives water to thirsty peasants, because he's wasteland Jesus. Car customization is good, car combat is good, graphics are good, optimization is good, it's all just good mang. Melee combat is a bit ♥♥♥♥♥ but the animations and sound effects are nice. My favourite thing about the game is the desolate post-apocalyptic desert aesthetic and atmosphere; ♥♥♥♥ing ironic when a Mad Max game reminds me more of Fallout than a Fallout game. Now I need to watch the movies.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a game set in a world where careless waste, political terrorism, and general public unhappiness was permitted to boil over into full out rage, leaving the world a scarred, barren wasteland.
The world of Mad Max, is completely different, from the world you and I know. The world you delve into in this game, is ruled by violence, governed by strife, fueled by crude oil, gasoline, and rig job cars built for war, and the only living one does here, is a filthy, misserable, dry-mouthed and perpually starving one, but in this world, simply being alive is a luxury few can claim to own. In this world, a car is required to be anyone or anything, including alive, and nothing but death, and dry bones await those with no car to carry them over the seemingly endless dunes of sand, which have long since covered the unfortunate would-be's who tried to survive before them. Money is worthless here, little more than tinder. The only thing people care about here, the only thing one could safely call 'money'. Is scrap metal. Piles of it, things used to create more cars, and therefore, more survival.

The game is set in an obscure area in future America, seemingly in an old refinery town long since lost to the sands of sorrow. The only thing still standing, and furiously customized to grow to a sorry, pathetic excuse for a community, is Gastown, a large refinery that still stands and pumps gasoline, natural gas, and oil from the ground below at reckless speeds to fuel the governing group of lunatics, psychopaths, and bestial, carnage worshipping madmen: The War Boys of Scrotus. Much of the game happens in the southern outskirts of this town, a small 'oasis' that, upon arrival in it, seems more like a cruel joke, this area is a small space in the middle of what seems to be an endless expense of send dunes, extending for as long and as far and as unforgivingly constant as the eye can see no matter how high into the sky you go(with airballoon included). Wastelanders and Madmen alike refer to this ocean of endless death and barren dryness that surrounds their homeland as The Big Nothing"

reviewText:
Let me just say this game is really not that bad. In fact , its the best movie-tie-in game  I've ever played which you really do feel like Max on a post-apocalyptic wasteland . My opinion about this game is like a tug of war and it really does have its highs and lows .

Highs
Beautiful setting - Although it really is a wasteland , it doesn't feel that repettive . The game developers try there best to make the experience of driving around the wasteland actually more entertaining with each region have a unique character to it . Alogn with change of weather and nighttime.
Gritty Combat - Akrham-y combat mechanic without the cool gadgets and kungfu moves  . When your playing Max , the only combat experience is your two fists and boy it really does feel good suckerpunch a godamn war boy in face .
World - If you like the crazyness of the franchise, then this game gives that same lust of insanity and madness that we all crave with specific tribes with there own culture and beliefs . Typical Mad Max trope to survive by scavenging scraps , food and water is also the main theme for this game.
Car mechanics and Combat - The soul of this whole franchise and this game is the car combat . Its basically Pimp-My-Ride with your sidekick Chumbucket as xzibbit . Car Combat is as entertaining as it gets especially when you high tail a convoy all by yourself , rampaging through dozens of cars jsut to get that head ornament as the cherry on top of your sweet Magnum Opus .
Story - This is probably in the middle but like any Mad MAx movie . It is kept pretty simple with a clear objective

Lows
The Grind - This is the bad apart about customizing your car , to upgrade the best parts for it you have to start doing small missions by destorying camps and clearing the region which is a chore especially if majority are almost the same . This is what BREAKS ME for this game , its tiring &repetitive and I had to take a long rest from playing this game before going at it again .
THE DOG IS USELESS - At first when I saw the dog at the first part of the game you'll be like  hell yeah
date: Dog partner in wasteland just like Road Warrior " NOOOOOOPPPEEEE . The only thing that dog does in this game is to sniff out mines and there is no reward other then clearing the region out of doing this . It is menial and boring as heck .\nMini-Boss are the SAME- THroughout parts of each region theres a mini-boss camps for you to beat to get that sweet paintjob on your crib but my god is it boring . Each Mini-boss has the same moves
recommended: body and mask and it is repetitive and lazy which makes the game almost a cakewalk .\nVerdict\nOverall
hoursPlayed: its really not a bad game but for those who enjoy a collectathon with a same-y sandbox gameplay with added car combat and collecting while experiencing post-apocalyptic franchise then you would love this game but for me it felt like chore ."

reviewText:
So let's start off with the good bits.

The port is very good, I can run this on high on my not-so-up-to-date computer quite smoothly, with frame drops only now and then which don't impact the game much. The animation is smooth, such as when Max swaps positions with Chumbucket, his entering and leaving a vehicle as well as the flow of his attacks just feels genuine. There are a lot of video settings combined with the fact that the visuals itself looks pretty good and the presence of rebindable keys is even better. However, there is no toggle aim for those who like it, though this game does not feature very much shooting in general which does not really impact the gameplay for me, despite my personal preference.

Now for the bad points.

The gameplay in general is quite stale and at times quite pointless. The ground combat is its weakest point, and I give it a 1/10. It largely resembles the Batman fighting style where you spam left click while waiting for counter attack indicators or non-counterable indicators at which you then just dodge. With the attacks, you have light and heavy, but most of the time you end up just spamming light attacks as you cannot dodge while in the middle of charging up a heavy swing, which means heavy swings are reduced to largely finishing off opponents or when there are no undefendable attackers. And in the end, regardless of whether there are defendable or undefendable opponents, it's still a left click spam fest with very little thought input. With an added note that boss fights are exactly the same, just one big guy instead of many smaller guys. One word: Tedium.

The car combat was also quite uninspiring. It had potential, but the biggest problem was that it ended up being a Harpoon Simulator 2015... on land. Instead of harpooning fish or sharks, you just harpoon buildings and people (in cars and out of them). Ramming into other cars while driving is pretty difficult, while also taking substantially longer to kill opponents as opposed to just harpooning them; though damage greatly increases if you were to run directly into them while boosting. So the easiest way is to just harpoon the people out of the vehicles which leaves you to freely destroy/ram stationary vehicles which explode into meagre amounts of scrap.

Now some general problems.

Fuel is something that's used to run your car (obviously), and you'd think in a post-apocalyptic world it would be a very valuable resource... except it isn't when you can basically find an unlimited supply of jerry cans at every balloon fast travel point. Added to that fact that your car also does not even use up that much fuel when it travels, means that the extra jerry can in the back ends up being more of a door opener than anything else.

Capturing camps generally has three objectives, blow up x things, disable y or kill z boss. And there's only two approach to all of these objectives, force your way through via the front gate with your car, or find a side hole to just walk through. Then basically the gameplay becomes all the same because you're forced into ground combat which becomes a tedium (as described above).

There are also some pointless mechanics such as: spam x to break open door/crate, or, 'this door requires explosives' when there's a jerry can basically right next to you.

Overall.

There's no stealth mechanic nor grabbing attacks which forces a very linear gamestyle, your guns are more or less just there to do objectives rather than supplement combat flow, car combat becomes a harpoon simulation, while the concept of fuel as a resource becomes moot. If you like the Batman series fighting styled gameplay, then this might be for you.

reviewText: So... This is your typical sandbox as well as a literal one - you drive in a box across miles on miles of sand. And that is the game's problem. Sandbox games require lots of interensting or funny content. And it requires motivation. This game does have quite some content scattered around and if you count by numbers it's not bad, but the thing is, the map is way bigger. It is true to the series, lore, which is good, but not good for the game, especially, when existing content is not really that interesting. Besides, gameplay revolves too much around the car. Again - good for the lore, not so good for the game. Even though you have a goal, like to reach a certain place, yada-yada, in reality you still are doiong all this in order to pimp your ride. For me - it's not a motivation. This should be a side show and not the main dish.\nTechnically, the game is not that bad. It looks good. Controls, even though a bit weird are fine. Although I am having issues with counter-attacks - it seems to be reacting with delay. ANd overall the quality of the game in general is good. If it was a linear game, a smaller one I think I would have been able to enjoy it, even though dialouges are like from the b-movies. Still, in sense, true to the origin.\nI am marking this as recomended, since Steam does not give us much choice, but I would recomend it to fans only. It does have a proper atmosphere. But if you are into sandbox or free-roam games... Well, you can try it on discount, but not sooner. Better play Borderlands then. They have sand and boxes, too.

reviewText: So here we have it. Mad Max. Id never seen the movies until I bought this game and playing it made me watch Mad Max 1 and 2 tonight. I didn't even know about this game until a friend mentioned he was quite hyped close to release. I waited until after release to buy it actually due to the wonderful" launch of Arkham Knight (sarcasm). But in all seriousness this game has slapped me in the face and proven me wrong.\n\nI have enjoyed 37 hours of Mad Max so far and I have not enjoyed a game this much since one of the Assassins Creed games which im not going to go in detail about as I am not here to promote AC. Every new title that comes out nowadays gets me worrying about optimization and whether the game will actually be in any way playable at launch. Mad Max is 100% playable and 99.9% bug free. A 2MB update could fix the only issues the game currently has and the best part is that the bugs aren't game breaking! The gameplay is extremely fun all the way through and even though im a guy im not afraid to admit that the main story has some emotion in it. There were moments that I actually gasped in shock lol. The driving is very smooth and I would compare it alot to GTA's style of driving but it feels like driving the Batmobile from Arkham Knight quite a bit when it comes to vehicle control and drifting etc. The vehicle customisation is great. You can change every little piece of your car to your liking but it comes at a price of course. Combat. Once again very like Warner Bros Batman Arkham combat although you do notice the difference in moves and overall let's say "gore"? Yeah gore. So ive actually completed the main story now and I was worried that when it is done will I still play Mad Max? Yes is the answer. The main story may be complete but still I had only 43% completed the game. It was beautfiul in it's own way. When it comes to character customization I would choose the word endless. You can change Max's facial hair
hoursPlayed: jacket
voteText:
gun and unlock new fighting moves. So after watching the first 2 Mad Max movies I would compare the game to Mad Max 2 the most. I was watching the very long car battle near the end and right away I was getting flashbacks of vehicle combat in the video game! Even the map/scenery makes me feel like im a part of the 2nd movie.

Most interesting feature of the game:

Chumbucket. This is a character you meet in the game. After meeting him he leeches onto you and never goes away. After 45 minutes of playing you are very thankful to have him there. 3000 pieces of scrap later you are extremely happy to have him with you because your car will begin to look beautful because of him. He is very helpful throughout the game and got me through some situations. Ive usually found that having a character like this who constantly is with you in a game gets annoying. It's like Roman from GTA IV. "Hey Nico! Want to bowling?". I know Roman wasn't physically there but he still got me trying to find subways so I could escape the world of phone signal. Although Chumbucket knows what he is doing. He knows when to speak and when to shut the hell up. That's always a great thing. Right?

Sooooo graphics! Beautiful! Some may shoot me virtually for this but im gonna compare this game to the Arkham Knight graphics. I know ive compared it to Batman enough but seriously it is the best and most accurate example and it's by Warner Bros for god sake! Honestly the graphics are great. The game is very well optimized and im extremely shocked that it is due to more recent games and their examples. Warner Bros have done a great job at recreating the Mad Max world for us to free roam around in with our rumbling V8 engines. Good job. And yeah here is the gretaest part of all for people worrying if they can run this game. Im using an AMD Radeon HD 7870 with an AMD FX 6350 on high 1920x1080. No stutters no lag and 30fps+.

Also on the main menu I see a DLC tab. The excitement is real and the wallet is open!

9/10"

reviewText:
I was excited when I saw the trailers and gamplay of the game . But was bit confused after i saw the movie Mad Max Fury Road. But I decided to pick it up and give it a go. And I wasn't disappointed.  What a game. Although I didn't have much time to play, but here are my thoughts after playing . And Wil include more in depth analysis

Pros:
-Good Optimization. Runs perfectly on my laptop with GTX 860M GPU
- Brutal Yet Addicte combat System. Batman arkham series would find it more interesting
- Vast Vast Wasteland to cover .
- Love The Cusomization.
-Fun to do quests and finding scraps.
-Fuel system and water system is damn good.  Really liked it. It forces me to focus on the game
- Survival at its best

Cons:

- There should be an speedometer :3 . It's good to see the how fast ur car can go.
- Story Is a bit disooriented .



One thing just popped up in my mind. There could be a multiplayer system of mad max. There could be Online races, car combats among the players like carmeggadon.  There could have been some crews formed among players and fighting among  the crews over the territory control .It would gave the game a big edge and could have make it a bit more interesting and different from many games. I hope devs will listen to us.


The fact is, it will push you to the limits. U can take risk but it has to calculative. Any wrong move and your car is done for sure.  And It's even risky to stay out open in the wasteland. Either Snipers or the cars will kill u for sure :3. Need to keep u r canteen filled up or eat a dead body for foodall these things just made me fall in love of this game.  Let's see how it ends up!"

What a game! What a lovely game!!!! All Shiny and Chrome riding into Valhalla has never been so satisfying.

reviewText: So... This is your typical sandbox as well as a literal one - you drive in a box across miles on miles of sand. And that is the game's problem. Sandbox games require lots of interensting or funny content. And it requires motivation. This game does have quite some content scattered around and if you count by numbers it's not bad, but the thing is, the map is way bigger. It is true to the series, lore, which is good, but not good for the game, especially, when existing content is not really that interesting. Besides, gameplay revolves too much around the car. Again - good for the lore, not so good for the game. Even though you have a goal, like to reach a certain place, yada-yada, in reality you still are doiong all this in order to pimp your ride. For me - it's not a motivation. This should be a side show and not the main dish.\nTechnically, the game is not that bad. It looks good. Controls, even though a bit weird are fine. Although I am having issues with counter-attacks - it seems to be reacting with delay. ANd overall the quality of the game in general is good. If it was a linear game, a smaller one I think I would have been able to enjoy it, even though dialouges are like from the b-movies. Still, in sense, true to the origin.\nI am marking this as recomended, since Steam does not give us much choice, but I would recomend it to fans only. It does have a proper atmosphere. But if you are into sandbox or free-roam games... Well, you can try it on discount, but not sooner. Better play Borderlands then. They have sand and boxes, too.

reviewText:
Just finished the main storyline / campaign.
It's a good, solid game.
Didn't have to deal with any of the sadly almost obligatory typical release date issues with most major games nowadays.
That in itself is a bonus.

For people who love the mad max franchise there is plenty of stuff, details, characters, places etc that fit right into this universe.
The environment including day/night cycle, weather, sky, clouds etc is beautiful.
The story/setting as a dystopian world with all hope gone works. It is dirty, brutal, bloody, gory and i loved it.
The melee based combat system works and is pretty satisfying.


Repetition might be an issue however: think of any other open world title which features more or less similar gameplay mechanis - these suffer similar criticism. The bases/places to 'conquer' vary in design/look/feel.
I don't compare this game to mgs 5, coincidental release dates do not mean one has to decide for one or the other. Enjoy them both.

Overall a nice open world game with a refreshing dessert apocalyptic ( australian )  setting.
Recommend it - for open world enthusiasts in general and for mad max fans in particular.
