reviewText:
(Warning: much words, such tl;dr)

To start I will say this: I like this game so far, there's plenty that's good about it.
That said, I'm sure everyone and their mother will be posting reviews about why it's good while glossing over the negative bits (which might not be negatives for everyone, I suppose). So I'm opting to talk about what I don't like here instead.
This is, of course, personal opinion, just because I don't like something doesn't make it bad.

-----------------------------

The on-foot combat mechanics... I believe someone said they are reminiscent of the Batman: Arkham series". If by 'reminiscent' you mean 'practically torn straight out'
date: then I'm inclined to agree. The mechanics aren't bad or anything
recommended:
it's just kind of disappointing that they more or less copy/pasted the brawling instead of trying to make something a little more unique.

-----------------------------

Certainly a more personal gripe
hoursPlayed: but I find the open-world collectible-hunting to be very tiresome. People compare it to Just Cause 2
voteText: and I see what they mean. Problem is
helpfulPercent: I gave up on JC2's collectibles less than 15% of the way through finding them all because I got bored of basically looking for the same few things over and over and over again in a colossal playable area where it was kind of difficult to distinguish one section of the world from any other save a few landmarks here and there. I'm not even quite finished with finding all the things in the first main area of Mad Max
votesHelpful:
and it's wearing thin.

-----------------------------

The bosses. Good god do I hate the bosses so far.

See
votesTotal: I always imagined that if a Mad Max game was going to have bosses
votesFunny: they would be awesome. Like
commentsCount: each boss would actually have tangible importance
column16: each would have a unique look
column17: voice
column18: personality
column19: specialization. Most importantly though
column20: they would have an awesome mobile death fortress of some kind
column21: and the showdown with them would include a huge running battle where you have to use all the tools at your disposal to pick apart their defenses one piece at a time while dodging smaller support and assault vehicles before finally delivering the killing blow.\n\nThe vehicle for each boss would be unique and require different strategies
column22: and the baddies themselves would have enough backstory that you'd know why they need to die outside of the usual "me good
column23: they bad
column24: they need go boom" deal. Finally
column25: when you killed them
column26: it would matter. Enemies that once served under that boss would be more likely to either run from you in terror or go kamikaze in hopes of a glorious death against a worthy foe. NPCs would tell (probably exaggerated) stories around campfires of how you took down some of the scariest dudes in the wastes like it was nothing.\n\nMaybe even have a sort of Crackdown-esque kinda deal where each boss provided some important service that strengthened the final villain you'd have to face
column27: and each one you took down would make the final challenge just that much easier.\n\nSo
column28:
what are the two bosses I've faced so far? Well...
The first boss was a huge dude with a gimp mask and an oversized mace that attacked by charging at me and swinging said mace.
The second boss was a huge dude with a gimp mask and an oversized mace that attacked by charging at me and swinging said mace... and he had a bit of paint splattered on him and there were some random goons and jets of fire.

I honestly could not tell you what the name of either boss was or what they had to do with anything. For all I know
column29: they had nothing to do with Scrotus and were just upset because I walked into their favorite BDSM club and started murdering everyone. Considering I seem to be at least 20% through the game
column30: and the only bosses so far seem pointless and practically identical
column31: I get the feeling I'm going to be fighting Mr. Gimp's several other identical twins in more-or-less matching uniforms before the end of the game.\n\nPerhaps I'll be pleasantly surprised by a unique and interesting boss at some point
column32: but even so... it's a really terrible first impression
column33: and it makes me wonder whether fighting the bosses is really going to be worth it.\n\nI'm not looking forward to fighting Mr. Gimp VI with his fedora
column34: and his gimmick weakness that sounds like the devs just wrote up slips of paper listing every way an enemy can die
column35: put them in a hat
column36: picked one at random and said "Okay
column37:
so you have to kill this boss by performing shiv executions on him over and over again. Otherwise you'll have spend 3 hours whittling his health down with those shriveled mouse testicles you call knuckles".

-----------------------------

On the topic of things that are terrible
column38: what I thought was a glitch during a boss fight
column39: I now believe be be the result of a very poor design choice (though I might be wrong). Whatever it is
column40: I hope it gets patched out.\n\nSee
column41: the first time I fought the first boss
column42: I died after running out of shotgun shells and dodging at the wrong moment one too many times. I respawned right outside the boss arena
column43: and was ready to go in and give it another shot... when I realized I had no shotgun shells
column44: despite having had a full load of four when hitting the checkpoint before the boss. The boss
column45: of course
column46: had full health (I expected that would be the case). I thought this was just an awful glitch. Later
column47: I was driving around and boosted at the wrong second in the wrong place
column48: and died as a result. Before the screen confirming that I had
column50: not survived falling several dozen meters popped up
column51: I noticed that the game autosaved as my corpse burned in the wreckage.\n\nNow
column52: I know nothing about the fine details of programming a game
column53: or how save systems work. But I am thinking that what happened during that boss fight earlier is that I used up all of my ammo and died
column54: and the game decided to autosave the state of my resources at the time of my death
column55: then punt me back to the last checkpoint with the same amount of resources I had upon dying. Which would be expected if this was made by FromSoftware
column56: but it's not. Having your head splattered with a mace only to resurrect a short distance away might fit the Dark Souls lore
column57: but it doesn't really mesh with the Mad Max universe
column60: when you load the last checkpoint/autosave
column61:
it ought to be as if everything after that point in time never happened.

(tl;dr plz fix autosaving on death so I can find something else to whine about)

-----------------------------

To wrap things up
column62: I'm going to change gears and relay the most awesome moment I've experienced with the game so far:\n\nDriving to a minefield with the turdbuggy
column63:
dog in tow and only two shotgun shells on me.
A wild Scrotemobile appears!
"♥♥♥♥. Just what I need right now."
Get in front of him
column64: try to line up a shot through the windsheild
column65: but the shotgun decides it wants to try targetting his rear left tire for some reason.\nRealizing that I'm going offroad
column66: I look forward to avoid driving off a cliff or smashing into something.\nBarely swerve left to avoid ramming into a pillar.\nWeird physics stuff happens
column67: resulting in the buggy spinning around a couple dozen times at mach 10 before landing in a perfect stop on all four wheels facing the exact opposite direction I had been driving.\nI instantly start aiming with the shotgun in hopes of killing the enemy driver
column68: causing the game to go into bullet time.\nApparantly
column69: the baddie hit a bump and went flying through the air.\nThe exact instant the game slowed down for aiming purposes
column70: the Little Scrotemobile That Could torpedo'd the pillar with all the force of a great typhoon
column71:
resulting in what I can only refer to as 'what would happen if Michael Bay was directing a car chase scene for a Mission Impossible film after having gone three months without beating it to explosions'.
There was much rejoicing.

Ahh
column72: if only the entire game could bring me that level of amusement..."

reviewText:
After the last PC fiascos coming out from Warner bros: Batman Arkham Origins/Knight & MK X, i hesitant to buy this game, but then, i give one more shoot to WB and in my younger days i loved the triology of movies Mad Max.
With fear i buy MM and then install and start playing with afraid of the problems, bugs and gliches that could be appear, but miraculously the game its one of the best surprises of last times and now i never stop playing this sick title, I am completely surrendered to the Beauty of Mad Max, is so good, with a great history in extra large brutal post-apocalyptic, the combat system is similar to Batman's but much more evolved and extremely well done, Beautiful environments with a awesome graphics, perfectly optimized to this gen, i have a modest GPU (GTX 550 ti), and the game runs smooth and perfect.
The game drinks influences of great titles, such as Rage, Red Faction Guerrilla, AC, Fallout 3 & LV, Tomb Raider (2014), Batman Arkham City, Far Cry, GTA, Fuel (Drive parts) and Just Cause, these are some of the titles that influence in the best way Mad Max, gonna get the positive aspects of these games and being well balanced and with a bunch of things to do.
Of course Mad Max is not a GOTY, has some flaws, there is no multiplayer, confusing menu of the main quests, and the no apperance of the original Mad Max: Mel Gibson and Tina Turner (the legs, i never liked the music!!!!).
Now guys surrender yourself to this game, as I did and now I might see the new movie of Mad Max: Fury Road, because this game open my appetite for more universe MAD MAX

reviewText:
TL:DR at the end, scored 8 / 10 as of 31st October 2015
Borba likes:Genre - Third person action adventure in an open world environment. Sporting on foot and vehicular combat, progression through upgrades and exploration,with repetitive side missions and objectives.

Narrative - Being a fan of the Mad Max universe, the story was spot on and the characters were distinctive and interesting. The overall plot was somewhat unpredictable, although a bit short, and the ending felt rushed and unimaginative.

Gameplay - The on foot combat has similarities to Batman series' combat. You chain attacks with possible finishers and executions, parry when a visual cue appears, dodge roll and may use your firearm or enemies' weapons. Vehicular combat is more interesting, with targeted damage and several ways of destroying or disabling vehicles. Overall, its easy to learn and satisfying to perform.

Interface - Obviously designed for consoles and gamepads, it performs solidly for keyboard and mouse users, despite being a bit buggish when accessing the garage to upgrade and swaping to the archangels section.

Graphics - Taking into account Mad Max's apocalyptic world consists mostly of sand, rock and some metal, there are plenty details and landmarks to take in, and some interesting biomes to discover. The game is well optimized and looks great, in a grim and depressing way.

Music - Both eerie and discrete during exploration, it quickly shifts into an energetic and tribal tone during combat. Borba considers it perfect in setting the mood for this universe.

Sound - From simple sounds such as footsteps, to the crunchy combat and spectacular ambient effects, it adds much to the whole game experience and immersion.

Polish - Going against the trend of ill-optimized triple A titles and the release now
recommended: the game released with very few issues
hoursPlayed: and none that prevented Borba to perform a full playthrough within the first week of release. Despite a couple of graphics driver crashes that occurred
voteText: no save data was lost and the game's performance is consistent on high settings.\nBorba dislikes:Replayability - After finishing the story
helpfulPercent: Max gets back on the map so he can find all collectibles
votesHelpful: get all upgrades and finish all challenges. Despite that
votesTotal: Borba doesn't feel compelled to do another playthrough
votesFunny: and feels this end game should provide more enemies to fight on foot and on vehicle
commentsCount: perhaps in the form of several arenas or more varied challenges.\n\nDesign - This
column16: is what separates a mediocre game from something truly special. Overall
column17: Mad Max is pretty mediocre as an open world action adventure game due to the fact it has such repetitive side quests that provide an obligatory grind to get the upgrades needed for the main quest line. Solid and fun game mechanics ( combat ) mitigate this situation
column18: but one can only wish there was more love put into the enemy strongholds ( fighting the same bosses in different environments doesn't cut it for Borba ) and more interesting dialogue into the encounters with friendly characters. Maybe with some DLC
column19: introducing new things to do ( arenas and on foot / vehicle combat challenges! ) other than finding collectibles
column20: completing the map and racing challenges.\nBorba feels like despite Mad Max being a solid game with fun combat and many upgrades to unlock
column21: it could have been so much more than a wasteland grind for completionists such as himself. If unsure
column22: consider the game when it gets a good discount
column23: for it is still a solid game that looks as well as it runs
column24: great!\n\n8/10"

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game. It's like Far Cry 3 in that you have to take camps so allies can occupy them, and it's like Rage with the way enemies come at you on the road. There are also strongholds that serve as home bases, and there are various ways of building them up so they serve Max better. I've seen some reviews claiming it's too survival heavy because ammo, water, etc, is scarce, but if you build up the strongholds, you really don't have to worry about all that and just have fun wreaking havoc.

Scrap metal is a necessity if you're to upgrade your car and even yourself so you can handle the increasing difficulty of the game.

I feel this game nails what it set out to do, which was put the player in a Mad Max world, and I especially love the car battles! I keep wanting to gather more scrap so I can turn my car into more of a beast, and this need is also the driving force to do favors for others, which moves the story along and keeps the action pumped.

The characters are fun and well-acted, and the Batman-type combat is fluid. Buy this game and be witnessed!

reviewText:
9/10 - I personally love this game and would recommend it to anyone.
Simply beautiful and has great game mechanics.

At first, I was worried it might be a crappy port since it was originally intended for consoles, but the PC version works very well and delivers impressive performance.
It might seem slightly overwhelming at first, but it holds the player's hand through everything one needs to know and has a useful, gradually-unlocked, well-detailed wiki that's fun to use/read (in-game).
One of my favorite features is the Capture Mode." You could produce some pretty cool screenshots and even videos with all the filters and camera settings you get.
9/10 overall; and not a perfect score because sometimes collision detection is a bit wonky or unclear
date: especially while driving through narrow areas/enclosures (invisible barriers/walls and whatnot)."

reviewText: After playing this game for almost 80 something hours and reading some negative reviews I felt like I needed to weigh in.  This game was largely over shadowed by Metal Gear Solid the Phantom Pain, and was dismissed by many reviewers who had bias or little time to actually play and enjoy Mad Max for what it is.\nThis game is a hybrid of  Far Cry 3 with the crafting system and collectables and Batman’s combo combat system, neither of which is a bad thing.    Some reviews accuse the combat of being simple and repetitive….   Well that is true but I never got sick of pile driving wasteland scum or curb stomping an opponent.  I enjoyed the story enough but where this game was the most fun was the vehicle combat!  As many reviews have stated it was fun and intense, the vehicle upgrade and customization systems are really satisfying.  My advice, pick this up during a STEAM sale if you missed it.  Mad Max was a lot of fun and again if you enjoy the combat in the Batman games and the collectable chase of a Far Cry you won’t be disappointed.

reviewText:
A shockingly good game that i avoided till last winter sale because i feared it was a movie tie in.

The game is more closely linked to the old Mel Gibson movies, its a long, cold, hard look at our society and how we function as human beings...or not.

Its an emotional rollercoaster that leaves you a tad sad but relieved by the credits.

You will play through this game thinking your rebuilding a man's sanity, that there is the possibility for some happiness in a dying world but then reality sets in.

Mixed feelings of loss and rage, a feeling of emptiness thereafter, very fitting for this setting.

There are very few games, that leave me sitting after completion staring at my library list...wondering what i will play next while still trying to process what exactly just happened. The ending is very strong, good or bad depends on you.

reviewText:
Mad Max finds himself stranded in the wasteland, his car wrecked and taken away from him: soon after he finds an unexpected ally in an exiled mechanic who thinks Max is the appointed driver to the car he dreams of building: you then set onwards trying to assemble said car so that you can finally get revenge over those who wronged you.
Mad Max is a competent and quite fun open world game that truly succeeds in recreating the environments, characters and events that made the fanchise famous while providing an enjoyable mix of vehicular and melee combat: a few problems can instead be found in the cliched story, simple mission design, slippery car handling, paper-thin characters and some annoying bugs.

PROS:

-excellent design and art style: the wasteland really looks nice and has lots of small details, different enemy factions all have their own character models, armor, weapons and cars

-the graphics, while not great, are generally done well and sport a good amount of detail in character and car models

-good soundtrack, even though it feels almost too unobtrusive at times

-Max's character is great and truly feels like a shell of a man driven by his sense of guilt

-Max's car has alot of customization and upgrade options available, slowly rebuilding it in a force to be reckoned with truly feels like an accomplishment: if you want to mix things up a bit you can also steal enemy vehicles and add them to your garage selection

-car combat is pretty fun once you get a few upgrades, combat on foot is simple but works well enough

-great ending section

CONS:

-some unimpressive textures

-certain 3d models for buildings repeat a bit too often

-car handling feels too slippery, even an upgraded and armoured hulk of a car can spin out of control if you hit a small obstacle: this makes some driving/ car combat sections less fun or downright frustrating

-mission design is very simple, most boil down to drive to a place/fight on foot/pickup an object or free someone with little variation overall

-side activities get dull after a bit, while liberating camps by either beating everyone in them or blowing up certain objects is fun having to roam around to shoot a sniper/ tear down a structure/ clear a minefield gets repetitive quite quickly

-some camera problems during melee combat, especially in cramped spaces: the camera autofocusing on certain explosions during vehicular combat can also make you crash since you can't see the road clearly

-apart from Max and the mechanic most other characters are really undeveloped and just act as quest givers or cliched enemies

-some assorted small bugs with a few flashing textures, cars disappearing and reappering in front of me, died once and for no reason when exiting my car, car engine sounds not working until you exit and enter again etc: nothing is gamebreaking but a some can get annoying

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=514817538

Mad Max is a very good game overall and I had fun in my 30 hours with it: the story is simple and cliched but engaging enough to make you want to finish it, the side quests are decent, car and foot combat are nothing spectacular but work and are enjoyable and upgrading my car to tailor my gameplay was something I really liked. Eventually all the side activities do feel like just some extra padding and get quite dull unless you're a completionist, but to be honest that's a problem with many open world games nowadays.

The car handling is perhaps the biggest problem, I honestly thought that my car generally felt slippery and sluggish...slippery as in easily entering a spin whenever I hit an object as if my car was an empty eggshell rather than a fully armoured beast and sluggish due to its generally bad turning radius and bad acceleration (upgrades that add weight makes it worse ofc). But driving around and car combat, while suffering a bit from the aforementioned issues, do manage to stay fun and that's what matters: the only exception is a badly designed and unskippable car race where the handling problems come up pretty badly, thankfully some pointers on the forums'll help you making it more manageable.

All things considered Mad Max is a pretty good game and one that'll last you for quite some time before the repetitiveness sets in and you decide to just finish the story: you can already find it for way less than its full price and I can easily recommend it if you're looking for more third-person action but want something different than Assassin's Creed.

reviewText:
Mad Max is an action, open-world game that sends you inside one of the best movie of 2015. Usually, I tend to avoid games based on movies, because more than often they are rushed titles whose only purpose is to sell using the name of the movie. So, what happened that made me change my mind about buying such a potentially bad game? Mainly, Steam reviews. With a solid 90% positive reviews I thought to give the game a chance, besides I'm also a big fan of Mad Max movies, a post apocalyptic genre lover and the game was 66% discounted during Christmas. I bought it and it was a real, amazing surprise.

TECHNICAL ASPECTS
***GAMEPLAY 8/10
Mad Max gameplay is amazing, but unfortunately it is flawed by some aspects that may bore the gamers. As I said, the game is open-world, Max can travel by foot (not a very good nor smart idea), by car (best idea) or by fast travel (anti-boredom idea). Why is fast travel anti boredom? Simply because the world is HUGE, it's like Skyrim but in a desert with almost no life, so even with a car, but nothing to do it gets boring. The environment is really well made, don't get me wrong, I tried to avoid using fast travel (I'm not a big fan of it), but if you want to 100% complete the game, traveling, even with your fastest car, becomes a nuisance.
Now, let's talk about fighting. Take the Batman Arkham franchise, strip the Bat of it's costume, grow Wayne a big bushy beard, give him some ragged clothes, a double barrel shotgun and throw him in a desert, done ? Good, you now have Max, a man that fights (kinda) like the Gotham vigilante. What is great about this in Mad Max is that you can perform some finisher moves depending on the environment. Is your enemy with his back against a wall ? Grab his head and smash it on said wall. Is your enemy the sniper in that tall tower that just blow up one of your car tires? Find a way to sneak up on him and push him over the ledge of his tower, no more sniping for you ... Baiatch ! Do you like the sound of your shotgun? Grab an enemy and gut shot him... again, and again, and again, and ... damn I ran out of ammo.
Once your enemies are all dead you can go back to your car and chill out... wait no ... a war party approaching !!! Fighting in Mad Max doesn't end when you enter your car, it really begins there. If you have seen the 2015 movie you know what I'm talking about, if not go buy the DVD and then buy the game (I'm not joking). Car fights are almost exactly like the ones you see in the movie: ramming, grinding, burning, harpooning, blowing up tires, fuel tanks or drivers. The only problem about cars is that the game doesn't like to see cars upside down, so whenever you flip your car and start sliding on your hood, some mystical force flips your car back on its wheels.
All of this you'll be able to do by buying the right upgrade for Max or the car, there are a lot of them. For Max there are the classic upgrades : better armour, more HPs, special combos, etc. For the car there are car bodies, tires, ramming grills, engines, hood ornaments, harpoons, spikes (to impale enemies that try to jump on your car) pipes that shoot flames and much more. Each upgrade will cost you scrap (the currency of the game), you get scrap by completing missions, looting enemies or locations and by destroying enemy vehicles. It is hard to have enough at the beginning, but doing side missions helps you a lot and eventually you end up having more than you need.
Last thing I'll explain about gameplay is what made the Steam reviews drop from 97% positive to 90% : the lack of diversity for what concerns side missions. In Mad Max you have the possibility of roam free around the map doing things like destroying enemy convoys or liberating outposts. Although these things are fun and give you the opportunity of doing something other than the main quest, they are basically all the same, they just get a bit harder the more you go on. These enemy outposts for example, are different only in their appearance, one is inside a chasm, while another was built on an abandoned oil rig. The problem is that you always have to do the same thing, fight your way among enemies and blow things up or kill the boss. Here, the bosses, or I should say big guys who look all the same except for the colour of their clothes"

reviewText:
WHAT A GAME, WHAT A LOVELY GAME !!!
Mad Max is an action packed 3rd person game where you play as the legend, Max, with his holy chariot, The Magnum Opus, roared through the wasteland in this post apocalyptic dystopian setting where livestock are extinct, eating maggots, rats and canned dog food are a luxury, water is a rarity, and freaky petrolhead with suicidal tendencies roam everywhere.

PROS+The graphics.. wow!
+Game run smooth like butter in my potato rig, unlike his brother Arkham Knight.
+The post apocalyptic landscape, stage and world design are a sight to behold, very immersive and captivating.
+I've said it once and I'll said it again, the stage design in this game is very, very good, every basecamp is different, every place has it's own post apocalyptic charms.
+Combat are a-okay, Max feels more human than Batman or Ezio (and other similar left click to attack and right click to counter themed action games) with his fury/rage system and neckbreaking german suplex.
+Magnum Opus is freakin' Badass when you finally find the V8 in later stages of the game.
+Storyline is pretty neat.
+Stronghold cleanup and loot crew which saved my time grinding in this game.
+The weather system are cool, The storm, the black death, which are randomly triggered is so awesome.
+Car combat are great, I'm having a blast destroying those war boy's convoy.
+Photo editor / Capture mode which are great for SS making.

CONS-Minefield side quest are kinda meh.
-Top dogs (Bosees) are all the same, design and gameplay-wise.
-The grinding are slightly annoyed me.

Troubleshoot -Every so often I would get crash followed with error message:
Error, D3D Device Lost!
Reason : DXGI_ERROR_HUNG: Graphics device stopped responding. There might be an infinite loop in a GPU program. Please verify that the latest graphics device drivers are installed.

haven't search for a fix yet since I'm busy upgrading my Magnum Opus.

It's a shame that such a good game overshadowed by the hype that is Metal Gear Solid V on it's release date.

9/10 will eat maggots again!

reviewText:
Rating: 8/10
Overview: Open World RPG
Similar Games: Batman Arkham city/Knight, Shadow of Mordor,

The Good

+ The wasteland is beautiful yet deadly, it feels massive and empty yet there is plenty of things to do. Driving over sand dunes while the sun sets, exploring desolate locations,races, liberating camps, story and side missions etc. The first time you experience a massive sand/thunder storm is pretty amazing, you can either seek shelter and wait for it to pass to try to survive it and collect massive rewards. Things like that only re-enforce the perception that the wasteland is tough to survive in. The wasteland is a great example of how good art direction and design can take a seemingly boring environment and turn it into something special.

+ Scavenging locations and liberating camps throughout the wasteland allows you to collect scrap which can then be used to upgrade your character or your vehicle the magnum opus

+ Lots of different challenges to complete, completing challenges grants you special tokens which can then be used to further upgrade your character.

+ Car combat is a big component of the game and destroying vehicles feels very satisfying. You can destroy enemy vehicles in a variety of ways.

+ Chumbucket, your loveable yet strange hunchback sidekick. The most interesting and fun character in the game.

+ Incredibly well optimized, plenty of graphical options

+ Lots of side quests, collectables, missions, races etc that are varied and provide a nice distraction from the main quest.

+ Great soundtrack and sound effects.

The Average:

The combat is a shallow version of Rocksteady's Batman games. There isn't enough gameplay mechanics or depth tied to the combat so the majority of the time you are only punching or parrying attacks with the occasional dodge. Even when you upgrade your combat skills, it doesn't feel like much has changed. Parrying an attack isn't instant so many times you will be in the middle of an attack only to be punched/charged from behind. This is further aggravated by the camera angle which is zoomed in to close to the character making it hard to see where all the enemies are.

The story is decent but nothing really special either, it doesn't stand out but it gets the job done.

The game is fairly easy especially if you are accustomed to the combat system. I never found the game to be challenging.

Some annoying  glitches, nothing game breaking but every once in a while an enemy will disappear through the floor, characters getting stuck etc.

If you want to do many of the optional quests, it can start to feel repetitive....like most open world games.

The Bad:

Boss battles are all the same which is a shame because there is so much potential here.

Conclusion:

A fun game that is great if played in short sessions. If you love a collect-a-thon, then you will truly love this game. The good news is you can skip many of the optional stuff and stick to the main story and still have a good time.

reviewText:
Product received for free

IntroThis game was given to me by a colleague who had a spare copy. I put the game aside due to the general consensus that the game was ‘okay’, however when I did get round to booting up the game - I didn’t play anything else until I finished it! And I don’t get to finish many games…

Story/BackgroundThe main story is a bit meh. The narrative has clearly been written to fit in with the game mechanics (you need to upgrade your car a bunch and you need a buddy riding along with you), though it does get a bit better towards the end.

The side quests are nice because they have a level of narrative, don’t take too long and there aren’t so many of them that they detract from the main story.

Post-apocalypse themes are always cool. The Mad Max setting is no Fallout. It is very brutal. There is death, violation, drugs and not to mention insane amounts of violence. I’m almost afraid to say I prefer this level of seriousness that almost everyone in this world wants to kill you purely for the fun of it.

MechanicsCombat is truly where the game shines. There are two types; on foot and in car.

Ground combat is just like the Batman games but super bloody and delightfully violent. It follows the action mechanic formula of punching and parrying, with weapons and unlockable skills thrown into the mix. Max has a gun, but true to the world, ammo is scarce so I found myself very rarely using it (much more fun to save for use in car combat).

The car combat mechanics are awesome. The nature of it, though unscripted, comes across as highly cinematic, detailed skirmishes. Intercepting convoys is extremely fun, there’s nothing like scouting out a dust trail from atop a plateau with your ‘long lookers’, getting into your vehicle and T-boning the target car, shooting raiders off your bonnet in the process. Very fun.

ProgressionMax and his car are the player’s main focus. Levelling up Max unlocks Max upgrades such as armor and skills. This system is very well done; rather than gathering experience points, you level up by completing challenges (blow up 50 barrels, do a 10-hit combo, etc.). Completing quests and eliminating threats unlocks car upgrades. There are many different combinations, the most expensive upgrades aren’t always the best to use. Sometimes the weaker upgrades are a better choice - they may have less mass, which allows for faster acceleration, for example.

VisualsThe game is beautiful. From far away landmarks, right the way down to sand trails and dust clouds, the level of detail is impressive. There’s even a feature to freeze time and capture screenshots and videos. No loading screens interrupt traversing the huge open world.

SummaryI’ve touched on the parts of this game that spoke out to me the most. If you are a fan of open-world action games, post-apocalyptic themes or good o’ violence ‘n explosions, then I highly suggest buying this. Some patience with the first introductory part is required until the game opens up and becomes much more fun. The game is NOT a survival game, Max is a very capable individual, though a bit simple and predictable - he fights like a total badass.

reviewText:
Much like the cars in it Mad Max looks good but is a bit creaky underneath. This review will probably contain SPOILERS, but only for like the first five minutes because the games a bit repetitive.

First, the good:

This game feels so much like the Batman games I originally thought it was the same developer. Which means the combat is pretty fluid and visceral, you feel like a total badass and it never feels far-fetched that Max is more than capable of taking down ten guys at once.
The driving is nice, takes a little getting used to and the cars feel doughy sometimes but flying down the dusty tracks in your hand-built monster is a fun experience.
The customisation is spot-on, I was eagerly anticipating having enough scrap for some of the personal or vehicle add-ons and they all make a noticeable difference.

Now for the bad:

Mad Max _feels_ like the Batman games but it doesn't look like the Batman games, mainly because the camera is so poor in close quarters that you can't see anything at all. This can lead to getting hit in fights you should be walking simply because the camera decided showing Max and the dude he's fighting is too much work so it points somewhere above their heads. Considering half the combat is in close confines this can get very annoying.
Also the enemy design is lacking inspiration. For general mobs there's weak dude, melee weapon dude, fast dude with a knife and shield dude. OK, so there's the occasional suicide bomber and some weird ferals" who come at you like dogs but mainly you will have a mix of the first four. Bosses are even worse

reviewText:
First things first: Thank you for reading! You're awesome!
Movie-based games used to be bad. Well, you could say, its comic-based, but nevertheless, its amazing! For a change upgrades are vitally important. The upgrades you apply to the car are essential and you won't stop collecting and upgrading, believe me. Such a good idea, to be able to upgrade not only Max, but the car also. Upgrades are the best, if the progress tree is designed well. You'll buy the right thing at the right time and feel smart and accomplishing. That's good game design - the perfect illusion of choice. Now the looks:
Everything you'd expect nowadays is here: depth of field, motion blur, volumetric lighting, ambient occlusion. But the sky steals the show. Its the most beautiful sky in a video game. A great achievement by the designers. Also the landscape, a huge, authentic wasteland without any loading screens. Wow!

So, how is this game in relationship-terms"?

reviewText: After fully completeing this game i can now say that I would not recommend it based solely on how un challenging and repetitive the gameplay is, you get spoon fed all the hidden objects, loot etc you just have to drive near it and it will be permenently marked on your map. The enemies dont increase in difficulty at all while max just becomes unstoppable within the first few hours, you can max out all maxs skills before even completing 30% of the game making the griffa tokens a pointless edition espically when they just hand them out for no reason half the time. The storyline is weak but still followable. The side quests and loot locations are repetitive and become boring after the first large territorial state is cleared fully. Minefields are just a waste of time offering no real loot value while taking the longest time to get to since you cant quick travel with the dog. Cars are quite cool as is the combat with the vehicles while the Races" are more just you trying to reach a certain location while a bunch of slow weak cars try to ram you off the road to stop you reaching your destination

reviewText:
The game is fantastic. The environments, the post-apocalyptic settings are amazing. The gameplay is solid and keeps you on your toes cause it can go very bad quickly if you're not fast enough.  I never had such a blast to just ride my car in a sandbox game. The amount of destruction I left behind me makes me smile all the time. The story could be better, that's true, but for me, the atmosphere makes up for it and I DO want to stay in the game for hours.

I'm really not a completionist in games, far from it, but Mad Max makes me want to do everything and it's a sign of an exceptionnal game. I had less fun to complete GTA 5 and I thought it was really good. The game is not more repetitive than other sandbox games but it sure is a lot more interesting to do the side stuff, than let's say, Assassin's Creed XYZ. The car is amazing to use for destruction.

And for those interested in the hardware side of MM. I'm running it flawlessly on a i5 4670k and a Radeon 7970 ROG Matrix Platinum. It looks so good and runs so smoothly that it makes me mad" at other's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC ports even more. This game is an example of a PC port well done.

9/10

A story a little bit more ambitious would have make this game deserve a 10/10 easily for me."

reviewText:
Essential Purchase!


Graphics

The graphics are just breathtaking. Every aspect of the graphics is perfectly done, and I could not ask for any better. The game runs flawlessly even on Ultra High settings. Every single detail is outstandingly created to fit the games storyline, and does the job. Overall, the graphics impressed me from the second I joined the game, and still continue to impress me as I am 10+ hours in. I have not yet found a single flaw about the graphics, and am positive it will stay that way.

Graphics Rating - 10/10



Gameplay / Storyline

The overall storyline/gameplay starts out as a bit confusing, but after just 10 minutes of playing the game, you WILL be completely hooked in. I am currently 12+ hours into the game, and I am not even close to being half way done yet, which is very impressive. The gameplay has tons of side missions, quests, extra levels, and such that you are able to complete while just forgetting about the main story line, which I do quite a bit. The cutscenes throughout this game are brilliant, extremely intriguing, and this game will keep you busy for 50+ hours. This is what I call well spent cash. Overall, I am loving this game.. go purchase it, right now. :)

Gameplay/Storyline Rating - 9.3/10

reviewText:
This is a tough one...
Let me start with a few points:
-It is a great open world game!
-It is sort of repetetive and somewhat forces you to do the same things over and over (not as often to ♥♥♥♥ you off but to get you bored)
- takes around 20 hours to complete when you are not focusing on completing it
-Not comparable to the movie( I know they are not at all related but I want to make this point so people who expect it can rethink it)
-Ammo or fuel are laughably available after a few hours into the game(seriously it's ridiculous you can waste it however you like)
-about 65% on foot and 35% car time which could also be misinterpreted ( I for once thought of a 90% car ration when buying so I somewhat got disappointed)
-The game is not really challenging. The bosses are laughably repetetive and easy and because car combat is always the same you are more likely to just be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off than actually feel beaten
-Story did not really seem interesting(I have to point out that I don't care about story in any game but this one seemed very generic)
-There was no story mission that took longer than ~15 min. which makes them seem unimportant

Now let me get to a point:
It is a good open world game
It is a mediocre car combat game but one of a kind

It has a lot of weaknesses mostly that it's repetetive. You can easiely compare this to Metal Gear Solid V. MGSV has almost always the same objective but offers many different approaches. Mad Max offers to slaughter everyone and everything either by blowing them up or beating the ♥♥♥♥ out of them which makes somewhat boring.

As I have stated I played 20.8h . If my playtime in this game grows by more than 5 hours I probably changed my mind but if not than I tell you this: After 20 hours I am done with the game. I unlocked pretty much everything and don't see a point in upgrading anything else since there is no challenge whatsoever in it anymore. Other than with Shadow of Mordor for example where it took me 24 hours to get to ~90% completion I am not really satisfied with the time I spent.

Do I recommend it? Yes!
Is it worth 50€/$ ? Not at all.
I got it for 19€ and I think it is worth it but I would not recommend you buying it at 50€ for such a simple and repetetive game.

Final Rating: Reluctant 7/10

Feel free to ask questions in the comment section if you have any and feel free to discuss certain points with my if your opionion differs.

Final Note: What mostly pisses me off is that it was said that ammo would be rare but since it is not fights get even easier and you mostly use ammo because you just want to get over with fights faster. I suppose they did it because fighting would end up in constantly bashing the same buttons and while driving you would have to constantly ram the opponent which is annoying and boring.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a great game if you love open world action games.

The story was okay. Max himself is supposed to be this broken man who has given up on trust and others, which ties into his character. I found out that this made him more of a mundane character over an interesting one. He only begins to show interesting desire at the end of the game. The story kept me mildly interested most of the time.

The gameplay is very fun. I was hesitant to get this game after hearing that it is repetitive, but I found that I experienced none of that. The combat is extremely satisfying in the Arkham style that so many games are copying these days, and the open world aspects are done well. The customizing of the Magnum Opus is fantastic, and I was always excited to get it upgraded further. The bosses were very dissapointing, with really only a few types of bosses reskinned over and over.

This game is definitely worth the buy, but I found the main story was a bit shorter than I would have liked. If you don't only do story missions and actually take the time to complete the open world aspects, it works.

reviewText: Mad Max is a perfectly enjoyable game, but don't get it expecting the reinvention of the wheel for gameplay or a deep story. The gameplay is, basically, Assassin's Creed / Batman Arkham Asylum: parry, hit hit hit, evade; go to a very high place (balloons in Mad Max) to reveal maps and unlock fast travel; collectibles everywhere and so on. As you play the story missions or unlock... unlockables you get to upgrade and customize your car, your gear and your skills.\n\nThe game is, to me, a lot like the new movie: something that you lean back and enjoy for the action, the Mad Maxy" vehicles
date: the road fights and the craziness of the post-apocalyptic world. There's something special about impaling a guy with a harpoon fired from the back of your car
recommended: pulling him through his windshield and then dragging him across the desert. The game is as violent as the movie

reviewText:
Its actually the first time ever I take the time to review a game.
I never had much to do with the Mad Max franchise until I saw Fury road and I was immediately sooked and almost made a salto when i heard of a standalone game instead of a crappy movie adaption for the franchise as I love cars, explosions and desert wasteland settings.

Technical aspect:

♥♥♥♥ this game runs smooth, SHINY AND CHROME . Its been a long time since i have seen a so perfectly fine optimized game. I run an i7 4770k @ 4,5 Ghz CPU and a Nvidia Gforce 670 GTX and the game runs on ultra settings like a charm on a very very stable 60 fps. I only had minor camera bugs, like the camera trying as hard as it can to focus on something your pulling after you with the harpoon, but thats more a programming thing than a grapical bug.

9,5/10

Story:

the story needs some time to get going and as im at like 20% of the game ( yes i like exploring) i havent seen much of it- however the game takes its time to introduce you into the characters, story and wasteland as much as it rushes you into the customisation and missionobjectives- overall that makes a good balance to me as the objectives are fast paced and short, rough fun but the story promises to take a deeper breath and contrasts well with the overall pace.
However the story builds up more with the questions that are not asked rather than with those asked- the game gives plenty of hints if you are willing to observe characters and the world as to what happened, why people are the way they are and how everything went to ♥♥♥♥- the brainchild you are producing while driving through endless dunes, seeing oiltankers and airplanes alike inbetween dried salty coral reefs and giant chasms is a sight to ponder and behold.

8/10

Gameplay:

As most people already delved into the way the game plays ill just quickly summarize it:
batman like hand to hand combat with powerful combos and finishers , but not as deep as one would like to wish... well what do you expect of a wastelander- meaty fistfights and crude mean weapons. The game doesnt do much in that regard but it does everything right that it attempts. the animations are fluid and dont evoke a repetitive sense as the enemies are plenty.

Stronghold invasions can be done the mad max style or the mad max style- one way or the other you will make stuff explode, fall down and die- here and there are some sneaky bits if you dont want to bother trying to rip down a fortresses defenses but eventiually things will explode.

Exploration is immensely fun, one would think a wasteland is hard to make feel alive but every time i started to get bored with the environment i got something new to look at and behold thrown at me. The game strikes a perfect balance of wasteland and living world to me and you can always spot a lovingly handcrafted wreckage or sightseeing spot around the next corner. (dont look too close tough- sometimes the graphics designers got a little bit lazy with the textures)

The survival aspect does get a mention but is rather something that adds a little athmospere than anything truly survival-esque -- youll never have to really bother about water, food and gas but its just a nice immersive aspect to take care of these things- i rather eat maggots and the occasional lizard that eating one medpack after the other and never actually drinking ( lookign at you tombrider) It just fits into the game and the developer noticed its a smart move to just immerse you a little bit more

scavenging is a good balance between exploring and reward- sometimes it gets a slight bit frustrating given the low rewards , but youll find story sniplets and nice vantage points ever so often- and overall the game isnt so littered with collectibles that you lose interest in picking them up  at some point *cough far cry cough*

Cars:

now here lies the fun- the customization options are fun and plenty, you actually have noticeable impact on the behaviour and playstyle of your car when you modify it- its an actual second character- Drawing a line to assassins creed black flag here- in Assassins creed the ship felt like a static thing to me that i would just upgrade- the magnum opus however has its characterchange for every addition or substraction you make and that brings a lot of diversity and fun- if you get bored with your heavily armored boulder of a car- how about ripping all those armor plates and bumpers off to create a fast and furious but very squishy dune racer?
You can even do this on the fly so you never have to enter a situation unprepared ( even tough i would rather have the garage only accessible in the safe havens- yet i understand that would hinder gameplay a lot, given the constantly changing world and objectives- so i understand the descision to make the garage acceccible at all times)

car combat is everything michael bay has to offer and it feels like the movies. Its fast, unfogiving and lots of metal will fly through the air.

Shiny and Chrome factor 9/10

Verdict:

you like desert wastelands, survival, cars ,explosions and mutated people ? get the game, its definitely one of the best releases 2015

9/10

reviewText: I usually don't go for games based on movies, but this is an outstanding well executed fun game i haven't been able to put down. Feels like the movie, expands on the Mad Max world, the art, models, feel, everything IMHO is great and engaging. Very recommended!

reviewText:
A game made in support of a movie.  RUN AWAY!........

An Aussie Cult Classic remade, amended and updated by...... AMERICANS!  Gaaaaaah.

There's two strikes, but guess what.... it works!

Mad Max the game captures the spirit of the traditional Mad Max movies, and blends them well with the current Fury Road movie as well.

An easy game to get into, a little 'console' in nature, it's just a fun way to spend an hour or two.  No overt brain power required, just a good bit of escapism.

Pros:
Runs well on moderate systems.
Accessible and simple to learn.
Atmospheric.   I feel parched everytime I play!
Graphics ( esp burning cars ) is VERY well done.   Scenery is excellent on PC.

Cons:
A little repetitive ( but you can streamline and concentrate on the story line )
GasTown not as imposing as was elluded to in the movies and lore.  Feels underpopulated, protected and generally underwhelming.

Knit Picking Side Notes:
For those who do not know or even remember such a thing as Aussie Slang....   Dinkie Dye ( yes, pronounced Die, not DEE as done in the game ) means 'The Real Thing'  'The Genuine Article'  'Not fake or artificial'  'The Real McCoy'  'The Real Deal'.  You get my drift.  I'm assuming that Chumbucket pronounces it Dinkie DEE" because he never went to finishing school
date: and not because Americans have no clue on how to pronounce 'Australian'.  I tell myself this because to miss pronounce it otherwise through ignorance would make this a 2/10 game for me

reviewText:
Avalanche really hit a home run with Mad Max.  The game is optimized to the max, pun fully intended.  I was a bit concerned about buying the game with the suggested minimum specs.  Witcher 3, Dragon Age 3 and Shadow of Mordor really pushed my Laptop to the limit.  I am running an aging i7-4800MQ 2.7Ghz 16GB RAM, SSD with 3GB Geforce 770M GTX video card.  I am very happy to say that I am running at near everything turned up on high with no noticble framerate drop that I can tell so far with nearly 4 hours logged without any tweaking done.  I am running Windows 10 and I have stuck with the Nvidia Driver version 355.60  and havent updated .82 yet as I haven't had any problems with .60 and don't want to rock the boat.

As far as the game play goes the fighting is a pretty fair mix of Shadow of Mordor and Rocksteady's Arkham combat styles.  If you have played either game you will be right at home with the ground combat.  Vehicle combat is very fun and you will spend the large portion of your time in the cars.   Chum your sidekick gets annoying as I pretty much figured he would but you eventually tune him out.  The biggest annoyance to me is I keep thinking of him as a big version of Gollum.  Storywise the game isn't anything amazing so far but it has enough Mad Max feel to it to live up to the title.  All in all the game is one of the best games I have played all year.

With so many games releasing these days with subpar preformance I think if nothing else Avalanche has proven themselves by releasing a game that is very, very well optimized and stable even on a machine well below the specs they have listed.  I for one am very happy with my purchase so far and high recommend.

reviewText:
Pros:

+Combat system works well with one exception

+Car customization is in-depth and increases the playtime exponentially

+Map is unique, not just sand dunes everywhere, there's variation and interesting landmarks

+History Relics were an excellent touch, Max's responses were great

+Tons of things to do

+The missions are set up to make you explore, some require you to go out into the wasteland and liberate camps

+Optimized amazingly

+Sound design is good, it's so satisfying to punch people in the face and hear bones breaking

Cons:

-Combat system fails when you're attacked by 2 people at once, you can only counter one of them, but even then you're usually knocked out of your counter by the other guy hitting you

-Cars are somewhat hard to control, now I'm not sure if this is because of the way I customized my Opus or not, it's usually not noticeable except for this one mission where I'm racing some people through a collapsed and half-buried airport (and indoor segments in general)

-Some sound glitching, when I jump off of a cliff for example, the engine sound gets stuck until I land, sometimes bombs don't make sounds

-Doesn't capture the survival aspect of the wasteland, it would have been nice to have a hardcore mode

-Multiplayer would have greatly extended this game's life-span, even something simple like racing with your custom cars

reviewText: Game Informer gave 'Mad Max' a 7.5 out of 10 and I'd say that's about right from what I've played so far and is pretty much what I was expecting. This is a solid action game that maybe follows the WB formula a little to cloesly. Anyone whose played one of Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment's 'Batman' games or 'Shadows of Mordor' pretty much knows what to expect from the ground combat more or less. While this is in no way a bad thing 'Mad Max' was also developed by Avalanche Studios , whose biggest claim to fame is the 'Just Cause' series, and I would've liked to see a little less WB and a little more Avelanche in the game play. The biggest complaint I see on negative user reviews is the driving, which is a little funky and takes some getting used to; but it's servicable and far from a deal breaker. The 2 cars I've driven so far, Chumbuckets Buggy and the very early Magnum Opus, both handle pretty much the same but aren't quite as good as most games where driving is a big part of the experience. I'm hoping that as I unlock improvements for the Magnum Opus the car will start to become a little more pesponsive because right now the driving is a little sluggish. If not I'd hope that a patch comes out to address this. I will give an extra thumbs up" to the vehicle combat; it's pretty spot on and so far I have no complaints. I'm barely a few hours into the game and so far I have to say that this game delivers and is about what I was expecting
recommended: but definitely not what I was hoping for."

reviewText:
ONE OF THE BEST GAMES OF THIS YEAR --- DEFINITELY A CONTENDER FOR GOTY

I wasn't expecting much of Mad Max before the release but I was blown away when I played the game.

I'll start off by praising the developers for the perfection that they've put into optimization of this game. I hardly notice any frame drop, it runs at constat 60 fps on maxed settings @ 1080p.

You wouldn't exepct much from a wasteland in terms of versatality but this game is unbelieveably dynamic. I mean going from town to town, you'd see the environment changing big time. Every town is different than the other in many ways. While playing this game, you'd never feel like you're stuck in same cliched location.

What makes this beautiful game even more beautiful is the awesomely implemented, better version of Batman style hand to hand combat with lots of upgrades to keep the game fresh till the very end.

Chumbucket's engineered Mangum Opus (Oh saint, the angel cumbustion wants you to drive it) So probably ya'll  know that this game offers great deal of cars combat but on top of that you have this one main car, called The Magnum Opus, It offers soo many different upgrades that even when you finish the game, you still wouldn't be able to have unlocked all the upgrades. You can modify the car in many different ways, whether it be in terms of its appearance or its performance.

Story - I still haven't finished the game, I've been doing side quests mainly because I don't wanna finish it fast but thus far, the story has been progressing nicely and it's quite engaging.

I'd totally recommend this game to everyone.

That being said the story in this game is outstanding and I would recommend this game to anyone who loves a good story and to those that play games casually.

reviewText:
Being a fan of Mad Max since the first film I was excited to ehar that a game was being made about the iconic character that was set in his universe but not based on the movies.  When I first started to see footage from the game it fell off my radar because to be quite honest looked really bad and early previews started coming out backing up these thoughts.  Once the game had arrived though it couldn't be further from the truth.

This game is such a sight to be hold.  The open world is beautiful to see and drive through, especially when lard sand storms blow in.  Avalanche did an amazing job bringing the world of Mad Max to life and making this world one that I love jumping back into to revisit.

As Max you are trying to bring to life Chumbuckets Magnum Opus, the best and baddest car ever built.  To do this you need to scavange scrap, find parts, find a body for the car.   With Chumbucket, your trusty mechanic you setout in the post apocalyptic world in search of siad things, trying to bring peace and safety into a world gone bleak.   Throughout your travels you will make allies and friends and also come across deadly enemies to take out and destroy.

Combat takes place in car vs car action as well as hand to hand combat.  The hand to hand combat is so much fun and makes for a great distraction from the massive car wars that take place all over your world.  I think one of the main things I love about the game is that it isn't based off any movie storyline.  Yes his wife and child are gone and he loses his sacred car, but other than that the villians and story going forward is fresh and new.

After the fiasco that WB had with Arkham Knight I was a little worried that this would go down the same path but it definietly did not.  It plays beautifully on the PC, even when things are maxed out.  They did a great job with the port and the optimization of the game.

If you are a Mad Max fan this is a definite buy and ev en if you are not, this game has a lot to offer and never feels like a chore to play or get boring.  There is a lot to do and will take you a fair amount of time to do it.

reviewText:
Mad Max is legit.  Dont' worry about it being another Batman, and honestly - **** the Polygon review.... Giving this game a 5 is like saying that Shadow of Mordor and Batman were both piles of poo and be real, those games were sick. Especially Mordor.

What I like about this game so far is that graphical style (people calling the color pallette bland are lame, the desert looks awesome - sandstorms, mindblowing).  The fluidity in the animations is great and Max's movements in the world are very lifelike.  I love how he is always checking his back.  Little touches like that pulled me into the Mad Max universe, and I'm going to be honest - I have no ****ing clue about anything Mad Max.  I will learn more and go watch the flicks because of this gem.  To me that is a win for Avalanche and the Mad Max game on many fronts!

Interested in checking out the game and hearing me be amazed in real time? Me neither, but for what it's worth:
https://youtu.be/ICC0bo93Edg

reviewText:
Pro Nice vehicle customization
Large/decent amount of vehicles to drive/collect
Very large world to roam in
Very good optimization
Beautiful graphics
A LOT of side quests
Exploration system is well done.
Excellent vehicle combat
Negative Story is Okay but should not be the sole reason for playing the game.
Collecting scrap can be tedious from time to time. If you had to just press the hotkey to collect instead of holding it, it might have not been such an annoyance.
Camera control can be annoying at times, especially when using vehicle weapons.
Combat on foot is batman style, does not require much skill, just press the parry button in time when someone attacks.
Conclusion / SummaryDo you like free roaming? Like to do a lot of sidequesting, collecting? Like to drive vehicles? Do you like the Mad Max franchise/movies? Then this game is for you. People who are not that much into the previous mentioned topics can still enjoy the game and get enough satisfaction out of it. The story isn't that great, comes down to go to person x to achieve vehicle unlock x etc. I think I'm halfway through the story but I don't think it will change any time soon. That's not to say that it is boring, the prerequisites that you need to complete can be simple or challenging depending on where you are in the game.

Exploration is also done very well. You have these Ubisoft-ish points you have to go to, to scout the area around it but even if you don't you can still explore the various sites by driving around. If you do want to use the balloon sites (to scout the area) you have to secure the site, then go in the air with the balloon and manually detect everything in your vicinity with your binoculars. So it's not something passive as just climbing up somewhere and then 'syncronishing' the area. Don't forget to enjoy the view when you're up there! ;)

Combat system could be better but doesn't really offer any real challenge. The only challenge you'll experience is when you face a large group of enemies where you'll have to press the block/parry button a lot of times on the correct moment. That's not to say the combat system on foot is bad, but it's not my favourite.

All in all this game doesn't offer anything new, but that doesn't mean it ain't good. I'm really enjoying it and can only recommend this. If you like the previous mentioned topics, buy it straight away, if not then wait till the price drops. This game is definately something you're going to be enjoying if you make the purchase for what you deem the right price!

reviewText:
Pros:

+Combat system works well with one exception

+Car customization is in-depth and increases the playtime exponentially

+Map is unique, not just sand dunes everywhere, there's variation and interesting landmarks

+History Relics were an excellent touch, Max's responses were great

+Tons of things to do

+The missions are set up to make you explore, some require you to go out into the wasteland and liberate camps

+Optimized amazingly

+Sound design is good, it's so satisfying to punch people in the face and hear bones breaking

Cons:

-Combat system fails when you're attacked by 2 people at once, you can only counter one of them, but even then you're usually knocked out of your counter by the other guy hitting you

-Cars are somewhat hard to control, now I'm not sure if this is because of the way I customized my Opus or not, it's usually not noticeable except for this one mission where I'm racing some people through a collapsed and half-buried airport (and indoor segments in general)

-Some sound glitching, when I jump off of a cliff for example, the engine sound gets stuck until I land, sometimes bombs don't make sounds

-Doesn't capture the survival aspect of the wasteland, it would have been nice to have a hardcore mode

-Multiplayer would have greatly extended this game's life-span, even something simple like racing with your custom cars

reviewText:
Illumination's Summarized Review

Mad Max is definitely a game you want to pick up if you are a fan of the Mad Max universe.

-It is well optimized
-Has a great combat system
-Voice acting & Rememberable characters.
-The vehicular based combat is engaging and puts you on the edge of your seat.
-The upgrade system feels rewarding and always keeps you one step ahead while exploring the wasteland.
-Scavenging for scrap-metal and parts is really addicting and I've spent countless hours clearing out the different areas before actually playing the main story missions.

Mad Max is enjoyable in every way and has been done right by Avalanche Studios.

reviewText:
Mad MaxMad Max is an open world third-person action-adventure game that has elements of both a PRG and a Shooter.  I have been watching this game for a long time and of course I pre-ordered it as soon as it was available but I have to admit I was a little worried after Batman: Arkam Knight.  I can honestly say that so far in I am really liking this game.

Port StatusMad Max plays great. The controls work well with the exception in the menu where I was forced to use my controller to log into WB.  Now this may only be an issue because I have a controller plugged in, but it was still an issue all the same and I should not have to unplug a controller to play a game with a keyboard and mouse.

GraphicsThey have done an awesome job optimizing this game.  I did have some lighting issues with flickering but after downloading the new Nvidia driver 355.82 it was flicker free.  With Vsync off I am getting well over 200 fps with every setting maxed out.  The graphics are Next Gen and look great.

StoryI really like the story, but then who doesn't like Mad Max. It is the familiar post appopolyptic story where Max has lost everything and revenge.  The open world game with side quests are great.  The environment is easy to immerse yourself in.  I just wish you had choices and consequences.

Furious BugsThe game is bug free for the most part although some people have experienced issues with the map, I have found an entirely different issue.  My bug relates to an earlier quest I completed in the first zone unlocking ammo stations in the last two zones.  Unfortunately my ammo stations are not unlocked and of course there is no way to replay the quest without replaying the game so I am unable to collect an achievement I earned unless I replay the game to do so.  The game has been patched several times but my issue remains.  After 75hrs in this game, I still enjoy running around in game, racing, and destroying cars but I am not too excited at the prospect of finding all of the loot objects again.

ConculsionThe game delivers in almost every aspect and I recommend it without any hesitation.

reviewText:
THE STEERING WHEELS ARE ON THE WRONG SIDE!!1

*Ahem*

Hello and welcome to my personal little, straight to the point review. I already played the game for a good while albeit I still have not
finished the main questline. Without further ado then here we go:

Story        This is of course extremely subjective but overall I have enjoyed so far. Although the story and the dialog is not Oscar-worth by any stretch of the imagination, this post apocalyptic mad world is presented in a very direct and simple manner.

While some could argue however that this is not a positive aspect to it (which wouldn't exactly be wrong since again, this is very subjective), I do find it a little problematic when story writers try to make some that is, or at least should be, simple into something complex in a attempt do add, or make it look like, it has depth" to it. Most often than not to me such action ends up just making the narrative confusing and in some cases
recommended: despite its simple presentation there is some good and funny creativity here (most noticiably on how this world works and how people make by and live on it). Your faithful ally Chumbucket and his crazy religious beliefs and lines is an (funny) example of it.\n\nThe things only start to frail a little when we enter the voice acting department
hoursPlayed: some are good and others.. eh. While I certainly don't expect every single line on every single occasion to be delivered as if Laurence Olivier was behind it
voteText: there were some moments (and not exactly few) that were bellow the average of what you would expect from it. Most noticeably it happens when you talk to random NPC's around the map that give you intel/scrap/whatever.\n\nPort/Graphics        Not much to say really - it is a very good one on almost all aspects. For more detailed info; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=79EL0QDoJrs&ab_channel=TotalBiscuit

Despite the game running at 60 FPS pretty much always there are times every hour or so where the game freezes for a second and then goes back to 60. The pattern looks to be completely random and I've seen it happen on some people videos/streams a few times and there were others talking about it. If I were to take a very wild guess here

reviewText: One of the best games I've played in recent years. The car combat is very satisfying and even the somewhat simplistic arkham style ground combat is fun, especially because the game switches the two around constantly. Like other reviewers have noted the game has a lot of busy" work but I never found it to be any more "grindy" then what you generally see in pretty much every open world game these days.\n\nAlso it needs to be said that the game is absolutely gorgeous. They actually managed to make a mostly desert area look beautiful and interesting. The day and night cycles are also noteworthy. The whole game just looks like a benchmark game
date: but it's extremely well optimised and fortunately never feels like one.\n\nIt's one of the few games I actually 100%'ed this year and that says a lot about it. I could never put myself to do so in games like say: assassin's creed

reviewText:
Excellent graphics, Very optimized, Really big open-world, Best explosion and vehicle carnage, Great special effects and so many amazing locations to discover ! Post-apocalyptic game 8/10 ********

A wasteland game that is heavily influenced by the movie of the year (2015), Mad Max: Fury Road. Though the main story doesnt exceed even the least of my expectations before the game's release but it delivers a vast open world with so many unique places to discover and pillage. Which happens to be the best part of the game.

The main attraction of this game is the vehicular combat and the car customizing functionality. Learn to drive like a mad man to best your opponents in the desert wasteland and you will be visually rewarded with beautiful explosions and chaos. The combat style flows closely with the Batman: Arkham games ( made by the same developers ) but IMO: they made it much better and more violent like it should be. Experiment with all kinds of weapons you can find during a battle because they will never fail to amuse you. ( My favorite was the Thunderstick ). Setting aside the main quests, this game heavily relies on exploration and side quests. It may seem that the developers spent more time in designing the entire world than focusing on its story that reminds me of some other post-apocalyptic themed games I played before ( Fallout ).

Bottom line is, this was an amazing hotseat video game that I could just turn my mind off to and relax.

reviewText:
this is one underrated game! the fact that this game released almost the same time with MGS V is the reason why people left this one.

+ near perfect port (knowing its WB games T_T)
+ car combat is awesome and satisfying
+ arkham asylum melee combat gameplay
+ upgradeable vehicle
+ vast areas to explore
+ war cryers! (not as epic as in the movie but i can live with this one :D)

- camera setting during vehicle combat and melee can be annoying at times
- mob fights are ridiculously hard at times
- boss fights not too challenging
- characters are not that strong compared to the movies

if you enjoy the movie then get this game, i think the story is not connected but the atmosphere of the movie is clearly there, though not all of it but its a well made title.

reviewText: While I haven't finished this game yet, I couldn't help myself to write some thoughts about this game down, first of all, this game is optimised so well that is more stress on your pc to idle the games main menu than when the game is loaded, so that is cool.\nAlso with my experiences with other post apocalyptic games, I have noticed three main types, there is the American wasteland, aka Fallout, where mutated beasts and creatures roam, and humans don power armour to survive, there is the Russian Metro, where even more mutuated beasts and even next level human evolution is taking place, then there is Australia, the Land Down Under. In Australia's wasteland, mutated beasts are not the focus, no. Cars, Oil and Guzzolene are the focus. Everyone becomes are souped up, heavy metal enthusiast rev-head. The need to travel extremely fast in a poorly constucted metal death machine that belches black oily smoke and sets fire the dusty ground beneath it's spiked wheels is everyone's dream.\nSo far it is good, and continuously gets better. Do pick it up and become a rev-head who eats dogfood and drinks water collected in a plastic bag!

reviewText:
I never thought in my wildest dreams of 20+ in years gaming that we would reach the point where this exists. This is the absolutely most gorgeous game I've ever had the pleasure of playing. Not just wonderfully rendered and optimized, but the level of detail is staggering. I sincerely hope the content directors of this game were paid a hefty sum, because they certainly deserve all credit due. From random debris drifting along the dunes, to the licks of burning fuel dripping out of the exhaust, and sandstorms from the depths of Hades. Sand, grime, blood, oil, unholy amounts of rust befitting the utter collapse of civilization.

Gameplay itself is quite straightforward and rewarding, yet punishing enough for an enjoyable challenge. Max's personal equipment and fighting skills are easy to level up. The somewhat grind comes in finding parts for your various vehicle outfittings. Though tearing through structures, war boys, and cars with the Magnum Opus" will sate your urge for downtown road rage to be sure!

You'll notice Max has an odd gait and brace on his leg. Combine that with the armor and equipment he has straped to him at all time
date: and the naysayers who complain about the platforming are just silly. Even if not permanent I really appreciate the effort taken to show persistent wounds and bruises as well.\n\nThe storyline is great. Combine dehydration
hoursPlayed: lack of medicine
voteText: constant fear of being raided
helpfulPercent: with some good old exposure to the elements
votesHelpful: and you can understand why most of the people you interact with don't have all their cylinders firing... if you catch my drift there.\n\nThis is a faithful companion to the new Fury Road. The reboot seems to have a vastly more aloof and gritty personality for Max. As well as perhaps giving a nod to the realities of everything going to absolute hell: PTSD
votesTotal: survival of the fittest
votesFunny:
empaty not having much signifigance because it's a luxury. This felt less like a game and more as an experience. You have to keep in mind George Miller created this story as a way of sharing what he lived through when treating victims of vehicular carnage while he was an emergency room doctor.

A few points of minor complaint I had:
-The dog and associated uses for it were nearly useless. Not sure if an afterthought or someone's "pet" project that never got the attention it deserved. Could have really made things interesting like a helpful attack dog
commentsCount: and/or sniffing out supplies. Not even once did mines ever pose a problem for me.\n-No deadly desert critters
column16:
or tasty lizards to roast? Missing out on the best parts of Australian outback there mates.
-No ability to make my own war-boy possee complete with flamethrowing guitars of the metal gods? What gives Avalanche... what gives?

9.8/10

People think dog food is the lowest point of survival? I would have loved to see Max suffer through a can of Vegimite instead. LOL"
