reviewText:
Some games are perfectly functional, and yet they leave you weirdly unexcited. They have few apparent flaws, but they don't really excel in any department either. Those games make it apparent that one important feature is missing from Steam reviews: the thumb pointing to the side.

The Mad Max movies popularized the post-apocalypse as a setting and left a stylistic imprint along the way. Many of the things you saw in the movies became a staple of post-apocalyptic fiction in general: vast and empty landscapes, moral decay, lack of resources and violence in all shapes or forms. Mad Max also gave the characters populating such an environment a distinctive look: Wasteland dwellers didn't just dress in torn up jeans or ripped shirts, they rather wore something between football gear, hardware store and BDSM fetish - something many fictional works borrowed from. In a way, games like Fallout, Rage or Borderlands are Mad Max games in spirit. Finally, the OG gets his own (current-gen) game and the result can be described as a big and resounding eh".

Even if you never laid hands on Mad Max before
date: chances are you already played it. The game incorporates two of the most overused popular features of this generation: open world and Arkham Asylum style two-button combat. Since this is Mad Max
recommended: vehicular combat also plays a big role in this game. In fact
hoursPlayed: your ultimate goal is to acquire enough currency to turn Max's car into a spike-ridden monstrosity capable of defeating the local warlord. To do so
voteText: Max can engage in a multitude of activities
helpfulPercent: be it racing
votesHelpful: attacking enemy convoys or taking down bandit camps. Plus
votesTotal:
there are possibly hundreds of locations Max can loot for small rewards.

Mad Max is not just any sandbox game - it's THE sandbox game. With all of the genre's pros and cons amplified. To the max.

The big drawback of those games is that the large quantity of activities goes at the cost of their quality
votesFunny: leaving you with a large selection of missions that get repetitive fast and simply aren't that interesting in the long run. It doesn't help that you need to do them dozens of times.\n\nHere's the thing: The game's mechanics are competent and don't have any apparent flaws apart from the lack of depth. After a while
commentsCount: you will develop a nice and steady flow
column16: taking out one bandit camp after another
column17: even though you don't enjoy yourself as much as you think you should. At some point
column18: you will develop that MMO tunnel vision
column19: eyes set on the next upgrade
column20: which will be enough to keep you going. The mechanics are simple
column21: but don't require any finesse
column22: strategy or skill. As you play
column23: your mind will wander off frequently. Maybe I should go swimming
column24: you will think. You will catch yourself pondering life and its existential tribulations to the sound of exploding cars and cracking bones. Eventually
column25: you will awaken from your trance.\n\nThe only times I stumbled over some honest fun was during the car chases
column26: but even they got tiresome after common enemies received multiple layers of armor and started attacking in groups of three - often when I was in a hurry to get somewhere. Meanwhile
column27:
the missions in which you are supposed to attack a convoy are possibly the closest you will get to a breathless chase depicted in Fury Road.

Mad Max is by no means a bad game and more of an example of somebody trying excessively hard to play it safe. It's vanilla ice cream. It's Coldplay. It's jeans and t-shirt. Only the visuals manage to impress since the game is nice to look at and runs without any hiccups.

This may sound like a thoroughly negative review
column28: but it comes down to what you want from the game. If you expect a strong movie tie-in
column29: you will be severely disappointed. However
column30: if you often find yourself with a couple of hours to kill
column31: Mad Max is the game for you. It will keep you busy for hours upon hours.\n\nBusy. Not necessarily entertained."

reviewText:
Wow... just... WOW!  I cannot remember the last time I was so violently enthralled with a game from the very get go.  I was not expecting this to fully capture the FEEL of the mad max movies as incredibly well as it has done!  Though I am not very far into it at this point, it has been pure pleasure since the very beginning!

The visuals are absolutely amazing, and optimization... holy sh*t!  I don't think I have ever seen a game that looks so good and runs so flawlessly!  This is probably one of, if not THE best looking games in my library and it runs on my 3440x1440 ultrawide smooth as silk on ultra settings!

They did an amazing job giving you a huge wasteland to roam and explore, yet while the area is so vast, so far it has definitely not suffered from the traditional open world sandbox travel through miles of nothing to get to the patches of content" syndrome.  Or at least it hasn't felt like it.  Maybe that's because the gameplay itself is just so d*mn much fun!  (did I mention how well it captures the feel of the films? :D)

The "on foot" combat is very very much

I mean... when was the last time you were racing through a debris filled desert mashing it up with other cars and shot the driver with a harpoon and yanked him out of the other vehicle through the window? reviewText:
At the time of writing, I have 41 Hours put into this, and still got about a third of the game left to complete. Loving every minute of it.

My belated game of the year for 2015. Gameplay's simple but extremely satisfying, combined with amazing post-apocalyptic atmosphere. HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!

One of the only games I've ever played that makes me want to 100% it. Despite the fact that this game has the Ubisoftian" style of open world design
date: it's not like Assassin's Creed or Batman
recommended: where the world is filled with absolutely mind-numbingly boring activities. You drive around and visit decrepit locations
hoursPlayed: loot and collect scraps while sightseeing
voteText: beat up people with a satisfying Batman-like combat
helpfulPercent: maintain and upgrade your vehicle
votesHelpful: run errands for Warlords and learn more and more about both Max and how the world turned into a wasteland. Everything is fluid
votesTotal: you go from one simple and satisfying activity to another. Not like AC or Batman where half the activities are clunky
votesFunny: time consuming and boring. Need scrap to upgrade car

column25: it just triggers my OCD if I leave them undone.\n\nNobody hates the Ubisoftian design more than me. Seriously

column29: you go through dried out seabeds

but the fact that I don't care about them here is a testament to how good this game's core gameplay is.

column36: Ubisoftian game design actually being executed well for once.\n-Near-perfect PC port. The only thing I can nitpick is that Anti-Aliasing is just a simple "Yes" or "No"

reviewText:
7/10

I enjoyed this game!

Pros
+ Excellent vehicle based combat. Especially convoy missions where you have to chase down and destroy a vehicle that's protected by other vehicles.
+ Well-optimized. I'm playing on a laptop (i7, GT750M, 8GB RAM) and FPS is 45-60.
+ Arkham-style hand-to-hand combat. If you've played the Arkham Batman games, you'll feel right at home.
+ Interesting locations in the big world.

Cons
- Average story, but the main story mission builds to an exciting ending.
- No real stealth gameplay. You will take out most enemies using combat, or by sniping from far.
- Almost all the bosses you encounter are reskinned versions of the same model, and use the same moves.

P.S.
I played this game during Patch 3/4 and encountered no bugs yet. Some people have mentioned their map disappears, but it should be fixed after Patch 4. Whatever you do, don't modify game0.tab to try to fix the missing map, because apparently it causes some camps in the game to reset and get into a corrupted state.

reviewText:
This game is exactly what I always wanted from a Mad Max game. Granted, I bought a Steam key from a friend pretty cheap, so I am judging the game based on spending $25 for it, not $60.

Pros:
*Open world filled with things to do and some really cool locations to explore.
*Cool storyline.
*Awesome driving with upgrades that really change the feel of your cars.
*Optimized for PC - my PC is decent but not great and it runs it perfectly on ultra-high settings.
*Combat is very Batman: Arkham City, especially once you unlock the cool maneuvers.
*Length: I have 40 hours in, and I am still only at 50% completion.
*The world conversations react to things you have done, so you see your legend grow.
*Never felt like it was a grind for scrap, unlike some negative reviews. Decent pace for upgrading both Max, the strongholds, and vehicles.
*YOU GET TO BE SHINY AND CHROME! WITNESS ME!

Cons:
*Only being able to climb/jump in specific areas means that you will get stuck sometimes. Like, if you fall off a walkway, you may find yourself stuck and unable to climb the ONE FOOT rocks hemming you in.
*Easy. Like, the game is rather  too easy, especially if you are  like me and ignore storyline to do all the side quests and scavenging. By the time you do the storyline, you're walking through boss fights. I usually only die from stupid mistakes, like falling off cliffs or blowing myself up.
*The bosses that rule the strongholds are all the same, just with different amounts of health. I feel like this was a cop-out. AAAAAAAH.... MEDIOCRE!"

All in all
date: I am having a BLAST playing this game and recommend it heartily. 9/10 at this price

reviewText:
I think this most appeals to true mad max fans, so if you aren't that into mad max, or only saw the most recent film and thought it was 'pretty cool', but haven't seen any of the others, or don't care about the mad max lore/setting, then you might not like it.. Although it has 96% on steam so you probably will anyway...

Looks great, and runs amazingly well, I usually stay above 70fps on my laptop with ultra settings

I feel inclined to leave this review 'cause I've seen a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t reviews from 'game critics' on those sites giving it a 6/10 and whatnot, which is a load of rubbish, I feel like they either don't 'get' mad max, or have been payed by Konami to give mediocre reviews to try and get people to buy MGS5 instead... I would not be surprised

I wouldn't call it a perfect 10, there a bunch of things that could be better, for instance pretty much the only few things you can loot is scrap metal and ammo (so far). You'd think in a wasteland survival game, finding new items/weapons/clothing would be a pretty big deal, but not in this game (so far anyway, I have only played a few hours and I could be totally wrong..). Which is a shame.

Everything else is pretty good in my opinion, nice combat system, driving mechanics are alright, and the setting is amazing, they captured the mad max environment perfectly. Plus the story has been good so far.

All I want you to take from this review is not to trust 'professional' game critics, 'cause they're usually full of ♥♥♥♥.

reviewText:
Well where to start. There are a lot of really great things about Mad Max and thing's that reveal themselves over time to the displeasure of the gamer.
I'll detail some pro's and con's seeing that there isnt alot of usefull information out there
about this game and a lack of any official forum that ive seen. *I've looked, nothing but links to twitter and facebook on the main site*

Con's

1. Complete lack of any moral decision making outside of killing random wastelanders that want water or are trying to share scrap with you and no effect on the overall story whatsoever, there arent any repercussions to killing the random wasteland either. This means you wont have the choice to do the right thing or the wrong thing, just whatever the designers wanted you to do for the story they wrote.

2. Lack of multiplayer in a game that would have benefitted it greatly.

3. Minimal HUD options can take you out of the world fairly easily.

4. Wonky camera control while first person driving, its especially irritating in combat.

5. Nothing to do after completion of game besides minor random car battles that are overly easy, I never felt like I was fighting for my life and they tend to run away most of the time near the end of the game.

6. Every Top Dog" boss is essentially the same boss battle over and over and most of the times with a palette swap
date: very lazy considering the universe mad max is set in is very diverse with their wastelanders generally.\n\n7. Car customization isnt so much car customization as it is just upgrading stuff
recommended: your stuck with the same batch of weapons even though you see other cars with neat stuff and can use them allthough they are never as effective as the magnum opus since you can only use your shotgun do to the lack of Chum not being available on any ride except for the opus. There's no way for you to truly make the car your own either
hoursPlayed: your limited to about 6 paint jobs that are used on all the cars in game pretty much
voteText: no personal decal deisnger so your stuck with the base in game decals which are passable if you find one you like and about 6 or so car bodies most of which look like crappy sports cars with the exception of the death rattle which resemble's nux's car from Fury Road.\n\n8.Wasteland base upgrades are a neat concept but ultimately outside of refilling your ammo
helpfulPercent: gas
votesHelpful: health
votesTotal:
and water *making the survival aspect of the game nil and void* they don't do anything aside from maybe open a back area where you can't do anything or perhaps add some cloth drapes to an overhang. That and I dont see myself co-operating with people that willing participate in a slave trade.

9. Max's movement at times since clunky and underdeveloped especially when you realize there is a jump button and its ♥♥♥♥ poor and is mostly there so you can hopefully hop out of whatever broken mess of ♥♥♥♥ you landed in. I've had to restart the game due to being stuck at least 10 times.

10. No contextual cover and movement meaning that there is no cover button in a world filled with cover. No ducking behind your car or crocuhing or sneaking. Max is more or less a wrecking ball
votesFunny:
The opus can handle almost entire camps without having to actually do much other than torch people as you lead them to your car.

11. Severe lack of character development and meaningfull interaction. In a game where the main character is known for being a man of few words you'd think the extraneous characters would recieve mass amounts of attention but after realizing the game was being made with an american voice actor before fans flipped out and they did the right thing hiring an australian I realized they didnt have a good grasp of the source material and what drives these characters.

12. Lack of ranged weapon's
commentsCount: Okay this is something I kind of understand
column16: in an apocalypse theres not going to be a ton of weapons floating around with normal people being ditched due to the lack of ammo. Well in the setting they used the bullet farm exists and not only that but you help a guy find sulfur and saltpeter to make black powder. So why is there a complete lack of any actual firearm outside of max's shotgun and car usuable only sniper rifle
column17: not even a pistol is to be seen anywhere.\n\n13. The Max menu for character customization is also just an upgrade menu with minimal choices for max's look and gear. The facial options you can take for max are things like max with beard

column19: No clean shaven max's of yesteryear for the fans.  Your relegated to ending up looking lika a commando if you want to use the better gear. The knuckle dusters you make and the armor doesnt feel like anything max would have ever used. your shotgun upgrades read as such * max add's a barrel to the shotgun* add's a barrel? how? with what? where? just scrap metal? This game would have benefitted from an actual equipment system instead of just assuming you have these things like plyers and for some mystery reason the only thing you ever have to buy is a crowbar which is a completely pointless mechanic to open some doors and box's considering how cheap it is it can be bought at the beginning of the game making the doors and chests just irritating.\n\n14. Car combat is ultra repetitive and barely entertaining after awhile

using the harpoon gun to destroy pretty much everything gets boring.

Pros.

reviewText:
When i saw the waving flames of the car i just destroyed as the sun was setting behind the wasteland dunes, something moved inside me.
When i caught into a sandstorm, i knew it was love at first sight.

If you want to play a game with a vast open world (do not expect many changes of scenery. Its a wasteland), car chasing, scavenging (yep, maggots are back on the menu boys), car upgrading and brutal fighting (batman fighting gameplay) this game is for you. Honestly, the way car reacts on the sand, the sound of the engines, everything is wonderful. The way the scenery changes inside a sandstorm, is something that you have never encountered before. In general what do you do in the game now (in case you wonder)

1) you scavenge small camps and abandoned vehicles like ships (i guess there was a sea over there) and you also find relics of another time that reminds you how it was once, and they really add to the feeling
2)Destroy larger camps with enemies.
3)Destroy big camps where you have to beat the local boss of the area
4)participate in death races (while in open world, you can steal other cars in order to use them in these races)
5)Help helpless people by giving them water, in exchange for information
6) as you cross the wasteland, random gangs will attack you, or an enemy convoy will pass, that you could attack and destroy in order to gain materials and  parts.
7) Game has soft borders. Means that there isn't any invinsible wall that will tell you its over". Want to drive into nothingness? Go ahead. More wasteland for you. You might find something useful
date: or you can die there. And yes
recommended: you can find something useful outside of the map. Well done Avalanche!\n8)I almost forgot. Enemies in cars are not stupid. If they see they loose
hoursPlayed:
they will run away. Its surviving afterl all is it not?

Want to know the best part? I play this game for 7 hours and i haven't even unlock the half of the map. I am just inside a tiny part of it.

Do you like the concept of Mad Max? Buy it."

reviewText:
This game has impressed me on many levels. It's very well optimized, it looks gorgeous and the gameplay feels good and works well. The story is not bad but it's not great either. It's pretty generic and is made up of the most common themes of RPGs.

The combat feels satisfying but is most of the time not a big challenge as your enemies will almost always attack one at a time which can easily be dealt with by parrying. If there are multiple types of enemies performing different types of attacks in can get quite tough at times.
The driving in this game is very good. The sound of the different types of engines are great, the handling feels realistic while still being arcadey enough to be fun and challanging at the same time and the vehicular combat works well.
Mad Max looks really good. Not particularly in terms of texture quality but some of the effects are really stunning especially the explosions. The atmosphere of the whole post-apocalyptic wasteland is also very believable and authentic. There are lots of incredibly detailed areas to be explored.

reviewText:
This game blew me away. The story, the characters, the environments, the customisation all on point. For a movie-game adaptation this is the best I've experienced so far. I haven't seen any Mad Max films but I picked this game up from {LINK REMOVED}♥♥♥.com for $17 AUD(roughly $12 USD) and blasted through it. I pretty much played it non-stop for 60+ hours over the past 4 or 5 days and I've never enjoyed wasting my spare time on a video game more than this beside MGS V: TTP(Which I no-life'd for 120 hours over 3 weeks).

Points of reference:
Magnum Opus - Car
War Boys - Enemies
Scrotus - Main antagonist
Chumbucket(Chum) - Companion


Overview

You are left for dead by Scrotus and he's has taken your Interceptor. Max is on a quest to rebuild a car capable of crossing The Plains of Silence.

At the beginning of the game you are buddied with a dog which I'll go over more later, and hunchback called Chumbucket which I'll also go over later. Max is on a quest to rebuild a car capable of crossing The Plains of Silence. Throughout the game Max and Chum build a new car; The Magnum Opus and upgrade it for attack, defense and speed. The game is set in 5 regions, 4 of which have strongholds which can be upgraded and used as fast travel points. The 4 regions with strongholds have a threat level and by doing an assortment of activities like taking over enemy strongholds, destroying territory markers and clearing minefields you will lower the threat level thus lowering the War Boy presence (The dog is used to find the land mines in the minefields). The strongholds each have a leader who gives you side missions. You'll also be able to upgrade Max with new combat abilities, attire and even hairstyles. The Magnum Opus can be upgraded with 5 different body types and various armaments and defenses like flame throwers, seeking rockets and a harpoon launcher. Of course with this game heavily revolving around Max's car, there are racing activities to do across the map called Death Runs. The Death Runs have a variety of different types of races such as normal races, timebomb races Chumbucket is with you throughout the entire game and stays in the car. His main purpose is to repair the car and initiate conversation with Max so driving around doesn't seem empty. He's a great character and fits well into the story.

Combat System

To be honest I didn't know what to expect from this game. Warner Bros. has reused the combat systems from the Batman Arkham games and Shadow of Mordor, games which I both enjoyed heavily(besides SoM which I haven't started yet). I think the combat system works really well for a game like Mad Max but at times it just felt like a big chore having to constantly press X(LMB) to attatck and Y(RMB) to counter all the time. Around camps and loot locations where you'll fight War Boys, there are often temporary weapon pick ups that break after a few hits or will drop when you enter a vehicle. I find using a game pad more comfortable for a games like this, especially since the majority of gameplay is made up of CQC and driving.

Conclusion

Now I'm not a long-time Mad Max film guy but I have been meaning to go watch Mad Max: Fury Road but I hadn't had time when the movie was in cinemas. I think the narrative is well written and kept me interested throughout the game. I became distracted from the main story for a while, grinding loot locations and collecting scrap metal  as scrap metal which is the games currency. The customisation of Max and the Magnum Opus was very diverse, as well as the enemies and enemy vehicles. Characters were well voiced and unique as well a balanced level of Australian and American accents. Overall I'd rate this game a 9.5 out of 10 and woould definitely recommend it to anyone, Mad Max fan or no.

reviewText:
Mad Max is one of my favourite games of 2015.

I was pleased to hear prior to purchase that the game was very well optimised, on a GTX 970 I can run everything on max settings and still maintain around 105fps. The story is really well done and resembles the same atmosphere felt in the film.

The characters are all fantastic and the voice acting is really one of the best I've ever seen in a video game.

Pros:
1. Probably the most well optimised game I've played ever.
2. Excellent setting, there's lots of post-apocalyptic games but none that focus on cars and car modifcations to the extent that Mad Max does.
3. Upgrade system is truly wide an deep. Not only do you have different tiers of unlocks for everything on your car but also for Max himself. There are also some hidden unlocks provided after completion of the story that were a very nice touch.
4. Combat system is basic but very satisfying with the upgrades you can give Max to give him more of an edge while fighting.
5. Open world do as you like. You can in theory do a bunch of challenges that gets Max to highest rank before completing the majority of the story and stronghold missions. This leaves you with a very easy path to finishing the game though.

Cons:
1. The game can get a little repetitive with scavenging from camps, finishing top dogs, oil camps and stank gum but these things are ofset by the long term rewards you get for completing the areas.
2. Stronghold missions tended to be a lot less fun and interesting than the story missions. Sometimes story missions unlock upgrades where you already have the next tier of upgrade.
3. Once you finish the game if you're still trying to finish up the upgrades to your V8 (final cost for all the V8s is well into > 10000 scrap) scrap tends to be harder to comeby in larger amounts. I also found that mobile scrap transports are very rare in the same limiting your ability to find them on the roads.

All in all I loved Mad Max from start to finish. It doesn't have any annoying second launcher or DRM, you have the option to get WBPlay (ie its not forced down your throat) and overall is a well rounded game.

reviewText:
I was a little bit concerned that my machine might be under-specced for a game of this magnitude, being that I only have a GTX660, but I switched the GPU Tweak into its game-mode and the only performance issue I have noticed thus far is an ever-so-slight-so-as-to-almost-be-unnoticable jitter in some of the cut-scenes. When I checked the in-game settings, I was happy to see that the default High setting was in use, but - even more astoundingly - it was also running at 2560 x 1600!

I've noticed a couple of bugs in the sound; Sometimes you get back into your car and race away, but the car noises are muted. They're there, but only at 10% volume. They come back eventually; Comments on missions play randomly even after the mission is complete; but overall, the sound is pretty great. The music moves with the action, without dominating. The car sounds are nicely done, with lots of variance for the different machinery. The voice acting for the main characters is well done, with ability seeming to coincide with the level of the characters' importance.

The playability is slightly marred by two things: The camera, and the vehicle controls. The camera is controlled with the right thumb stick, but you also need to use your thumb for fighting moves. I've had a couple of bad experiences where I've been backed into a wall and the viewpoint hasn't allowed me to see what is going on. It's cost me a few crucial hits at times. The car controls share a bit of the camera grief too at times, although only at low speeds, but my main frustration is with the steering. It takes forever to re-center, let alone swinging to opposite lock to catch a slide. If you let go of a steering wheel irl, it will (read: should) automatically rotate to the direction of the car's travel, and quickly - it may, in fact, over-rotate, which is where over-correction and spins happen, but that is for another type of game engine. Max seems to work the steering at the same geologic time-scale whether moving at 10 or 210kph. Maybe that's something to do with the car's 'handling' stat, I don't know yet. I'm still rolling around in The Jack, so maybe time will tell.

The rest of the game mechanics work very well, especially the fighting - both on foot and vehicular. I'm really enjoying wading into groups of warboys with the parrying and combo system used in the fist-fights, whilst regularly unlocking new moves and finishing combos as I progress. The vehicular mayhem presents just as many ways to convert cars to scrap, whether you go with the classic ram-them-until-they-become-a-screaming-fiery-mess approach, or a surgical mindset where the use of tools such as the shotgun and harpoon can quickly remove a threat, but leave the car intact if required. Or both. There are a lot of different enemies, and each needs a different approach, so your tactics will need to evolve constantly. It doesn't get boring or repetitive very quickly at all.

And the storms - wait until you see the storms. The environment varies just as much as the enemies, and can be just as deadly. Even when you're in a semi-safe area, you still need to watch out for everything from twisters and tornadoes, to full-blown force-5 hurricanes - and even they come in all sorts of different forms too.

I was a little bit disappointed that cars weren't more lootable - I mean, you've done away with the warboys and now you have their car at your disposal, but your only option is to drive it back to the stronghold to add it to your collection if you haven't already done so. It really needs the option to scrap the car, either on the spot for some quick scrap, or back at home for increased returns. You can't even syphon the guzzolene... fortunately, or oddly, there is quite a lot of it about, so not a big deal.

There is a lot to get through in this game, and even with the small frustrations, I think I'll be playing it for a good while yet.

reviewText:
My initial impression was really good. It was everything i expected it to be and so much more, but as i continued playing, i started feeling a bit disappointed, there were no bikes, no big rigs, no epic huge car chases, and while the car stuff is really fun on its own, it just doesn't really capture that epic mad max car chase spirit.

Furthermore, the whole game feels like it was made out of a demo of a much bigger game. This is either some really small team that was working on it or they had a very limited budget or only worked on this game part time. Like for example, every single boss fight you fight the same exact boss, the same moves and tactics and even the same 3D model (although later on it gets 2 other 3D models to mix things up a bit but its still the same moves and everything), later on they introduce another boss that is different, but it also gets reused multiple times with a different 3D model, i think it gets used 3 times in total, the rest of the boss encounters are the same guy you had to fight from your very first boss encounter.

So all in all you got like, 5 enemy types that are reskinned for every faction, 1 playable vehicle type, 2 boss types, 5 or 6 types of activities littered all over the map. While those things are awesome the first few times you do them, after some time it becomes repetitive, joyless grind, especially sh*it like finding/disarming minefields, and you have to do them all in order to unlock the car part you need.

While at its core the gameplay is solid and mostly fun, there's a lot of things that are a not completely thought through by developer.For example, the game has a jump feature, but nothing to jump on or over, there is no platforming and the jump isn't high enough for it to be of any use. Often times you end up not being able to jump over objects that are at your knee height, and there's no climbing feature that could be combined with the jump to get on top of high objects, you can only climb things marked for climbing.There's also a knife, that you can only use once.... yeah like you stab someone and the knife disappears, having you scavenge for a new knife every time you kill a guy. There are upgrades that extend your ammo belt capacity and that also lets you have more knifes, so you end up walking around with a collection of knifes, why not just have one knife that never disappears after a kill instead of carrying 9437583 knifes with you, this is the most bizarre game design choice i have seen in a while.No matter how much you max out your car, its still week and slow as sh*it. You can have your engine maxed out but you will still have a hard time catching up to enemy cars and you will never be able to outrun them. You can add all the armor and spikes and turn your car into a barely moving tank, but they will still be able to knock your car's health by more than half in just one side ram, it feels like everything you do to make your car formidable is futile, you might just steal one of their cars and drive that instead.By default, the game has this really nice survival element to it, you have to scavenge for food, water, gasoline and ammo to survive in the wasteland, but than you get to upgrade your stronghold and this is where all this neat survival stuff gets thrown out the window. Once you get to one of your strongholds, it automatically refills your health, water, car, ammo belt. you no longer have to scavenge for anything when you are running low and finding stuff like water or gas cans no longer has that joy to it because you already have an unlimited amount of it, this is essentially like using a cheat code.
Speaking of stronghold upgrades, there's this one upgrade called stockpile, it costs a lot and it literally does nothing, you waste all your money that could have been used to pimp out your ride, on a thing that has no function in the game.And if we are speaking of wasting money, you cant just buy whatever upgrades you want for max and his car even if you already did the missions to unlock them, gotta waste money on all the crap ones before them first to be able to buy the ones you need.You gotta grind a lot to get it, random scrap(money is called scrap in this game) that enemies drop or you find in looting locations only give you like +2 +5 scrap, and you need 4100 of it to get that fancy V8 carburetor for your car. You waste countless hours and hours chasing after cars and looting random villages, that you could have used to actually play and enjoy the game. It's like one of those sh*itty free" to play mobile games where you have to pay micro transactions to get game coins to be able to progress faster
date: only this game has no micro transactions and you are stuck with the free to play part of it.Than there's also this thing where for whatever reason

reviewText:
My initial impression was really good. It was everything i expected it to be and so much more, but as i continued playing, i started feeling a bit disappointed, there were no bikes, no big rigs, no epic huge car chases, and while the car stuff is really fun on its own, it just doesn't really capture that epic mad max car chase spirit.

Furthermore, the whole game feels like it was made out of a demo of a much bigger game. This is either some really small team that was working on it or they had a very limited budget or only worked on this game part time. Like for example, every single boss fight you fight the same exact boss, the same moves and tactics and even the same 3D model (although later on it gets 2 other 3D models to mix things up a bit but its still the same moves and everything), later on they introduce another boss that is different, but it also gets reused multiple times with a different 3D model, i think it gets used 3 times in total, the rest of the boss encounters are the same guy you had to fight from your very first boss encounter.

So all in all you got like, 5 enemy types that are reskinned for every faction, 1 playable vehicle type, 2 boss types, 5 or 6 types of activities littered all over the map. While those things are awesome the first few times you do them, after some time it becomes repetitive, joyless grind, especially sh*it like finding/disarming minefields, and you have to do them all in order to unlock the car part you need.

While at its core the gameplay is solid and mostly fun, there's a lot of things that are a not completely thought through by developer.For example, the game has a jump feature, but nothing to jump on or over, there is no platforming and the jump isn't high enough for it to be of any use. Often times you end up not being able to jump over objects that are at your knee height, and there's no climbing feature that could be combined with the jump to get on top of high objects, you can only climb things marked for climbing.There's also a knife, that you can only use once.... yeah like you stab someone and the knife disappears, having you scavenge for a new knife every time you kill a guy. There are upgrades that extend your ammo belt capacity and that also lets you have more knifes, so you end up walking around with a collection of knifes, why not just have one knife that never disappears after a kill instead of carrying 9437583 knifes with you, this is the most bizarre game design choice i have seen in a while.No matter how much you max out your car, its still week and slow as sh*it. You can have your engine maxed out but you will still have a hard time catching up to enemy cars and you will never be able to outrun them. You can add all the armor and spikes and turn your car into a barely moving tank, but they will still be able to knock your car's health by more than half in just one side ram, it feels like everything you do to make your car formidable is futile, you might just steal one of their cars and drive that instead.By default, the game has this really nice survival element to it, you have to scavenge for food, water, gasoline and ammo to survive in the wasteland, but than you get to upgrade your stronghold and this is where all this neat survival stuff gets thrown out the window. Once you get to one of your strongholds, it automatically refills your health, water, car, ammo belt. you no longer have to scavenge for anything when you are running low and finding stuff like water or gas cans no longer has that joy to it because you already have an unlimited amount of it, this is essentially like using a cheat code.
Speaking of stronghold upgrades, there's this one upgrade called stockpile, it costs a lot and it literally does nothing, you waste all your money that could have been used to pimp out your ride, on a thing that has no function in the game.And if we are speaking of wasting money, you cant just buy whatever upgrades you want for max and his car even if you already did the missions to unlock them, gotta waste money on all the crap ones before them first to be able to buy the ones you need.You gotta grind a lot to get it, random scrap(money is called scrap in this game) that enemies drop or you find in looting locations only give you like +2 +5 scrap, and you need 4100 of it to get that fancy V8 carburetor for your car. You waste countless hours and hours chasing after cars and looting random villages, that you could have used to actually play and enjoy the game. It's like one of those sh*itty free" to play mobile games where you have to pay micro transactions to get game coins to be able to progress faster
date: only this game has no micro transactions and you are stuck with the free to play part of it.Than there's also this thing where for whatever reason
recommended: to perform an action you have to hold down E (or whatever button you assign) instead of just pressing it once. I would understand it for actions that take time like breaking doors open
hoursPlayed: but why the f*ck did they think its a good idea to make you hold E for every single action such as picking up an a weapon in the middle of combat
voteText: its so frustrating. and than there's the ridiculously tiny distances you have to be from a thing to perform an action

reviewText:
Mad Max is something every post-apocalyptic adventurer wants to explore. It's pretty fun and mildly entertaining for few hours. Although it has some minor imperfections it proves itself to be a quite good game.

Personally I didn't get much out of the story, it was a little bit clingy and it had was just a typical video-game plot #192.

The combat system of the game appears to be somewhat similiar to Batman and Shadow of Mordor. Very well animated intense combat with multiple enemies is fun and you can actually feel the power of Max's punches. Basic combat moves are easy to learn and easy to execute when the keys that you have to press are X and Y.

One of the most important part of this game is driving. Building your own Magnum Opus" so to speak. You can choose what body type you want to use and customize your car whilst you roam your way through the territories and cause havoc. Car handling is hard to learn and to master in the beginning of your journey but it'll get better when you actually evolve your car.

The game has some minor imperfections as I mentioned earlier. The NPC behavior for example. The NPC cars may just drive at you out of nowhere
date: ram you twice when you are parked and looting and try to kill you by driving over you. Well
recommended: at that point you should rush to your car and battle with them
hoursPlayed: but
voteText:
sometimes this occurs: The NPC's actually dissmiss you at the exact moment you step in to your car. Then they'll drive away and try to get as far as you as possible without even noticing your existence.


Summa summarum

+ Great graphics with magnificent framerate (60 stable @ Max settings)
+ Enjoyable combat
+ Size of the continent
+ A lot to do (loot

discover)

- Car driving can get a little bit irritating when you have to do something carefully (watch out for bombs i.e.)
- You can't really jump


It's a nice game to lose twentysomething hours with

reviewText:
Made by the same studio that made the legendary Just Cause 2 (best $5 you can spend on Steam, by the way - nab it in the next sale!), Mad Max is an open-world game in the Just Cause vein, but set (as you can guess) in the world of the Mad Max films. Coming from a studio that have proven themselves so capable of open-world games before, it's no surprise that the game does a great job of turning Max's world into a massive vehicular playground.

The game does an amazing job of bringing the Mad Max world to life, right down to details you don't think about in the films, such as the sheer scarcity of resources. Unfortunately that attention to detail is also the game's biggest flaw: once you've spent upwards of ten minutes just scrounging for something to restore your HP and only find enough medical supplies to heal yourself by half, you begin to realize that outside of the car chases, the Mad Max world ... really isn't all that interesting. It's just a flat desert with few settlements, all of which are cobbled together from ugly junk, and populated by scattered bands of savages whose most intelligent battle strategies are to ram you with their car or punch you in the head. The movies cut the experience down to just the cool parts - in a video game, you also have all the dull stuff in between.

That's not to say this game isn't fun - because it is, especially if you love the movies - but if you're looking for the next awesome open-world game to top Just Cause 2 or GTA V, this probably isn't it.


THE GOOD:

- Even for a game in which 90% of the world is brown sand, this game looks BEAUTIFUL. There is so much fine detail, right down to Max's tracks in the sand. If Just Cause 3 looks half this good, we have a lot to look forward to.
- Even though the world is very empty, it makes up for this by making most objects smaller than a building destructible or otherwise interactive. Run over a rocky hillside and knock the rocks down. Ram a rusted-out car body and watch it shatter. Blow stuff up with gas cans, because nobody in Mad Max Land has ever heard of conserving fuel. It's fun just to see which environmental objects will react when you mess with them.
- Your car, the Magnum Opus, is (somewhat) customizable, and it comes with a Jockey from Left 4 Dead 2 who performs repairs for free any time you hop out. Minor spoilers: the iconic Interceptor is stolen in the opening cutscene, but one of the Magnum Opus' body styles is nearly identical, so it's almost like you still have it. I'm 100% sure they added that just to make fans of the main car happy (like me!).
- Lots of NPC vehicles, which are a collect-a-thon in and of themselves (can you steal them all and gather them at your strongholds?). They all look like the kind of crazy machines you'd expect to see in the movies.
- The game and its world feel very authentically Mad-Max-esque. It feels more like Road Warrior than Fury Road, perhaps just because the action tends to be less in-your-face. The story has loads of references to Fury Road though, and the main plotline has you trying to reach Gas Town from the movie.
- Some people hate the weird quantities in which you find Scrap (the game's currency), but I like it because it provides a touch of realism. You wouldn't find stacks of neatly-sorted and counted-out metal in a real wasteland, would you?
- The explosions are awesome and sometimes in slow-mo!
- The villain in the intro movie rides a ridiculous motorized throne in true Mad Max villain fashion.
- There's a dog!


THE BAD:

- This game reveals the disappointing truth that life in a post-apocalyptic desert wasteland isn't all high-adrenaline pedal-to-the-metal car chases. Sometimes you have to search for food. Sometimes you have to scour an abandoned camp for car parts. Sometimes you have to kill a dozen guys with your bare hands just for a sip of water. Most of the time you just have to drive in a straight line through the blank desert, hoping to stumble across something worthwhile.
- With Chumbucket the seemingly-invincible mechanic riding the storyline's Magnum Opus vehicle and providing free repairs, there's no real reason to use any other car in the game. The MO is basically indestructible (if it gets to low HP, you just have to get out and let Chum repair it), and oftentimes you'll need Chumbucket's advice in order to complete a mission, which you won't have if you take another vehicle.
- The Magnum Opus' customizability is fairly limited, and chances are you'll end up with all the parts by the end anyway. None of the ones I've gotten yet required me to swap out anything except the body shell, so I don't know if I'll have to choose mutually-exclusive parts down the line or not.
- Goals aren't always clear - I have to keep talking to the same NPCs to remember what I'm supposed to do. One guy keeps telling me he's getting impatient, but I forgot what his mission actually is.
- Combat is awkward at best and wonky at worst. Basically all you do in melee combat is spam M1 except when an enemy is about to knock you down, in which case you press M2. Car combat is limited to ramming your opponent full-force (the quickest/best option), sideswiping them repeatedly (difficult and doesn't do much damage), or impaling the other driver with the Magnum Opus's harpoon gun (fun, but not that fulfilling).
- The keyboard controls are a bit weird, requiring you to hold down keys to perform simple actions (e.g. hold E for ~1/2 second to pick something up) rather than just tapping the key like other games. Stranger still is that it isn't even done to make up for key-taps being bound to other actions - tapping E does nothing, for instance. I'm still scratching my head as to why this is done this way.


Definitely recommended for fans of the Mad Max films. If you want an amazing action game and haven't played Just Cause 2 yet, go play that instead, then come back to this on a sale.

When i saw the waving flames of the car i just destroyed as the sun was setting behind the wasteland dunes, something moved inside me.
When i caught into a sandstorm, i knew it was love at first sight.

If you want to play a game with a vast open world (do not expect many changes of scenery. Its a wasteland), car chasing, scavenging (yep, maggots are back on the menu boys), car upgrading and brutal fighting (batman fighting gameplay) this game is for you. Honestly, the way car reacts on the sand, the sound of the engines, everything is wonderful. The way the scenery changes inside a sandstorm, is something that you have never encountered before. In general what do you do in the game now (in case you wonder)

1) you scavenge small camps and abandoned vehicles like ships (i guess there was a sea over there) and you also find relics of another time that reminds you how it was once, and they really add to the feeling
2)Destroy larger camps with enemies.
3)Destroy big camps where you have to beat the local boss of the area
4)participate in death races (while in open world, you can steal other cars in order to use them in these races)
5)Help helpless people by giving them water, in exchange for information
6) as you cross the wasteland, random gangs will attack you, or an enemy convoy will pass, that you could attack and destroy in order to gain materials and  parts.
7) Game has soft borders. Means that there isn't any invinsible wall that will tell you its over". Want to drive into nothingness? Go ahead. More wasteland for you. You might find something useful

reviewText:
Ratings and scores make no sense to me in accurately describing both the value and experience a game has to offer, so I will just say that this game is worth the buy, and here's why:

+ Atmosphere: It looks, sounds, and feels like Mad Max should. It fits within the universe and doesn't ruin the character.

+ Graphics: Impressive weather effects (especially the sand storms, which are epic), detailed and high quality textures and models (for an open world), the physics are the most impressive (how cars explode and how debris gets knocked around or breaks into pieces). No visual disturbances to speak of, a very good looking game.

+ Sound: The engines, the punches, the shotgun and sniper, explosions, storms and hurricane-like winds are all fantastic.

+ Gameplay: Batman combat system (melee) meets twisted metal and burnout (vehicles) meets a standard open world Ubisoft game (collect loot and hidden items at locations around the map). It's nice to have a game where collecting loot actually matters, in the sense that you can upgrade Max's vehicles and abilities, and history artifacts give the universe some depth.

- There isn't that much gameplay variety here; collecting loot, ransacking and liberating strongholds and bases, races, driving around, BUT at least the driving and vehicular combat is fun as hell, otherwise I wouldn't recommend this game.

- This has been said on every review, and it's true, the story and characters are lacking. You won't find memorable or compelling characters here, even Max kind of falls short, but the experience of driving through the wasteland and blowing ♥♥♥♥ up like in the movies is like none other. Still a fun game to play even if you aren't totally invested in it's plot.

I usually wait for sales for games and I hardly ever preorder or buy day one release, but this game was worth every penny. I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Short review.
PROS
Chumbucket reminds me of Smeagol for some reason. Maybe the ring and magnum opus has to do with it.
Third person open world.
Combat like Batman
Doing extra requirments apart from scrap to upgrade your car.
Love how you use the dog to look for mines, adds that extra connection to another character.
Vehicle combat is great fun.

CONS
Too much repetition constantly looking for scrap and destroying strong holds.
All hand to hand fighting feels like the one you did before.
Story is a tad shallow.

CONCLUSION
Mad max is worth a buy and the thrill is great for the first 10 to 15 hours before reppetition sinks in. However after completing the wasteland missions and story there isn't too much to do apart from removing any left over strong holds scarecrows etc. It is worth a buy however buying it from steam seems a bit too much. I got mine from ♥♥♥ for 31 aussie dollars instead of 60 usd.
7.5/10

reviewText:
Performance:

Runs silky smooth at 60fps on an i2500k / nvidia 670 on the 'very high' preset.
If it's a PC port - I can't tell. PC support is great, a lot of graphics options, including being able to change audio output device ingame (from speaker to headphones, for example). Haven't seen that in a game in a long time.

Controls:

Seamless transition from controller to keyboard/mouse - if you want to use your 360 controller for driving and kb/m for shooting (of honestly, there is little of), you can.
Almost all combat is either car or melee arkham-style punchin'. The very few times where aim is required, there are 'quickshots' available, so playing this all on a controller is perfectly doable.
Keyboard/mouse controls work fine. They're not bad by default, they're all remappable, and the melee combat controls are almost all centered on LMB/RMB. Remapping basic functions to a thumb or extra mouse button works, and the ingame prompts updated as expected.

Game:

Atmosphere is very much in line with Mad Max and/or Fury Road, melee combat is similar to the Arkham games. Car combat is (so far) fairly simple, but really fun.

There are upgrades. A LOT of upgrades. There's over a dozen categories of car upgrades - each with varying levels, at least a dozen 'passive' upgrads (fuel use, water consumption, scrap collection, ....) and then a bunch more Max-only upgrades for melee combat or cosmetics.

It being an openworld game, there is going to be some busywork to unlock them - but so far it doesn't feel like it because most of the encounters will have scrap, water, or fuel as a bonus - all of which you need.

Closest comparison with regard to the openworld game? Just Cause 2 and Far Cry 4 - Open world with unlockables, upgrades based on exploration, and camps to be liberated.

If you like the Mad Max setting, or want an openworld game similar to the Arkham series while also driving a spiky, flamethrowing, harpoon-shooting car across the desert wasteland; this is for you.

Minor beef: Playing on an AZERTY board, the controls (ingame and when remapping) will say, for example, 'W' for forward as per qwerty, but when remapping it will show no change. However it functions fine on azerty. It just makes some of the tutorials/ingame tips weird when starting out if you play on azerty.

reviewText:
Very under rated game.

Most open world games lose my interest fast as they involve a lot of repeat content. All those side activities and missions end up feeling indentical after you have done a few.  I figured madmax would be the same. I was pleasantly surprised when I started noticing how each little side area and objective were not only hand crafted/designed to be different, but many had different mechanics from each other. No two warcamps are the same. Hell, even the balloon quick travel points are different and require a unique mechanic to complete (ie: one might require you to refuel the balloon, another has you driving your car around to remove the cables that are tieing it down).

The game feels very mad max. The world is closer to feeling like the newer film than the older (which is fine, I love all of them). Driving is a lot of fun, and the batman like combat is also fun. I enjoy the combat in this better than in batman for a few reasons. 1. The rage system - It makes combat that much more interesting than in batman. 2. Unlike batman, there are times when you realistically just cant counter an attack, even if you see it coming. If you are in the middle of grabbing some guy and breaking his neck, its just not realistic to think that you can suddenly counter another attack. Dont worry though, you can still counter 9 out of 10 attacks if your timing is good, but there is a bit more realism with the system than there is in Batman (where you will go flying accorss the screen no matter what you were doing, to counter an attack).

The amount of customization and upgrades in the game is pretty insane too. You have TONS of car options and upgrades, character upgrades, a skill/train system with upgrades, and a hideout" upgrade system that lets you build things in your base of operations. The car upgrades are by far the most impressive. The sheer number of things you can add and customize is great.

The voice acting is also top notch and very accurate with a Max film. The characters all have that no longer part of the reality we know behavior

reviewText:
An accurate simulation of life in Australia, Mad Max has great driving physics, and beautiful graphics and sound design. Just listen to how the engine note of the Magnum Opus changes slightly with every upgrade or take Chumbucket's buggy rockclimbing and note the detailed suspension movement. This is a solid game.

This game plays great with a keyboard, but doesn't support controllers other than a 360 pad. Steering wheel support should have been a consideration with a game so heavily focused on driving.

Occasional UI glitches appear; Most of the time your mouse cursor will appear over gameplay, which can be solved by pausing and unpausing. Other times, the pause menu's back button will continue to be drawn over gameplay, which can be fixed by clicking it. Other than that, the game runs flawlessly.

The game looks somewhat difficult to mod, with all data files being stored in proprietary archives. As a singleplayer-only game, mods and user-generated content are key to its survival.

reviewText:
Made by the same studio that made the legendary Just Cause 2 (best $5 you can spend on Steam, by the way - nab it in the next sale!), Mad Max is an open-world game in the Just Cause vein, but set (as you can guess) in the world of the Mad Max films. Coming from a studio that have proven themselves so capable of open-world games before, it's no surprise that the game does a great job of turning Max's world into a massive vehicular playground.

The game does an amazing job of bringing the Mad Max world to life, right down to details you don't think about in the films, such as the sheer scarcity of resources. Unfortunately that attention to detail is also the game's biggest flaw: once you've spent upwards of ten minutes just scrounging for something to restore your HP and only find enough medical supplies to heal yourself by half, you begin to realize that outside of the car chases, the Mad Max world ... really isn't all that interesting. It's just a flat desert with few settlements, all of which are cobbled together from ugly junk, and populated by scattered bands of savages whose most intelligent battle strategies are to ram you with their car or punch you in the head. The movies cut the experience down to just the cool parts - in a video game, you also have all the dull stuff in between.

That's not to say this game isn't fun - because it is, especially if you love the movies - but if you're looking for the next awesome open-world game to top Just Cause 2 or GTA V, this probably isn't it.


THE GOOD:

- Even for a game in which 90% of the world is brown sand, this game looks BEAUTIFUL. There is so much fine detail, right down to Max's tracks in the sand. If Just Cause 3 looks half this good, we have a lot to look forward to.
- Even though the world is very empty, it makes up for this by making most objects smaller than a building destructible or otherwise interactive. Run over a rocky hillside and knock the rocks down. Ram a rusted-out car body and watch it shatter. Blow stuff up with gas cans, because nobody in Mad Max Land has ever heard of conserving fuel. It's fun just to see which environmental objects will react when you mess with them.
- Your car, the Magnum Opus, is (somewhat) customizable, and it comes with a Jockey from Left 4 Dead 2 who performs repairs for free any time you hop out. Minor spoilers: the iconic Interceptor is stolen in the opening cutscene, but one of the Magnum Opus' body styles is nearly identical, so it's almost like you still have it. I'm 100% sure they added that just to make fans of the main car happy (like me!).
- Lots of NPC vehicles, which are a collect-a-thon in and of themselves (can you steal them all and gather them at your strongholds?). They all look like the kind of crazy machines you'd expect to see in the movies.
- The game and its world feel very authentically Mad-Max-esque. It feels more like Road Warrior than Fury Road, perhaps just because the action tends to be less in-your-face. The story has loads of references to Fury Road though, and the main plotline has you trying to reach Gas Town from the movie.
- Some people hate the weird quantities in which you find Scrap (the game's currency), but I like it because it provides a touch of realism. You wouldn't find stacks of neatly-sorted and counted-out metal in a real wasteland, would you?
- The explosions are awesome and sometimes in slow-mo!
- The villain in the intro movie rides a ridiculous motorized throne in true Mad Max villain fashion.
- There's a dog!


THE BAD:

- This game reveals the disappointing truth that life in a post-apocalyptic desert wasteland isn't all high-adrenaline pedal-to-the-metal car chases. Sometimes you have to search for food. Sometimes you have to scour an abandoned camp for car parts. Sometimes you have to kill a dozen guys with your bare hands just for a sip of water. Most of the time you just have to drive in a straight line through the blank desert, hoping to stumble across something worthwhile.
- With Chumbucket the seemingly-invincible mechanic riding the storyline's Magnum Opus vehicle and providing free repairs, there's no real reason to use any other car in the game. The MO is basically indestructible (if it gets to low HP, you just have to get out and let Chum repair it), and oftentimes you'll need Chumbucket's advice in order to complete a mission, which you won't have if you take another vehicle.
- The Magnum Opus' customizability is fairly limited, and chances are you'll end up with all the parts by the end anyway. None of the ones I've gotten yet required me to swap out anything except the body shell, so I don't know if I'll have to choose mutually-exclusive parts down the line or not.
- Goals aren't always clear - I have to keep talking to the same NPCs to remember what I'm supposed to do. One guy keeps telling me he's getting impatient, but I forgot what his mission actually is.
- Combat is awkward at best and wonky at worst. Basically all you do in melee combat is spam M1 except when an enemy is about to knock you down, in which case you press M2. Car combat is limited to ramming your opponent full-force (the quickest/best option), sideswiping them repeatedly (difficult and doesn't do much damage), or impaling the other driver with the Magnum Opus's harpoon gun (fun, but not that fulfilling).
- The keyboard controls are a bit weird, requiring you to hold down keys to perform simple actions (e.g. hold E for ~1/2 second to pick something up) rather than just tapping the key like other games. Stranger still is that it isn't even done to make up for key-taps being bound to other actions - tapping E does nothing, for instance. I'm still scratching my head as to why this is done this way.


Definitely recommended for fans of the Mad Max films. If you want an amazing action game and haven't played Just Cause 2 yet, go play that instead, then come back to this on a sale.

reviewText:
Mad Max is something every post-apocalyptic adventurer wants to explore. It's pretty fun and mildly entertaining for few hours. Although it has some minor imperfections it proves itself to be a quite good game.

Personally I didn't get much out of the story, it was a little bit clingy and it had was just a typical video-game plot #192.

The combat system of the game appears to be somewhat similiar to Batman and Shadow of Mordor. Very well animated intense combat with multiple enemies is fun and you can actually feel the power of Max's punches. Basic combat moves are easy to learn and easy to execute when the keys that you have to press are X and Y.

One of the most important part of this game is driving. Building your own Magnum Opus" so to speak. You can choose what body type you want to use and customize your car whilst you roam your way through the territories and cause havoc. Car handling is hard to learn and to master in the beginning of your journey but it'll get better when you actually evolve your car.

The game has some minor imperfections as I mentioned earlier. The NPC behavior for example. The NPC cars may just drive at you out of nowhere
date: ram you twice when you are parked and looting and try to kill you by driving over you. Well
recommended: at that point you should rush to your car and battle with them
hoursPlayed: but

sometimes this occurs: The NPC's actually dissmiss you at the exact moment you step in to your car. Then they'll drive away and try to get as far as you as possible without even noticing your existence.


Summa summarum

+ Great graphics with magnificent framerate (60 stable @ Max settings)
+ Enjoyable combat
+ Size of the continent
+ A lot to do (loot
helpfulPercent: scavenge

discover)

- Car driving can get a little bit irritating when you have to do something carefully (watch out for bombs i.e.)
- You can't really jump


It's a nice game to lose twentysomething hours with

reviewText:
Is it worth $60? Regrettably, no.

Mad Max has a monotonous grind to it. But if you can see the details that make it stand out.  The story is good albeit short and the actors are great. The final showdown was simple and quick. The bosses weaknesses and methods are identical except for Stank Gum and Scrotus (who has only a slight variation to the regular bosses). Which was refreshing but still not too difficult. The map is rich in areas to explore. The airport terminal was expecially cool but quick.

All in all it is designed as a console arcade game and the learning curve is very easy. There were times that I wished some fights would drag on. Early on convoy takedowns required time and strategy but as soon as you got the exploding harpoons they became easy and boring.

I played 20 hours trying to clear each area then got bored and rushed through the story. I just got tired of collecting loot.  So if you would like to support the devs then pay full retail but if your on a budget then I suggest you wait for the sale. Either way you should get some enjoyment but I'm not so sure about replayability.

p.s. Devs, please add some more of those great stories along with that supurb acting. I'll take story over loot any day.

reviewText:
An accurate simulation of life in Australia, Mad Max has great driving physics, and beautiful graphics and sound design. Just listen to how the engine note of the Magnum Opus changes slightly with every upgrade or take Chumbucket's buggy rockclimbing and note the detailed suspension movement. This is a solid game.

This game plays great with a keyboard, but doesn't support controllers other than a 360 pad. Steering wheel support should have been a consideration with a game so heavily focused on driving.

Occasional UI glitches appear; Most of the time your mouse cursor will appear over gameplay, which can be solved by pausing and unpausing. Other times, the pause menu's back button will continue to be drawn over gameplay, which can be fixed by clicking it. Other than that, the game runs flawlessly.

The game looks somewhat difficult to mod, with all data files being stored in proprietary archives. As a singleplayer-only game, mods and user-generated content are key to its survival.

reviewText:
Thank you Avalanche for a great game!  Well made PC game that captures the essence of the vast wasteland.  Kill or be killed, bloody and gritty.

Brutal combat thats easy to pick up with tons of customization.

The car combat is jarring and dirty, with fire, explosions, blood and broken parts flying all over.

The story is not the best, but I love the characters, esp Chumbucket.  The guy has taken mechanics to a whole new level.. a religion for him.  His finest creation, the Magnum Opus, is your ticket out of the Wasteland.  Together you have to gather the parts, fuel and ammo for Max to escape to the Plains of Silence, presumably to find his family again.

There is a vast wasteland to explore and scavenge with tons of sidemissions spread all over.  You never know what you might find over the next dune, a convoy?  A fuel depot?  A gang of vicious killers bent on taking your life and car?
A blast to play, with tons of optimizations for optimal performance on PC.  8/10

*EDIT*  Just finished the game at 51 hours playtime.  I have not completed all the acheviements or 100% complete the game.  I have done all the story missions and all the sidemissions.  All thats left is to gather all the loot and find the hidden thingys.  Well worth the money, and the most important thing is THE GAME IS FUN!

reviewText:
If I had to imagine what a Mad Max game would be like, it would be exactly like this game.

Graphics are pretty decent, the gameplay is solid. Not too strong of a story but it's Mad Max. Lots of violence and things blowing up. Badass cars and a well crafted post-apocalyptic wasteland.

Couple of complaints I have is that the game gets repetetive, going from territory to territory scavenging scraps and collectibles, clearing out camps of baddies yet I couldn't stop playing. I also ran into bugs once in a while like clipping through objects or character body parts dissapearing and mines in the minefield not showing up properly. Coincidentally this game was made by Avalanche, same developer that made Just Cause 3 and somehow this game didn't turn out to be a buggy mess like that one but I digress.

The things I liked were the cars, specifically the Magnum Opus, the pinnacle of badassery. The wasteland itself could be quite beautiful and pretty to look at too during certain hours of the in-game day. The flow of combat is pretty simple and looks great when chaining combos and counters together. You get a sidekick named Chumbucket who's just the best lil hunchback sidekick ever.

I had a lot of fun with it and would definately recommend it to strangers and my friends if they like driving and action games.

reviewText:
Very underrated game. No idea why gamespot gave it 6/10 and polygon gave it 5.5 . The only site ive seen to do justice to this game is IGN with a solid 8.4 rating which i totally agree with. TOTALLY BUY THIS GAME!!!

pros
- runs great without errors or lags
-hooking story (though short)
-insanely fun with respect to racing, and upgrading the magnum opus(your car) as well as battles on foot.
-beautiful visuals, ( though its mainly a wasteland,it does good to give that 'post apocalyptic feel' ..like RAGE)
-very satisfying collecting scrap to upgrade max
-excellent weapons(on car and on max), excellent vehicle controlling.
-very wide variety of characters and enemies,excellent voice acting.
-overall just insanely fun

Whether it be crashing into cars, blowing up enemies,fighting,upgrading max, there is a wide variety to do, and this game will have you hooked on it. Even though, you may sometimes get bord of collecting scrap at various scavanging locations,if you stop for 10 minutes, you will definately feel the need to start back playing this game. Its addicting!

Cons:
- it just glitched on me twice and i ending up spawning somewhere else when i died, it fixed itself after i completed the mission and probably will be updated very soon.
-nothing else

TLDR: BUY IT, you wont be dissapointed

reviewText:
Mad Max has climbed up to my list of top favorite games. Considering that includes Super Metroid, Mass Effect 2 and Witcher 3, that has to mean something!

I must preface this review: it's been years since I have personally had a game like Mad Max land on my doorstep. A game that is just pure fun, that is almost completely stress-free, yet at the same time is not stupid and mindless with mediocre gameplay. Oh no. This is a great game.

So, let's begin (no spoilers).

--

Mad Max shares a lot of similarities to Far Cry 3 and 4. It's just a huge open world with a bunch of objectives to complete and places to explore. There's the story, but you kind of do it inbetween your open world rampage. That's definitely not the primary reason to get the game, but it's not a bad part of the package. You play this game to have a blast.

Some of the objectives feel repetitive, a common point of recent critic reviews, but the gameplay more than makes up for it. There's nothing like ripping around a huge open world slaying man-scum. More on that later.

Upgrading your vehicle feels good. The scrap system is simple, yet at the same time demands that you make choices about what equipment you really want to purchase. Speed? Buy that. Armor? Buy that! There's some complexity involved in some gear having weight, where you have to decide on whether a piece is worth its trade-off. It's a great upgrade mechanic that remains minimalistic without hurting the complexity involved.

Related to upgrades: there is something called the Archangels" system
date: which is somewhat like gear loadouts. Neutral towards it
hoursPlayed: personally

helpfulPercent: and you are free to embrace or disregard a lot of them (such as the Archangel system). The game lets you play how you really want to play
votesHelpful: without punishing you.\n\nSpeaking of gameplay: it feels raw and powerful. In fact

reviewText: this game is good, but i wouldn't say it's as good as some people make it out to be. it's basicly like Red Faction: Gorilla  with some other eliments to it. the map is a good size, but not as huge as people make it out to be. it's maybe the size of GTA V map, give or take a little. and it's not as optimized as alot of people make it out to be either. the customization is very good with the character and car. the battles are fun as well, but only to a point. this game does not being anything new to the table, but is a nice combination of eliments from other games. such as fighting in the Batman Arkham series/Shadow of Mordor. base take over like Far Cry 3 & 4, graphics simular to the Fallout series. driving eliments simular to Sleeping Dogs with the smashing aspect, but the driving quality of the Dirt racing series.  the game is worth the price, but i wouldn't say it's as good as a lot of people rave it up to be. like i said it's basicly a amped up version of Red Faction: gorilla.\n\nok now about the optimization aspect and why i say it's not as optimized as a lot of people make it out to be. really it's right where a game should be on full release, nothing amazing. if it was so amazingly optimized, i should be able to max the game out at 1080p with my HD7950 OC gpu and my i7 3770k oc'ed to 4.2ghz cpu with 16gb of high performence gaming ram. but i can't max everything out like alot of people that i assume have no clue what max settings really is. i can max textures with almost everything maxed and get no micro studdering. but a few settings has to be dumbed down to eliminate any micro studdering when driving. so in my oppinion, some of these reviews are a little inaccurate. so anything i have bad to say about the game really isn't about the game at all. it's about the misleading reviews like, i run this game maxed out with a GTX 660 ti"  or "i max this game out with a R9 270" it's not going to happen

reviewText:
Yup, awesome game. Very well done, runs like butter, looks incredible too. I was/am impressed and that is a hard thing to do!

Pros:
Big world.
Lots of stuff to do.
Lots of killing.
Lots of driving.
Best post-apocalyptic game I've played outside of Fallouts.
Too many more to go into!

Cons:
Audio is a bit stuttery in spots, biggest culprit is buzz saws, and some wind effects.
Too much fade-to-black after almost every action. Gets mighty annoying, and wasn't needed at all.
Crashes after 3 hours of continued play, but avoidable by quitting every 2 and relaunch.
I hit a challenge count glitch that made me start all over after almost finishing it... but the game is just so fun I didn't mind!

But like every wb game it felt very much like the last and the last felt very much like assassins creed ie batmanssains creed, lord of the rings orcssasins creed and now mad maxssasins creed except max cant climb at all.. the level design was the most barron ive ever seen in a game as you would probably expect seeing as its set on a dried up ocean floor yet the little pockets of civilization  built from wood crates, Downed aircraft, beached ships and old high ways and subways always were interesting and got the imagination going two fold which I loved and always took the time to look around and take it in before i got max to murder everyone in the general vacinity.. one massive down fall for mad max though is the general repetition when it comes to clearing areas  which you dont have to do they're more of a side mission sort of deal but progression through the game is slightly haultered if you dont"" especially clearing the mine feilds which felt tedious but the story and most of the side missions were really good and kept me interested and full of action unfortunately i had to stop playing mad max right near the end because fallout4 come along so madmax "and my misses" got kicked to the curb but i do plan going back to madmax "not to the misses". anyways i could go on for pages and pages about this game essentially its really cheap

reviewText:
tl;dr: surprisingly fun and atmospheric game which does a lot of thing right because it doesn’t reinvent the wheel but gets repetitive in the mission and side-activity design

fulll review here[chillingchua.wordpress.com] as it's too long ... again

pro:
you get thirsty just by driving in the wasteland
NPCs are awesome and right up the Mad Max standard of nutjobs
good voice acting in the english version (can’t tell for others)
proven/familiar combat system (Assassin’s Creed/Batman) but with some improvements
the car is the main character of the game
no instant game over when your car is wrecked while driving
fuel consumption system for cars
quite a few different enemy car types in combat
hood ornaments (i.e. a gutted teddy bear gives defence bonus)
most camps have a second entry point to avoid ramming down the front door
very limited ammo capacity, so no cover based gunfights
some choices in the story were not as expected … feared even ;)neutral:
fuel consumption system is not needed after a bit
very few copy & paste models for side quests
the main story is just the normal Hollywood effort, don’t expect too much overall
viewing point system to get area map (at least they match the setting)
controls need to get used to (wasted quite a few canteens as “refill” and “ignite” are position based on the same controller button)cons:
Max is quite boring compared to the NPCs
camera issues, especially during fights (car & hand to hand)
need a specialized car with a dog for one specific task only
the same races have to be completed with different cars to get all rewards
repetitive mission design (drive there, kill this, collect this)
Chumbuckets lines get repetitive after some time
Stronghold rebuilding .. you guessed it: repetitive
water is just another healing resource, no consumption over time even in the desert
