reviewText:
This is a fun game by Avalanche. It has all the aspects of an Avalance game: great optimization, fun gameplay, nonexistent laughable storyline, great graphics, intoxicated physics and LOOOOAAAADS of grind.

Just like all their games, it does outstay it's welcome by constantly pushing you to be a competionist, whether it be to unlock upgrades that make certain missions less than insufferable, by constant reminders of everyone around you that you have to do these activities or just plain old UI pestering and game currency collection.

While the brawling is good and has some amazing bone cracking sounds, the car combat is far from perfect. Your car - the Magnum Opus is incredibly squishy, regardless of whether you put armour on it or not (and armour makes the car nearly impossible to control well, so there is no reason to ever use it in my opinion) and while that would be fine under different circumstances, they decided it would be a great idea to add 2 more lifebars to enemy vehicles that block your harpoon attacks until you deplete them. Thing is: by the time you do deplete them 2 things happen:
First their basic health is basically nothing, they will likely die in one hit or you can pull a wheel/driver off them.
Second you will be dead bored by the time that happens (or just dead, if you ran out of rockets or physics sent you in a spin for no reason). In short: the best way to deal with enemies in vehciles is to stop the car and force them out into melee combat. That's not what you want for your car combat part.

Otherwise it's a fun game and if you are a completionist who can endure the same tasks for many many hours to unlock everything, you will love this game, because it really REALLY wants you to do it and rewards you a lot for it. The question is: once you complete everything and there's nothing to do, what do you do with all these unlocked upgrades? I guess the devs didn't think about that.

I recommend it based on production quality and mellee combat. The game does outstay it's welcome and I did rush the last 2 story missions without doing anything in-between because I couldn't be bothered (and not because of the story, please don't expect any good storyline from this game), but for the most part I enjoyed it's explosive ride across the prettiest of lifeless colourless, empty and monotonous deserts I have ever seen in a game to date.

I also ate maggots from a corpse to replenish health. Just so you know: corpse fly maggots eat rotting flesh with bacteria happily festering inside. If you were to eat them, you'd most likely die within the next hour.

reviewText:
Is it worth $60? Regrettably, no.

Mad Max has a monotonous grind to it. But if you can see the details that make it stand out.  The story is good albeit short and the actors are great. The final showdown was simple and quick. The bosses weaknesses and methods are identical except for Stank Gum and Scrotus (who has only a slight variation to the regular bosses). Which was refreshing but still not too difficult. The map is rich in areas to explore. The airport terminal was expecially cool but quick.

All in all it is designed as a console arcade game and the learning curve is very easy. There were times that I wished some fights would drag on. Early on convoy takedowns required time and strategy but as soon as you got the exploding harpoons they became easy and boring.

I played 20 hours trying to clear each area then got bored and rushed through the story. I just got tired of collecting loot.  So if you would like to support the devs then pay full retail but if your on a budget then I suggest you wait for the sale. Either way you should get some enjoyment but I'm not so sure about replayability.

p.s. Devs, please add some more of those great stories along with that supurb acting. I'll take story over loot any day.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a collection of great ideas poorly tied together and capably (but not perfectly) executed.  It's shallow gameplay is outstnding fun when taken in small doses.  Just don't plan on powering your way through this game in a few sittings; if you do, the lack of polish, disjointed story, and repetition (oh lord, the repetition!)  will kill your buzz all too soon.

Mad Max has been compared and found wanting to Assassin's Creed and Batman: Arhkam games (and rightly so while on foot), but the best part of Mad Max takes place behind the wheel.  The car chases (enemies chasing you and vice versa) and convoy battles will stick with you and drive you to play even more  ...at least while they last.  Unfortunately, there are only a limited number of convoy missions (and no free-roam convoys), which is a shame since this seems to be every player's favorite activity.  There are still randomly spawning enemy vehicles roaming the wastes, but they seem fewer and fewer as the game progresses, and enemies flat out run away once your vehicle becomes moderately equipped.

If you're looking for a good gap filler - a game to play when the latest MMO has become stale, but before another massive time-sync game - this is a great place to start.  Just don't be in a rush to finish.

reviewText:
Im just going to write my review with -/10 ratings.

Graphics and optimization: 10/10
Im running this game on high and getting around 110 FPS. The areas look great and the game runs very smooth!

Combat: 8/10
Combat is very fluid and combinations go together seamlessly. However I found it to get stale after awhile as the combos were pretty much the same throughout the whole game.

Story: 8/10
The story was put together very well. *NO SPOILERS*

Gameplay: 7/10

People will complain that is an unfair rating. However, for the first 10 hours I had a great time. But very quickly the constant and repetitive bosses, scrap collection, etc. got old and it made it very hard to stay interested.

Overall Rating: 8/10

I bought this game on discount the day it was released and have enjoyed it alot. However I will admit that it can get repetitive at times. I would definitely buy it on a discount! However, if you are hard on money I would not pay full price.

reviewText:
This game has impressed me on many levels. It's very well optimized, it looks gorgeous and the gameplay feels good and works well. The story is not bad but it's not great either. It's pretty generic and is made up of the most common themes of RPGs.

The combat feels satisfying but is most of the time not a big challenge as your enemies will almost always attack one at a time which can easily be dealt with by parrying. If there are multiple types of enemies performing different types of attacks in can get quite tough at times.
The driving in this game is very good. The sound of the different types of engines are great, the handling feels realistic while still being arcadey enough to be fun and challanging at the same time and the vehicular combat works well.
Mad Max looks really good. Not particularly in terms of texture quality but some of the effects are really stunning especially the explosions. The atmosphere of the whole post-apocalyptic wasteland is also very believable and authentic. There are lots of incredibly detailed areas to be explored.

reviewText:
Most underrated game of 2015? possibly

Many a gaming site gave poor old Mad Max a bit of a tanning when it came out, calling it repetitive, boring and derivative.  As such, I wasn’t really excited for it, and only picked it up on sale because I have been a huge fan of the films for many years and couldn’t get over how awesome Fury Road was.  However, I was really glad to find out that the critics got this one wrong.

First off, if this is boring, repetitive and derivative, its no more so than Shadows of More Door or any of the Arkham or recent Asscreed games.  Also, unlike Arkham Knight, this actually runs at more than 5fps.

Mad Max the game is a bit of a contrast to Mad Max the movies.  Game Max is a sort of wastleand Captain America who goes around helping people, giving water to thirsty drifters and brawling like a part-time UFC fighter, nothing like the tormented and twisted survivor of the films.  You also spend alot of time DESTROYING oil pumps, the most valuable thing in the wastleland.  But put that aside, and you'll find a brilliant, open worldy game that is most fun when you make you're own fun.

Story missions are just glorified excuses to obtain upgrades for your car.  Mad Max is at its best and most immersive when you go off rails and just explore.  Avalanche have given us one of the most beautiful game worlds (perfectly optimized for pc) i can think of in their stunning rendition of the wastleland, from the burnt-out buildings and sweeping dunes to the ramshackle monstrosities of the settlements.  You spend most of the game in your customizeable car, and its a real joy to both drive around and see whats cookin' or to engage in the exhilirating car combat, which does actually nail the feel of the movies dead on and gives you a lot of fun toys to play with.  Taking on convoys is the highlight of the game for me, without doubt.  There's also some interesting underground sections too, which are a nice change of pace.

When not in the car, you raid settlements, sabotage oil pumps, and generally have a jolly time biffing people in the face.  While many said the combat was awful, I loved ever minute I was ramming fists into mouths.  Mad Max's fisticuffs is heavily based on the very familiar Arkham system, but it work by giving you so much more control over what you are doing, with light and heavy attacks, combo finishers, weapons (THUNDERSTICKS!!!) and ability to get Max's shotgun into the mix.  Even sometimes Max loses his rag and starts drop kicking and suplexing mofos.  Seriously, once you've unlocked enough moves combat is just as good as the Batman games and definitely better than Asscreed.  Like I mentioned before, the fighting doesn't fit in well with the Max of the movies, but when you're ramming a thunderstick (grenade on a spear) into someones gut amd kicking him into a mob of bald gimps just before he explodes, do you really care that much?

What I enjopy most about Mad Max is just how immersive it is.  The world is so graphically captivating that it was just a real pleasure to exist there.  Sometimes I'm on the hunt for convoys, sometimes I'm lookin for a spot of fisticuffs, sometimes i'm doing insane jumps off ramps, sometimes i'm taking part in death races,  sometimes I'm just driving around to see what there is.  And with some many things to do and most of the gameworld unlocked after the tutorials section. you're free to explore at you're leisure and jus do whatever the hell you want.  If only this had multiplayer...

It’s not a perfect game by any means. The controls mess you up occasionally, you can only climb objects painted yellow, and there's a fair bit of grinding to do to upgrade your car.  The thing that really got my goat was when the game sends random enemies/storms at you at the worst moments.  Maybe I'm waiting to ambush a convoy and a lightning storm comes along and zaps me to cinders, or maybe I've just wrecked that convoy, no armour left, and a random bunch of war boys appear right behind me and smah me into oblivion.  Or how about the fact that all the bosses look and fight EXACTLY the same?

But all its faults are negligible in my opinion, as the experience of Mad Max as a whole was very enjoyable and immersing. Don’t like these big AAA console games?  Max ain’t gonna change your mind, sweetheart, but if you do like the Arkham/Mordor/Asscreed thing and fancy a wee bit of insane car combat in the mix, Mad Max is worth a try.

reviewText:
If I had to imagine what a Mad Max game would be like, it would be exactly like this game.

Graphics are pretty decent, the gameplay is solid. Not too strong of a story but it's Mad Max. Lots of violence and things blowing up. Badass cars and a well crafted post-apocalyptic wasteland.

Couple of complaints I have is that the game gets repetetive, going from territory to territory scavenging scraps and collectibles, clearing out camps of baddies yet I couldn't stop playing. I also ran into bugs once in a while like clipping through objects or character body parts dissapearing and mines in the minefield not showing up properly. Coincidentally this game was made by Avalanche, same developer that made Just Cause 3 and somehow this game didn't turn out to be a buggy mess like that one but I digress.

The things I liked were the cars, specifically the Magnum Opus, the pinnacle of badassery. The wasteland itself could be quite beautiful and pretty to look at too during certain hours of the in-game day. The flow of combat is pretty simple and looks great when chaining combos and counters together. You get a sidekick named Chumbucket who's just the best lil hunchback sidekick ever.

I had a lot of fun with it and would definately recommend it to strangers and my friends if they like driving and action games.

reviewText:

pros
- runs great without errors or lags

-very satisfying collecting scrap to upgrade max
-excellent weapons(on car and on max), excellent vehicle controlling.
-very wide variety of characters and enemies,excellent voice acting.
-overall just insanely fun

Whether it be crashing into cars, blowing up enemies,fighting,upgrading max, there is a wide variety to do, and this game will have you hooked on it. Even though, you may sometimes get bord of collecting scrap at various scavanging locations,if you stop for 10 minutes, you will definately feel the need to start back playing this game. Its addicting!

Cons:
- it just glitched on me twice and i ending up spawning somewhere else when i died, it fixed itself after i completed the mission and probably will be updated very soon.
-nothing else

TLDR: BUY IT, you wont be dissapointed

column35: as well as a Thunderpoon and Side Burners. In addition to the weapons that can be attached to the Magnum Opus

reviewText:
Most underrated game of 2015? possibly

Many a gaming site gave poor old Mad Max a bit of a tanning when it came out, calling it repetitive, boring and derivative.  As such, I wasn’t really excited for it, and only picked it up on sale because I have been a huge fan of the films for many years and couldn’t get over how awesome Fury Road was.  However, I was really glad to find out that the critics got this one wrong.

First off, if this is boring, repetitive and derivative, its no more so than Shadows of More Door or any of the Arkham or recent Asscreed games.  Also, unlike Arkham Knight, this actually runs at more than 5fps.

Mad Max the game is a bit of a contrast to Mad Max the movies.  Game Max is a sort of wastleand Captain America who goes around helping people, giving water to thirsty drifters and brawling like a part-time UFC fighter, nothing like the tormented and twisted survivor of the films.  You also spend alot of time DESTROYING oil pumps, the most valuable thing in the wastleland.  But put that aside, and you'll find a brilliant, open worldy game that is most fun when you make you're own fun.

Story missions are just glorified excuses to obtain upgrades for your car.  Mad Max is at its best and most immersive when you go off rails and just explore.  Avalanche have given us one of the most beautiful game worlds (perfectly optimized for pc) i can think of in their stunning rendition of the wastleland, from the burnt-out buildings and sweeping dunes to the ramshackle monstrosities of the settlements.  You spend most of the game in your customizeable car, and its a real joy to both drive around and see whats cookin' or to engage in the exhilirating car combat, which does actually nail the feel of the movies dead on and gives you a lot of fun toys to play with.  Taking on convoys is the highlight of the game for me, without doubt.  There's also some interesting underground sections too, which are a nice change of pace.

When not in the car, you raid settlements, sabotage oil pumps, and generally have a jolly time biffing people in the face.  While many said the combat was awful, I loved ever minute I was ramming fists into mouths.  Mad Max's fisticuffs is heavily based on the very familiar Arkham system, but it work by giving you so much more control over what you are doing, with light and heavy attacks, combo finishers, weapons (THUNDERSTICKS!!!) and ability to get Max's shotgun into the mix.  Even sometimes Max loses his rag and starts drop kicking and suplexing mofos.  Seriously, once you've unlocked enough moves combat is just as good as the Batman games and definitely better than Asscreed.  Like I mentioned before, the fighting doesn't fit in well with the Max of the movies, but when you're ramming a thunderstick (grenade on a spear) into someones gut amd kicking him into a mob of bald gimps just before he explodes, do you really care that much?

What I enjopy most about Mad Max is just how immersive it is.  The world is so graphically captivating that it was just a real pleasure to exist there.  Sometimes I'm on the hunt for convoys, sometimes I'm lookin for a spot of fisticuffs, sometimes i'm doing insane jumps off ramps, sometimes i'm taking part in death races,  sometimes I'm just driving around to see what there is.  And with some many things to do and most of the gameworld unlocked after the tutorials section. you're free to explore at you're leisure and jus do whatever the hell you want.  If only this had multiplayer...

It’s not a perfect game by any means. The controls mess you up occasionally, you can only climb objects painted yellow, and there's a fair bit of grinding to do to upgrade your car.  The thing that really got my goat was when the game sends random enemies/storms at you at the worst moments.  Maybe I'm waiting to ambush a convoy and a lightning storm comes along and zaps me to cinders, or maybe I've just wrecked that convoy, no armour left, and a random bunch of war boys appear right behind me and smah me into oblivion.  Or how about the fact that all the bosses look and fight EXACTLY the same?

But all its faults are negligible in my opinion, as the experience of Mad Max as a whole was very enjoyable and immersing. Don’t like these big AAA console games?  Max ain’t gonna change your mind, sweetheart, but if you do like the Arkham/Mordor/Asscreed thing and fancy a wee bit of insane car combat in the mix, Mad Max is worth a try.

reviewText:
Mad Max
Mad Max is loosely based on the world built up in the Mad Max: Fury Road movie. There is Scrotus (Immortan Joe's son) and his hordes. There are Buzzards and there is also the Roadkill faction. Each faction is uniquely identifiable by their garb and veichles of choice. This is one of the places the game falls flat though. Each faction whilst looking and sounding different are basically the same sorts of people you'll fight but reskins of each other. No faction has a unique fighting style.

This lazy design choice also filters into the bosses, where every Top Dog mini boss has exactly the same fighting style despite intel" saying they each have specific weaknesses and such. This is a let down because the mini bosses having their own unique fighting styles and designs would've improved immersion in the game. The game is also very easy
date: you can block your way through most fights and there's hardly any times you'll find yourself in trouble.\n\nWhere the game excels though is exploring the land presented to you in the game. Despite it mostly being nothing but sand each area has its own style and helps makes the drives throughout this post apocolyptic wasteland less of a bore. Whether it's driving through sulfur pits
hoursPlayed: decrepit motorways or canyons each location is fresh and encourages you to dive around.\n\nEach location typically has the same amount to do in it. So 2 minefields to clear
voteText: a few scarerows to rip down
helpfulPercent: snipers to remove and camps to raid. This sounds dull and can get tedious at time I do admit
votesHelpful: but I was having a blast 90% of the time. Especially when sieging the camps
votesTotal: most of them are pretty different from each other in terms of aesthetics so it doesn't get boring to explore and it gives you incentive to fully scout out every crevice of the camps for scrap and insignia signs to destory.\n\nEach major non enemy leader who hands out missions will own a stronghold. Each stronghold will have projects for you to do (basically mini fetch quests). The projects at each stronghold give bonuses and change the aesthetic of the stronghold too. At first the stronghold will be run down but with each project you do
votesFunny: it'll not only give you a bonus such as refueling your car or rearming you with fresh ammo but it'll transform the look of the stronghold from rundown slum to a place which is relatively nice to live in. It's nice to see your actions having a profound effect on the people living there.\n\nThe sound design for this game is excellent
commentsCount: with thumping engines
column16: ear shattering explosions and cool australian accents. It almost never lets you down
column17: they've really excelled here. My only complaint is the NPCs dotted around the map you can talk to
column18: they sound as if they got someone off the street to do a fake accent and babble some rubbish. Only part of the audio that's a let down. These NPCs are visually a letdown too because they all look very similar so the developers obviously didn't put too much effort into them.\n\nThe story isn't very compelling
column19: but then again Mad Max isn't famous for excellent story telling. It's mediocre
column20: except my main problem with it is that it ends too early. Just as the story missions start to get interesting the game ends abruptly. It took me 20-30 minutes to finish Act 5.\n\nMax can have his items and car upgraded and his skills unlocked via Scrap. You can find Scrap all over the world
column21: on dead bodies
column22: in forts and in scavenging locations. The upgrading system is very satisfying and you can definitely see yourself and your car progress in strength and capability. You can do up your car however you want
column23:
so you can have a fast but fragile car or a slow but tooled to the nines car and all inbetween. The choice is yours!


In conclusion:
+ Lots to do
+ Lots of places to explore
+ Art / Sound design is fantastic
+ Car combat is fun
+ Upgrading your car is very satisfying

- Very easy foot combat
- Car combat can get tedious
- Story ends abruptly
- Mini bosses all have the same fighting patterns
- Factions don't have unique combat moves

In conclusion Mad Max is a fun open world game with nice enviroments to explore. It will get repetitive at times

reviewText:
Follow the story of our hero, Max, as he seeks revenge against the bandit clan leader who stole his life away.  Mad Max has a lot of entertaining and fun aspects, but also contains a lot of boring and repetitive actions.  The story is decent, the controls are good, the graphics are very beautiful, and the environment is very well done.  The gameplay is rather simple, and even without upgrading your character's abilities or gear you can do very well in a fight with minimal experience, but the true enjoyment of this game does not occur on foot, but in your car.  With your trusty mechanic and harpoon shooter in the back, you take the wheel and fight head to head against other drivers, often with tricks up their sleeves.  The car combat is very fun, and it's worth upgrading your ride to handle some of the difficult challenges that await you in the wasteland.  Overall I would recommend it if you can find it for less than $25, but I would not say that it is worth much more than that unless you enjoy exploring a vast and open wasteland picking up scrap metal for hours on end.  A scavenging location can yield anywhere from 2 pieces of scrap to 50, but you need thousands of scrap to get a few of the upgrades for your car, and that takes a lot of time to grind out.

TLDR: Overall, a good game, but be prepared for a lot of grinding if you want 100% completion on it.
7.5/10

reviewText:
I tried so hard to like this game. I keep seeing all the reviews that rant and rave but I just can't say that this game is worth it. Its basically a copy and paste of shadows of mordor which I really liked so I assumed I would like this, but its god aweful. The beginning of the game makes you think you have all these options to pick but you start off only unlocking things because you need them in the story so it doesnt really feel like you are in control of getting upgrades and modifying your car for a bit. This happens later though and makes the game more fun. However, EVERYTHING you do feels super grindy. Go here fight the same guys, pick stuff up, go here and talk to this person, rinse and repeat. Again, shadows of mordor was basically the same thing but for some reason I liked it much better compared to this game. Also, everything you do feels super drawn out and takes forever to do. Maybe its supposed to be that way but every thing from loading screens, to even the movement of max in how if you accidentally aimed wrong while walking toward something like a ladder and or pressed the action button too soon, you had to re-adjust and try again. Fighting in the car gets old quick as sometimes you can feel helpless in your attempts to outrun or fight off even 2 or 3 cars. Next is the upgrades; if youre like me, you try and collect things and get upgrades before doing all of the main quests. What bugs me is that you dont even get the big v8 engine until  theres only like 2 main quests left, which leaves me sad because once I get the engine, I have nothing left to do.

Lastly, and for whatever reason I think Im one of the few people this has happened to; this game is buggy as ♥♥♥♥. My sound cuts out A LOT for different things. Whether its the engine or dialogue, or even general sound effects. And when this happens, my game stops loading the landscape so im left with weird piles of sand and ground that I can drive into and through. And sometimes the ground gives out and my car falls through the map. In addition, whenever this happens, I can't even fix it by going to the main menu or fast traveling because the game freezes when I try either of those options. So then I basically have to restart the game and watch the intro videos which arent that long but start to take forever once I have restarted the game like 4 times in 45 minutes of play.

So like I said, I really tried to like this game. I REALLY did; but sadly, I ♥♥♥♥in hate it. However, I don't neccesarily think the game doesnt deserve praise. People should still play it as it is pretty fun.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that will divide people. You'll like it or hate it. The game is loosely based on the recent Fury Road movie though the story and characters arent. (The Max in the game isnt modelled or voiced by Tom Hardy either). The game starts with Max being attacked by the warlord of Gastown, Scrotus, who steals Maxs Inteceptor and leaves him for dead. Max finds a hunchback mechanic called Chumbucket who helps Max to build a new car to get back at Scrotus. The Magnum Opus.

Good points:
-The Wasteland of the game and all the bizarre characters who inhabit it really capture the look and feel of the recent movie. The map is huge and your let loose to try and attack Scrotus' camps and structures to weaken his influence over the Wasteland.
- The Magnum Opus can be customized with different weapons like flamethrowers or a ramming grill for example as well as improving things like wheels and engine. Which is great because the Magnum Opus feels more like your own vehicle than some generic vehicle. The vehicle combat in game is a lot of fun too.
-The graphics in this game are great though you'll need a powerful rig to get them at their max. (No pun intended)

Bad points:
- This game has a lot of collectibles and you'll spend a lot of time gathering scrap to improve the Magnum Opus and Max.   This gets very repetitive and while i didnt mind it so much at first i was sick of it towards the end. Unfortunately since you need certain upgrades for some of the story missions it'sunavoidable to some extant.
- The combat is similar to that of other WB games like the Arkham series and Shadow of Mordor. It does feel a bit too easy at times as it's just one button to attack and another to counter. There isnt much enemy variety either.The one thing i liked about the combat was how visceral and real it looks. Rather than fancy acrobatics or martial arts the fights look more like a pub brawl and just as brutal.

While some might see the freedom to explore as you will with occasional story mission as a plus, i felt the game could have done with more structure as it would have helped it avoid becoming a repetitive experience. I have decided to recommend it because i did really enjoy the game for the first 15-20 hours and it still is a decent game overall. However if you cant stand loads of collectables and repetitive gameplay this might not be for you.

reviewText:
An accurate simulation of life in Australia, Mad Max has great driving physics, and beautiful graphics and sound design. Just listen to how the engine note of the Magnum Opus changes slightly with every upgrade or take Chumbucket's buggy rockclimbing and note the detailed suspension movement. This is a solid game.

This game plays great with a keyboard, but doesn't support controllers other than a 360 pad. Steering wheel support should have been a consideration with a game so heavily focused on driving.

Occasional UI glitches appear; Most of the time your mouse cursor will appear over gameplay, which can be solved by pausing and unpausing. Other times, the pause menu's back button will continue to be drawn over gameplay, which can be fixed by clicking it. Other than that, the game runs flawlessly.

The game looks somewhat difficult to mod, with all data files being stored in proprietary archives. As a singleplayer-only game, mods and user-generated content are key to its survival.

When i saw the waving flames of the car i just destroyed as the sun was setting behind the wasteland dunes, something moved inside me.
When i caught into a sandstorm, i knew it was love at first sight.

If you want to play a game with a vast open world (do not expect many changes of scenery. Its a wasteland), car chasing, scavenging (yep, maggots are back on the menu boys), car upgrading and brutal fighting (batman fighting gameplay) this game is for you. Honestly, the way car reacts on the sand, the sound of the engines, everything is wonderful. The way the scenery changes inside a sandstorm, is something that you have never encountered before. In general what do you do in the game now (in case you wonder)

1) you scavenge small camps and abandoned vehicles like ships (i guess there was a sea over there) and you also find relics of another time that reminds you how it was once, and they really add to the feeling
2)Destroy larger camps with enemies.
3)Destroy big camps where you have to beat the local boss of the area
4)participate in death races (while in open world, you can steal other cars in order to use them in these races)
5)Help helpless people by giving them water, in exchange for information
6) as you cross the wasteland, random gangs will attack you, or an enemy convoy will pass, that you could attack and destroy in order to gain materials and  parts.
7) Game has soft borders. Means that there isn't any invinsible wall that will tell you its over". Want to drive into nothingness? Go ahead. More wasteland for you. You might find something useful
date: or you can die there. And yes

they will run away. Its surviving afterl all is it not?

Want to know the best part? I play this game for 7 hours and i haven't even unlock the half of the map. I am just inside a tiny part of it.

Do you like the concept of Mad Max? Buy it."

reviewText:
Very nice and decently sized story mode, but the most fun I had in the game was upgrading the Magnum Opus and fooling around in the world.  Graphics are great, and the game is ♥♥♥♥ easy to run.   I got this game during the winter sale in order to hold me off form playing Just Casue 3 until I upgraded my PC more to run it, and I absolutely love it.  Highly reccomend this game to fans of the Mad Max series or someone just looking for a great open world game.

Pros:
-Great Story mode, decently long
-Weapon mechanics on cars
-Wide variety of enemies
-Driving is a breeze
-Large map with different terrains suited for different vehicles
-Beautiful graphics and surprisingly easy to run
-Extremely large variety of customization for cars and Max
-Camps require strategy to infiltrate and defeat
-This game is heaven for those who like to hoard items

Cons-
-Top Dogs" and other bosses insanely easy to defeat
-Random encounters with enemy drivers can get annoying if you're trying to traverse long distances
-Fighting is a bit too mindless since you mainly use two buttons to attack and parry
-F*CKING SANDSTORMS

THE VERDICT:
I loved this game.  It runs flawlessly and there is no feeling of being drowned in DLC to get the most out of Mad Max.. very surprising seeing that this was made by the same company that made Arkham Knight for PC.  Overall I am very impressed.  This game has made me want to get into the Mad Max movies
date: considering I only watched Fury Road.  I rate this game a 95/100."

reviewText:
This game blew me away. The story, the characters, the environments, the customisation all on point. For a movie-game adaptation this is the best I've experienced so far. I haven't seen any Mad Max films but I picked this game up from {LINK REMOVED}♥♥♥.com for $17 AUD(roughly $12 USD) and blasted through it. I pretty much played it non-stop for 60+ hours over the past 4 or 5 days and I've never enjoyed wasting my spare time on a video game more than this beside MGS V: TTP(Which I no-life'd for 120 hours over 3 weeks).

Points of reference:
Magnum Opus - Car
War Boys - Enemies
Scrotus - Main antagonist
Chumbucket(Chum) - Companion


Overview

You are left for dead by Scrotus and he's has taken your Interceptor. Max is on a quest to rebuild a car capable of crossing The Plains of Silence.

At the beginning of the game you are buddied with a dog which I'll go over more later, and hunchback called Chumbucket which I'll also go over later. Max is on a quest to rebuild a car capable of crossing The Plains of Silence. Throughout the game Max and Chum build a new car; The Magnum Opus and upgrade it for attack, defense and speed. The game is set in 5 regions, 4 of which have strongholds which can be upgraded and used as fast travel points. The 4 regions with strongholds have a threat level and by doing an assortment of activities like taking over enemy strongholds, destroying territory markers and clearing minefields you will lower the threat level thus lowering the War Boy presence (The dog is used to find the land mines in the minefields). The strongholds each have a leader who gives you side missions. You'll also be able to upgrade Max with new combat abilities, attire and even hairstyles. The Magnum Opus can be upgraded with 5 different body types and various armaments and defenses like flame throwers, seeking rockets and a harpoon launcher. Of course with this game heavily revolving around Max's car, there are racing activities to do across the map called Death Runs. The Death Runs have a variety of different types of races such as normal races, timebomb races Chumbucket is with you throughout the entire game and stays in the car. His main purpose is to repair the car and initiate conversation with Max so driving around doesn't seem empty. He's a great character and fits well into the story.

Combat System

To be honest I didn't know what to expect from this game. Warner Bros. has reused the combat systems from the Batman Arkham games and Shadow of Mordor, games which I both enjoyed heavily(besides SoM which I haven't started yet). I think the combat system works really well for a game like Mad Max but at times it just felt like a big chore having to constantly press X(LMB) to attatck and Y(RMB) to counter all the time. Around camps and loot locations where you'll fight War Boys, there are often temporary weapon pick ups that break after a few hits or will drop when you enter a vehicle. I find using a game pad more comfortable for a games like this, especially since the majority of gameplay is made up of CQC and driving.

Conclusion

Now I'm not a long-time Mad Max film guy but I have been meaning to go watch Mad Max: Fury Road but I hadn't had time when the movie was in cinemas. I think the narrative is well written and kept me interested throughout the game. I became distracted from the main story for a while, grinding loot locations and collecting scrap metal  as scrap metal which is the games currency. The customisation of Max and the Magnum Opus was very diverse, as well as the enemies and enemy vehicles. Characters were well voiced and unique as well a balanced level of Australian and American accents. Overall I'd rate this game a 9.5 out of 10 and woould definitely recommend it to anyone, Mad Max fan or no.

+Good amount of content.
+Combat is fun (subjective, but it feels meaty to me).
+Very well optimized

-Game seems very easy, even without combat upgrades I rarely had a problem.
-Can be grindy in parts trying to get scrap" for upgrades.
-Don't see much reason to use other cars.
-Only 3 lengths of beards

reviewText:
This game blew me away. The story, the characters, the environments, the customisation all on point. For a movie-game adaptation this is the best I've experienced so far. I haven't seen any Mad Max films but I picked this game up from {LINK REMOVED}♥♥♥.com for $17 AUD(roughly $12 USD) and blasted through it. I pretty much played it non-stop for 60+ hours over the past 4 or 5 days and I've never enjoyed wasting my spare time on a video game more than this beside MGS V: TTP(Which I no-life'd for 120 hours over 3 weeks).

Points of reference:
Magnum Opus - Car
War Boys - Enemies
Scrotus - Main antagonist
Chumbucket(Chum) - Companion


Overview

You are left for dead by Scrotus and he's has taken your Interceptor. Max is on a quest to rebuild a car capable of crossing The Plains of Silence.

At the beginning of the game you are buddied with a dog which I'll go over more later, and hunchback called Chumbucket which I'll also go over later. Max is on a quest to rebuild a car capable of crossing The Plains of Silence. Throughout the game Max and Chum build a new car; The Magnum Opus and upgrade it for attack, defense and speed. The game is set in 5 regions, 4 of which have strongholds which can be upgraded and used as fast travel points. The 4 regions with strongholds have a threat level and by doing an assortment of activities like taking over enemy strongholds, destroying territory markers and clearing minefields you will lower the threat level thus lowering the War Boy presence (The dog is used to find the land mines in the minefields). The strongholds each have a leader who gives you side missions. You'll also be able to upgrade Max with new combat abilities, attire and even hairstyles. The Magnum Opus can be upgraded with 5 different body types and various armaments and defenses like flame throwers, seeking rockets and a harpoon launcher. Of course with this game heavily revolving around Max's car, there are racing activities to do across the map called Death Runs. The Death Runs have a variety of different types of races such as normal races, timebomb races Chumbucket is with you throughout the entire game and stays in the car. His main purpose is to repair the car and initiate conversation with Max so driving around doesn't seem empty. He's a great character and fits well into the story.

Combat System

To be honest I didn't know what to expect from this game. Warner Bros. has reused the combat systems from the Batman Arkham games and Shadow of Mordor, games which I both enjoyed heavily(besides SoM which I haven't started yet). I think the combat system works really well for a game like Mad Max but at times it just felt like a big chore having to constantly press X(LMB) to attatck and Y(RMB) to counter all the time. Around camps and loot locations where you'll fight War Boys, there are often temporary weapon pick ups that break after a few hits or will drop when you enter a vehicle. I find using a game pad more comfortable for a games like this, especially since the majority of gameplay is made up of CQC and driving.

Conclusion

Now I'm not a long-time Mad Max film guy but I have been meaning to go watch Mad Max: Fury Road but I hadn't had time when the movie was in cinemas. I think the narrative is well written and kept me interested throughout the game. I became distracted from the main story for a while, grinding loot locations and collecting scrap metal  as scrap metal which is the games currency. The customisation of Max and the Magnum Opus was very diverse, as well as the enemies and enemy vehicles. Characters were well voiced and unique as well a balanced level of Australian and American accents. Overall I'd rate this game a 9.5 out of 10 and woould definitely recommend it to anyone, Mad Max fan or no.

reviewText:
Mad Max is one of my favourite games of 2015.

I was pleased to hear prior to purchase that the game was very well optimised, on a GTX 970 I can run everything on max settings and still maintain around 105fps. The story is really well done and resembles the same atmosphere felt in the film.

The characters are all fantastic and the voice acting is really one of the best I've ever seen in a video game.

Pros:
1. Probably the most well optimised game I've played ever.
2. Excellent setting, there's lots of post-apocalyptic games but none that focus on cars and car modifcations to the extent that Mad Max does.
3. Upgrade system is truly wide an deep. Not only do you have different tiers of unlocks for everything on your car but also for Max himself. There are also some hidden unlocks provided after completion of the story that were a very nice touch.
4. Combat system is basic but very satisfying with the upgrades you can give Max to give him more of an edge while fighting.
5. Open world do as you like. You can in theory do a bunch of challenges that gets Max to highest rank before completing the majority of the story and stronghold missions. This leaves you with a very easy path to finishing the game though.

Cons:
1. The game can get a little repetitive with scavenging from camps, finishing top dogs, oil camps and stank gum but these things are ofset by the long term rewards you get for completing the areas.
2. Stronghold missions tended to be a lot less fun and interesting than the story missions. Sometimes story missions unlock upgrades where you already have the next tier of upgrade.
3. Once you finish the game if you're still trying to finish up the upgrades to your V8 (final cost for all the V8s is well into > 10000 scrap) scrap tends to be harder to comeby in larger amounts. I also found that mobile scrap transports are very rare in the same limiting your ability to find them on the roads.

All in all I loved Mad Max from start to finish. It doesn't have any annoying second launcher or DRM, you have the option to get WBPlay (ie its not forced down your throat) and overall is a well rounded game.

reviewText:
First impression:

Really good actually. Didn't expect to enjoy the game as much as I do so far. The atmosphere is great. The visuals, audio/music and voice acting are great.  They've captured the world of Mad Max perfectly. Good driving mixed with Arkham Asylum combat and some survival game aspects. Fun.

On a technical side, this game is the best PC port this year. A gazillion graphical settings and in has rock solid frame times no stuttering and great performance at 4k. It's a shame this game came out on the same day of MGS V. It deserves much more attention that it will get.

Will update once I am several hours into the game.

EDITED: After 30 h of gameplay I can safely say that I am still really enjoying the game. Upgrading the cars is fun. The gameplay mechanics, while simple, do their job. The atmosphere is pure Mad Max. I can see myself spending a lot of time with this game.

reviewText:
The first thing you should know about Mad Max before you buy it, is that it borrows a lot from other games.

There are camps that you can capture, that pay out resources occasionally. Before you take these camps, it is ideal to scout out their defensive features, such as snipers or flame thrower traps. You do this by standing nearby, somewhere out of sight, with your binoculars which will mark these defensive features for you (much like in far cry 3, except it does not mark individual enemies). Each of these camps also has a myriad of minor objectives to complete, such as finding all the scrap, historical relics, or whatever other random things are scattered around the camp, or destroying insignias. Once you do this, you get a nice shiny 100% on that camp.

The melee combat is fairly fun, though a bit more weighty than some might like. However, it is the same system as assasins creed, or the batman games. You will spam (light attacks) or hold (heavy attacks) the x button, and press the y button to parry (ideally at the right time, so you have a better counter). Some attacks can't be parried, so you will have to roll out of the way.

The driving itself (aside from boosts, weapons, and other such things, of course) is fairly similar to GTA V's as far as weight goes. The vehicle combat is also pretty fun, with a fairly large variety of enemies and tools at your disposal.

There are also a few survival aspects, such as a canteen you want to keep filled with water so that you can heal (you don't regenerate health), or cars burning gasoline (which can be scavenged at many places on the map).


Overall, I found it to be very fun for the first few hours. However, if you have played a lot of Assasin's Creed, or any of the Batman games, the melee system may be a bit more dull for you. If you have played either, I'd suggest picking it up on a sale, as the world of Mad Max is still very fun to drive around in and experience. If you like vehicle combat in games, or generally just driving around and exploring the map, this is definitely worth considering.

reviewText:
Loved it, normally I hate racing games but this one didn’t force you to just race but do a few mad max style extra things. Many people have compared to the batman games and after playing them would agree the fist fights are very similar, however max has much more. So…

Pros; Great cinematic graphics loved the lens flair and some of the scenery shots you can take. A bit of base building and stranger. Massive open world with plenty to do and enough diversity that you don’t feel like to you have to do a section of the game you hate. Nice story although very Mad Max with very little deep concept it had nice array of characters to meet.

Cons; Game can be a grind at some points especially when trying to progress the story as not grinding can make some missions very hard (could be a pro if you like that kind of thing). Some of the experience elements I thought were wasted especially if you can bypass them in other ways (ammo, water, fuel).

Overall though I would say a good game and was a bargain in the last winter sale.

reviewText:
A fun yet repetitious complement to the latest Mad Max movie.  They did an awesome job capturing the aesthetics of the film, and building a beautiful game that feels like an extension.

Absolutely loved leveling up and turning my ride into a badass war machine.  The vehicle combat was a blast, and was the only part of the game that didn't get old towards the end.

Fist fighting combat was very satisfying (like Batman without gadgets), but lack of enemy variety made all the fights feel the same.  However, still a visceral and enjoyable experience when you beat down a group of 20+ guys.

Great fun.

8 / 10

reviewText:
I'm going to write a little initial mini review here. I don't really think that at 8 hours in, I should write a comprehensive review of the game and so consider that before you read.

But I have a few things to say and so here they are.

The intro to the game is wonderful, very well done. A lot better than Witcher 3 and most games that have been released in the last year. Very artsy, very well done.

The game itself, the story, I like it. I'm not a big fan of the Mad Max series. I saw the first film, that is it. But I like the characters, the narrative, the story.

The thing I like best about the game is that for me, this is the first game that actually really looks great in 4K. I mean the difference between 1080 and 4K in this game is very dramatic and I am playing it in 4K with a single  GTX970 and getting 60-70 FPS solid. The game is very well optimized. I get 144 FPS solid in the game with 970 SLI.

Only a couple of negatives to report. My Logitech conroller won't work in the game, and this seems to not be an isolated problem. The other issue is that there is no walk/run toggle in the game. You pretty much cannot walk.

4 out of 5, will keep playing and come back and update the review.

reviewText:
This review is a bit biased as I'm a huge Mad Max fan.

That said, this game is still amazing. Maybe you've read other reviews that say it's the most open world open world action adventure action adventure trope game. Yes, it's open world, yes, it's an action adventure game, but let me ask those reviewers one thing? How else would you have preferred a Mad Max game? The primary focus in Mad Max is vehicular combat across the vast open terrain of the wasteland. Yes, Max has free flow combat similar to other WB published games in the past few years, but he isn't Batman or the guy from Shadow of Mordor. Max is, to an extent, a regular ol' dude with some emotional issues pertaining to his past and the fact that he is a shell of his former self. Point is, Avalanche made the Mad Max game that Mad Max fans had always wanted; so f * * k the reviewers that say the game is repetitive or lacking. Have they even seen a Mad Max film? The stories aren't exactly as complex as Metal Gear Solid, which I think is another reason why Mad Max is being overlooked, the fact that MGSV came out the same day. The Mad Max stories are rather simple with an even simpler context, global economic crisises and nuclear warfare.

Now that I got my little rant out of the way, I can actually talk about the game. Max is driving his beloved Interceptor through the Wasteland, trying to reach the Plains of Silence in hopes of finding a more civilized society. Unfortunately, Scaborous Scrotus, son of Immortan Joe, succeeds in vehicular combat with his mighty Land Mower and Max is forced to jump out, ending up fighting Scrotus himself. After apparently killing Scrotus, Max finds himself somewhere unknown and befriends Scrotus' dog. Together, they find Chumbucket, a hunchback mechanic. This is where the story really takes off as Chum and Max plot to build a Magnum Opus, a car better, stronger, and superior in each way to the Interceptor. Chum and Max travel throughout the Wasteland, assisting faction leaders and progressing throughout the story to upgrade car parts and Max's own gear. The story is actually more interesting than just that, but I don't wanna spoil it.

Gameplay, as noted in my rant earlier, is similar to recent action adventure games. Besides comparing it to recent WB games, I could also compare it to Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood, as you invade camps (Forts) and complete a primary objective in order to take control of it where your allies will then be there. Also the strongholds where you meet various community" leaders. You do favors for these leaders (i.e. side missions that actually have plot) and are then able to upgrade these strongholds by collecting project parts at various scavenging locations or camps scattered throughout the wasteland. These locations could be massive forts or hidden caves

reviewText:
This is one of the best mediocre games I have played in a long time. It really doesn't bring anything new or exciting to the table in terms of game-play and mechanics. It has a lot of grind to it for completionists. It's just not that special.

HOWEVER, it absolutely nails the mayhem and insanity of the universe portrayed by the Mad Max movies, especially (and obviously) Fury Road. Do you want to play a Mad Max movie? Do you want to explore that world a bit and see more of the wastelands? Do you want to crash, blow up, grind, and otherwise wreck a lot of cars? Then I think you'll enjoy the hell out of this game.

It does all that and it is gorgeous while doing so. The game runs incredibly smooth, and though it almost feels like a console game meant for being played with a controller, I found I preferred playing it with keyboard and mouse (I feel the same way about the Arkham games).

8/10. Most mediocre games are just mediocre. This one is fun as hell. :)

reviewText: What a surprise! The best action post-apo game since Rage".The game is great on so many levels. First of all it works great (nice optimalization) ! 60 FPS as a starting point gives smoothness especially needed in car chases (btw car mechanics are cool). Incredible vistas! They are rather minimalistic in details but this is a good thing. The feeling of isolation is palpable here. Also the different color moods are fantastic! Another good thing is hand to hand combat. It's got batman's formula and It's enjoyable. The story is ok with many cool looking characters but don't expect to much. The downside is too busy map. The core of the game is grinding for scrap but with two good mechanics like driving/combat you don't mind doing so. Overall I give it 9/10 score-(if you don't like post-apo then 8/10)  great fluid car-combat gameplay with beautiful scenery!"

reviewText:
2 hours in so far so good. OK looking graphics but runs very smoothly at 60fps with everything maxed. Xbox controller working well but I have not tried it with kb and mouse.

The map is huge, with lots to do but this may get a bit repetative as far as I can tell. It feels a bit like Shadow of Mordor and Assassin Creed with similar combat to the Arkham series of games, but with slightly different controls. Combat and driving flows well using controller and is easy to pick up and master.

Story is interesting so far with plenty of upgrades and stuff to earn through gameplay. It looks quite like Rage but it has more emphasis on hand to hand and car combat. I imagine it will be a game that is easy to 100% but rather time consuming. As I said I think the side missions and collectibles could be tedious but I am enjoying it all so far.

I paid £20 and I am very happy with my purchase. Certainly worthy a punt.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Ejoyable so far. I'm a big fan of post-apocalyptic games.

PROS:
+ Graphics.
+ Optimization(seriously, it's sick. 60 FPS with everything on max, 1440p. GTX 970).
+ Voice acting.
+ Story(haven't got far at all yet, but I like what I've seen so far).
+ Ground combat(I like this kind of combat system--aka Batman Arkham X combat style--, so if you don't this might be a con).
+ Car combat

CONS:
- No real innovation(capturing/razing strongholds ala Ubisoft isn't anything new and is quite frankly rather boring. Same goes for flying up in the balloon to scout, although this gives quite the view which is great).
- Car handlig(might be just me, but I don't like the slight delay between the pressing of the steering button and the actual steering of the car).
- So far, no sniper rifle outside of the car(to use the sniper rifle, you gotta be in the back of the car. As I haven't finished the game yet, I might get a portable sniper rifle further in - although I suspect I won't).
- Some potentially game breaking bugs(like having looted a place you need to loot later on in a quest, thus making looting that place again during questing impossible).

If you enjoy the Mad Max franchise, post-apocalyptic games or open-world games, you might find this fun. Thus far, I'm going to give this game 7/10. I will probably update the review later on as I get further into the game, might add or remove some points or pros/cons.

Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Absolutely flawlessly optimized game. The only thing that I can literally say bad about this game's performance is a couple glitches here and there (fell through the map once, car span wildly into the sky another time) that don't even happen that often, once every 8+ hours. As for the length of the game, it took me 24 hours of play time (23 hours, 53 minutes to be exact) to complete all of the story missions & lower the threat level for Jeet's territory to null. The game counts that to be around 40% of the game completed, I'm sure the rest being all of the scavenging locations and whatnot. This game will without a doubt last you more than 48 hours of playtime to 100% it. I picked this game up for $23, and to give a general summary of the purchase, was well god damn worth every penny. Never got bored of it through my three or four binge sessions, either, a nice touch. Only complaint really though is that the combat is basically mash X (or square, for PS controllers), press Y if you see an indicator to counter an attack, and for unavoidable attacks, lunge out of the way. A slight complaint, too, is that the controls are actually smoothed, an effect similar to mouse acceleration, unfortunately, I didn't find a setting to turn this behavior off. Fortunately, after the first hour or two, you will get used to it and you won't feel it thereafter.

As for the optimization (because it needs it's own paragraph): you can probably run this on a toaster at lowest settings, which really speaks something. My mediocre cards (2x R9 270x, 4GB VRAM, OC edition) can run this game at 60FPS+ with every single setting maxed out with vsync on. In comparison, I get ~60FPS in BF4 on low-medium settings. To summarize, this game is an absolutely optimized beast.

Completely would recommend this game, seen the movies or not.

reviewText: If you've played any of the Batman games, the gameplay will be familiar.  Mad Max is a combination of driving and 3D beat-em up.  The action is over the top.  The story is not quite as involved as the aforementioned title but then again this is post-apocalyptic wasteland.  Such a place in reality would be large, dangerous, and empty.  Drama would be a luxury that no one trying to survive could afford.  In that sense, a sparse story fits the locale.  The place may be a large sandbox but the scenery is absolutely gorgeous.  In over 60 hrs of play I've only had two CTD's so the game is well coded.  Recommended.

reviewText:
Mad MaxAn open-world third person action/adventure game that is also a license game.
This game takes place prior to the events in Mad Max: Fury Road.
Most critics dislike it, but most of the public love it.
I give it an 8/10.

Gameplay
Movement, and Exploration
Average on-foot movement speed, with a sprint that I wished was much faster.
Simple platforming. Anything yellow can be interacted with - ladders, cramped entrances, climbable areas, etc.
You can fall a fair bit before you take any damage, but walk slowly if you jump from high up.
You can insta-die if you fall too far, but it's pretty forgiving.
Health can be regained by eating old dog food, or eating maggots from certain corpses. The main way you regain health is by drinking from your water canteen. The water canteen does not carry that much water but can be refilled from water-stills that refill regularly.
Unlock the map by going up on a balloon where you must use your binoculars to mark stuff individually. I like this as it's more interactive than alternatives. If you missed something then putting away your bino's lets you look for stuff with a much wider field of vision. Once used, these ballon sites become fast travel points.
All locations have a visible checklist of stuff to collect - scrap, historic relics, ammo.
Most locations on the map are simply for looting -scrap, ammo, fuel, water, collectable historical relics- but are still very varied, and mostly unique.
Enemy camps can be liberated, but require you to clear perimeter defenses, kill defenders, and completing an objective (either killing enemies, or blowing up oil derricks/tanks).
Once liberated camps give you scrap ever few minutes.
Beware of minefields - they can be cleared by using a special vehicle, and your dog.
There are storms in this game! These are terrifying -but sound and look wonderful!
They come in two types; Sandstorms that kill you by hitting you with debris, and Lightning-storms that kill you with scary lightning.
Staying out in them is dangerous but let you find boxes of scrap. Outrunning them is impossible (but you can try!) but if you reach a liberated camp it ends immediately.

Progression, and Upgrades
Scrap is the main currency of the game. Get it by looting dead enemies, destroying vehicles, and looting locations.
Scrap is used to upgrade your car and gear -including combat skills
Allied Strongholds can be thought of as your bases. By completing side missions and finding certain project parts you can build things in them that do important things when completed - such as fully refuel your car, restore health, fill your canteen. The best project is the one that auto-collects scrap from destroyed vehicles - prioritize this!
If you capture a certain enemy vehicle you can return it to Strongholds for a huge scrap bonus.
Completing challanges (which are easy, eg, killing 100 enemies, destroying 30 vehicles, etc.) gives you Griffa Tokens which you can spend by visiting a mystic named Griffa to increase passive stuff like health, or scrap collection.
In order to unlock upgrades you must also decrease the threat levels in areas of the maps. This is done by killing snipers, toppling 'scarecrow' towers, liberating camps, clearing minefields, and by attacking and destroying moving conveys of enemies (which is particularly fun, and lets you loot powerful stat-boosting hood ornaments)
On-Foot Combat
Pretty basic (which I hold as a positive) at the start - Arkham-Style.
One button to attack -hold it down for a heavy attack).
Parry, or dodge attacks.
You can pick up weapons, but they break really quickly.
You can pick up shivs to quickly execute dazed enemies.
Purchasable skills allow you to use shivs in more situations, and other cool things.
You have a shotgun with very limited ammo for emergencies!
Car Combat
Very good  car combat mechanics!
Primary means of dealing damage is to hit cars with your car-either side-bashes or frontal impacts (boost is important!)
You get a -unlimited, but requires recharging- harpoon to pull off car parts, drivers, structures (towers, doors/walls), enemy troops, and drivers!
Use your shotgun to explode exposed fuel tanks, and boarders.
You also get a Thunderpoon, a rocket launcher.
Different classes of enemy vehicles with different dangers - boarders, flamethrowers, ramming.
If your car looses all health you must exit within 5 seconds, then survive on-foot until repairs are done.
Can repair when not in motion.
You can use a sniper rifle to pick of snipers or damage camp defenses at range. You can drive slowly while using it.Audio
Excellent overall audio quality.
The cars sound very good, from the whiny V6 to the throaty V8.
Explosions sound very good.
Flamethrowers roar!
The storms sound absolutely terrifying!
The voice-acting is good, with a smal variety of accents - with Max having an australian voice-actor.
Visual
The framerate was stable - for me, on my mid level gaming PC on High graphics settings, it was +/- 48 FPS
The game is beautifull!
Flames, and explosions look really good.
The ruins of the world look like actual ruins - rusty and broken.
Each area of the map is visually different, and each is thematic! (eg, Ex-Ocean floor, a polluted junkyard, etc.)
Story
In the opening cinematic you kill the Big-Bad-Guy"

reviewText:
Pros:
* The open world in Mad Max is really really well done. It's dark. It's brutal. And it's all about survival.
* Graphics are just superb and well optimized. Avalanche Studios has outdone itself.
* Unique style of game. It's fresh, creative, and fun.
* Melee combat
* Upgrades for Max and his Magnum Opus are addictive to go after.
* Car combat is really well done and fun. Hijacking convoys is very satisfying.


Cons:
* Story is not very appealing.
* No attachment or affinity to any character in the game. Almost dull.
* Glitches in the game at random times make it sometimes frustrating.
* Strongholds, camps, and side missions can get very repetitive, if not boring.
* Jumping in the game is so silly and useless. The interact button can leap over major obstacles, whereas the jump button can barely jump a foot high. Just straight silly.
* While fun, melee combat is OP. In fact considering low ammo you often don't have a choice, which leads to repetition.
* You only have a shotgun as personal weapon. Most weaponry is in your car, with limited ammo.
* Smashing button for interactions in a game is so year 2000...


Overall : 70/100. Worth a buy on huge Steam sale.

reviewText:
Mad Max is a completely competent open-world action game with a story that is  short and shallow, but very Mad Max.

Mad Max ticks all the open-world action check boxes. You destroy towers (scarecrows) and take over forts to gain influence in each region. You fight against other factions in a Batman-light-style hand to hand combat and an excellent vehicle-combat that includes harpoons, thunderpoons, flame-throwers, depth-charges, ramming bars, boarding spikes, and wheel-shredders.

In addition to playing through main missions (of which there are only a handful - really, by the time you realize there is a narrative, the story is in its last few missions), there are a lot of side missions that you will run for various demented characters throughout the wastelands.

The game is beautiful. It also performs very well, showing what you can accomplish when you put effort into your platform optimization. On an i7-4790k with 16GB RAM and NVIDIA GTX 970 SLI system, we see consistent framerates in excess of 140fps at 1920x1080. Even with almost every setting maxed-out and while doing a live streaming session (usually disastrous for framerate on an SLI system due to the way streaming applications capture frames), we hit well-above 100fps.

Other than a shallow and fairly short story, Mad Max doesn't suffer any great failures on any one aspect. Yet, it does not quite seem to be greater than the sum of its parts. It is very entertaining. It has a lot of thoroughly enjoyable aspects, of which vehicle combat is probably the best. But it is also wears out its welcome, by the end. You've eventually had enough sand, screaming crazies running at you, and flame-shooting cars side-ramming you. You've had enough scrap collecting and busy-work -- which this game is riddled with.

It is competent; not groundbreaking.

But this should not be a bad thing. And it also does help us to understand why the reviews have been all over the place for this title. It isn't mind-blowing, but it isn't bad. I bought this game for just over half price, just before launch. Due to the discounts we saw everywhere, I was certain they were trying to dump the game while they could and had low expectations. Instead, I found a thoroughly good game for which I have no quarrel having paid half price. At full AAA launch price? Well, I'm not sure it would quite have lived up to that . . . but I wouldn't be disgruntled over it. I would be interested in a sequel to this title, if they make one. They have a solid foundation, here.

It is difficult for me to say that I do or do not recommend this game. I enjoyed it and feel it was worth what I paid for it. I would not be upset, but perhaps a little disappointed, if I'd paid full price. So, ultimately, I'd have to suggest that if you are a huge Mad Max fan and you can't stop playing open-world games, it may be worth full price. If you just love Mad Max or just love open-world games, then pick it up for half price and you'll probably be very satisfied and surprised.

Below is the first of a nine part 31hr live-stream playthrough of Mad Max:
https://youtu.be/36oo8PD0REY

reviewText:
Mad Max is one of my favorite film series, and this game really feels like Mad Max to me.

There is plenty of stuff to do although it gets really repetitive really fast.  You spend most of your time grinding for scrap for the numerous upgrades for your car as well as Max himself,  these come in the form of demolishing enemy camps, searching old wrecks and buildings, clearing minefields, etc.  The story is good but short and it forces you to complete a lot of these scrap grinds in order to upgrade enough to advance.

The melee combat feels a lot like the Batman games, and the whole game plays a lot like Shadow of Mordor.  The game is really repetitive with it's tasks but it is very satisfying driving around in your overloaded car getting into road battles and fist fights.

I would highly recommend it for fans of Mad Max but I could see how some people would get bored with it easily.

reviewText: If you've played any of the Batman games, the gameplay will be familiar.  Mad Max is a combination of driving and 3D beat-em up.  The action is over the top.  The story is not quite as involved as the aforementioned title but then again this is post-apocalyptic wasteland.  Such a place in reality would be large, dangerous, and empty.  Drama would be a luxury that no one trying to survive could afford.  In that sense, a sparse story fits the locale.  The place may be a large sandbox but the scenery is absolutely gorgeous.  In over 60 hrs of play I've only had two CTD's so the game is well coded.  Recommended.

reviewText:
Mad MaxAn open-world third person action/adventure game that is also a license game.
This game takes place prior to the events in Mad Max: Fury Road.
Most critics dislike it, but most of the public love it.
I give it an 8/10.

Gameplay
Movement, and Exploration
Average on-foot movement speed, with a sprint that I wished was much faster.
Simple platforming. Anything yellow can be interacted with - ladders, cramped entrances, climbable areas, etc.
You can fall a fair bit before you take any damage, but walk slowly if you jump from high up.
You can insta-die if you fall too far, but it's pretty forgiving.
Health can be regained by eating old dog food, or eating maggots from certain corpses. The main way you regain health is by drinking from your water canteen. The water canteen does not carry that much water but can be refilled from water-stills that refill regularly.
Unlock the map by going up on a balloon where you must use your binoculars to mark stuff individually. I like this as it's more interactive than alternatives. If you missed something then putting away your bino's lets you look for stuff with a much wider field of vision. Once used, these ballon sites become fast travel points.
All locations have a visible checklist of stuff to collect - scrap, historic relics, ammo.
Most locations on the map are simply for looting -scrap, ammo, fuel, water, collectable historical relics- but are still very varied, and mostly unique.
Enemy camps can be liberated, but require you to clear perimeter defenses, kill defenders, and completing an objective (either killing enemies, or blowing up oil derricks/tanks).
Once liberated camps give you scrap ever few minutes.
Beware of minefields - they can be cleared by using a special vehicle, and your dog.
There are storms in this game! These are terrifying -but sound and look wonderful!
They come in two types; Sandstorms that kill you by hitting you with debris, and Lightning-storms that kill you with scary lightning.
Staying out in them is dangerous but let you find boxes of scrap. Outrunning them is impossible (but you can try!) but if you reach a liberated camp it ends immediately.

Progression, and Upgrades
Scrap is the main currency of the game. Get it by looting dead enemies, destroying vehicles, and looting locations.
Scrap is used to upgrade your car and gear -including combat skills
Allied Strongholds can be thought of as your bases. By completing side missions and finding certain project parts you can build things in them that do important things when completed - such as fully refuel your car, restore health, fill your canteen. The best project is the one that auto-collects scrap from destroyed vehicles - prioritize this!
If you capture a certain enemy vehicle you can return it to Strongholds for a huge scrap bonus.
Completing challanges (which are easy, eg, killing 100 enemies, destroying 30 vehicles, etc.) gives you Griffa Tokens which you can spend by visiting a mystic named Griffa to increase passive stuff like health, or scrap collection.
In order to unlock upgrades you must also decrease the threat levels in areas of the maps. This is done by killing snipers, toppling 'scarecrow' towers, liberating camps, clearing minefields, and by attacking and destroying moving conveys of enemies (which is particularly fun, and lets you loot powerful stat-boosting hood ornaments)
On-Foot Combat
Pretty basic (which I hold as a positive) at the start - Arkham-Style.
One button to attack -hold it down for a heavy attack).
Parry, or dodge attacks.
You can pick up weapons, but they break really quickly.
You can pick up shivs to quickly execute dazed enemies.
Purchasable skills allow you to use shivs in more situations, and other cool things.
You have a shotgun with very limited ammo for emergencies!
Car Combat
Very good  car combat mechanics!
Primary means of dealing damage is to hit cars with your car-either side-bashes or frontal impacts (boost is important!)
You get a -unlimited, but requires recharging- harpoon to pull off car parts, drivers, structures (towers, doors/walls), enemy troops, and drivers!
Use your shotgun to explode exposed fuel tanks, and boarders.
You also get a Thunderpoon, a rocket launcher.
Different classes of enemy vehicles with different dangers - boarders, flamethrowers, ramming.
If your car looses all health you must exit within 5 seconds, then survive on-foot until repairs are done.
Can repair when not in motion.
You can use a sniper rifle to pick of snipers or damage camp defenses at range. You can drive slowly while using it.Audio
Excellent overall audio quality.
The cars sound very good, from the whiny V6 to the throaty V8.
Explosions sound very good.
Flamethrowers roar!
The storms sound absolutely terrifying!
The voice-acting is good, with a smal variety of accents - with Max having an australian voice-actor.
Visual
The framerate was stable - for me, on my mid level gaming PC on High graphics settings, it was +/- 48 FPS
The game is beautifull!
Flames, and explosions look really good.
The ruins of the world look like actual ruins - rusty and broken.
Each area of the map is visually different, and each is thematic! (eg, Ex-Ocean floor, a polluted junkyard, etc.)
Story
In the opening cinematic you kill the Big-Bad-Guy"
date: but lose your car in the process. You meet
recommended: and begin to work with a hunchbacked mechanic named Chumbucket. The story then revolves around the two of you building the perfect car
hoursPlayed: the Magnum Opus. Everything you do is to aimed at fulfilling the goal of getting your car in a good enough condition to cross something Max calls the Plains of SIlence. Along the way you meet plenty of characters that you'll either kill

reviewText:
Pros:
* The open world in Mad Max is really really well done. It's dark. It's brutal. And it's all about survival.
* Graphics are just superb and well optimized. Avalanche Studios has outdone itself.
* Unique style of game. It's fresh, creative, and fun.
* Melee combat
* Upgrades for Max and his Magnum Opus are addictive to go after.
* Car combat is really well done and fun. Hijacking convoys is very satisfying.


Cons:
* Story is not very appealing.
* No attachment or affinity to any character in the game. Almost dull.
* Glitches in the game at random times make it sometimes frustrating.
* Strongholds, camps, and side missions can get very repetitive, if not boring.
* Jumping in the game is so silly and useless. The interact button can leap over major obstacles, whereas the jump button can barely jump a foot high. Just straight silly.
* While fun, melee combat is OP. In fact considering low ammo you often don't have a choice, which leads to repetition.
* You only have a shotgun as personal weapon. Most weaponry is in your car, with limited ammo.
* Smashing button for interactions in a game is so year 2000...


Overall : 70/100. Worth a buy on huge Steam sale.

reviewText:
Absolutely flawlessly optimized game. The only thing that I can literally say bad about this game's performance is a couple glitches here and there (fell through the map once, car span wildly into the sky another time) that don't even happen that often, once every 8+ hours. As for the length of the game, it took me 24 hours of play time (23 hours, 53 minutes to be exact) to complete all of the story missions & lower the threat level for Jeet's territory to null. The game counts that to be around 40% of the game completed, I'm sure the rest being all of the scavenging locations and whatnot. This game will without a doubt last you more than 48 hours of playtime to 100% it. I picked this game up for $23, and to give a general summary of the purchase, was well god damn worth every penny. Never got bored of it through my three or four binge sessions, either, a nice touch. Only complaint really though is that the combat is basically mash X (or square, for PS controllers), press Y if you see an indicator to counter an attack, and for unavoidable attacks, lunge out of the way. A slight complaint, too, is that the controls are actually smoothed, an effect similar to mouse acceleration, unfortunately, I didn't find a setting to turn this behavior off. Fortunately, after the first hour or two, you will get used to it and you won't feel it thereafter.

As for the optimization (because it needs it's own paragraph): you can probably run this on a toaster at lowest settings, which really speaks something. My mediocre cards (2x R9 270x, 4GB VRAM, OC edition) can run this game at 60FPS+ with every single setting maxed out with vsync on. In comparison, I get ~60FPS in BF4 on low-medium settings. To summarize, this game is an absolutely optimized beast.

Completely would recommend this game, seen the movies or not.

reviewText:
2 hours in so far so good. OK looking graphics but runs very smoothly at 60fps with everything maxed. Xbox controller working well but I have not tried it with kb and mouse.

The map is huge, with lots to do but this may get a bit repetative as far as I can tell. It feels a bit like Shadow of Mordor and Assassin Creed with similar combat to the Arkham series of games, but with slightly different controls. Combat and driving flows well using controller and is easy to pick up and master.

Story is interesting so far with plenty of upgrades and stuff to earn through gameplay. It looks quite like Rage but it has more emphasis on hand to hand and car combat. I imagine it will be a game that is easy to 100% but rather time consuming. As I said I think the side missions and collectibles could be tedious but I am enjoying it all so far.

I paid £20 and I am very happy with my purchase. Certainly worthy a punt.
